From:	Carmen Opazo <cgoq2002@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 14, 2006 8:29 AM
To:	monitor@amnistia.cl; press@washingtonpost.com; WebEditors@newsweek.com; oped@nytimes.com; national@latimes.com; oped@globe.com; dwilson@MiamiHerald.com; tips@tribune.com; wsj.ltrs@wsj.com; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Pena de muerte a Angel Daz / intervencion gobernador urgente



Estimados Seores,

Me dirigo a ustedes para oponerme a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, e indicar todas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo.

Primero, quiero manifestar mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, y dejar claro que no pretendo restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni del sufrimiento que ha causado.

Hay una gran disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos.

Siento una gran preocupacin por el uso contra ngel Daz del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, que es un tipo de testimonio notoriamente poco fiable.

Les recuerdo que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte.

Sealo que una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena.

Por estas razones pido al gobernador que intervenga para detener esta ejecucin.

Agradeciendo su atencin,


------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dear Sirs,

I m writing to you to oppose the execution of ngel Nieves Daz, based on a number of facts which cast doubt on his capacity to represent himself, and the fairness of his trial.

First of all I would like to manifest my support for the family of Joseph Nagy, killed in 1979, and explain that in no way do I mean to belittle the gravity of the crime committed, nor of the suffering it has caused. 

There is, however, considerable disparity in this case, in which one of the accused has been condemned to death, while another has received a life sentence, despite the contradictory testimonies about who fired the shots. 

I feel extremely concerned about the use of a testimony from somebody in jail against ngel Daz, because history has shown that these types of testimonies are notoriously untrustworthy.

I remind you also that four members of the jury did not vote in favour of the death sentence in this case. 

I also draw your attention to the fact that a recent investigation has identified serious problems in the system of the application of the death penalty in Florida, amongst which figure the geographic and racial disparities, and the fact that a unanimous decision by the jury is not required to impose the death penalty. 

For the above reasons I ask the governor to intervene and prevent the death penalty in this case. 

Yours sincerely,


-------------------------- 
Carmen Gloria Opazo Quiroz
Santiago
Chile
--------------------------

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dear Sirs,

I m writing to you to oppose the execution of ngel Nieves Daz, based on a number of facts which cast doubt on his capacity to represent himself, and the fairness of his trial.

First of all I would like to manifest my support for the family of Joseph Nagy, killed in 1979, and explain that in no way do I mean to belittle the gravity of the crime committed, nor of the suffering it has caused. 

There is, however, considerable disparity in this case, in which one of the accused has been condemned to death, while another has received a life sentence, despite the contradictory testimonies about who fired the shots. 

I feel extremely concerned about the use of a testimony from somebody in jail against ngel Daz, because history has shown that these types of testimonies are notoriously untrustworthy.

I remind you also that four members of the jury did not vote in favour of the death sentence in this case. 

I also draw your attention to the fact that a recent investigation has identified serious problems in the system of the application of the death penalty in Florida, amongst which figure the geographic and racial disparities, and the fact that a unanimous decision by the jury is not required to impose the death penalty.  

For the above reasons I ask the governor to intervene and prevent the death penalty in this case. 

Yours sincerely,


-------------------------- 
francisco daza
El Rosario
espaa
--------------------------

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	my grandson

	

Dear Mr. Bush,
 
I am writing to you on behalf of my ten year old grandson, Tyler Morris Causey who lives in Port Orange. He is presently staying with his other Grandmother, Jennifer Petteway. Tyler's mother has been arrested several times on prescription fraud and other charges. She is now in Volusia County Branch Jail. I believe she has 7 counts on her. On November 24 of this year, there was an article in the local newspaper about her. She has posted bail the other times she has been in jail, but this time she has been in there approximately 2 weeks. We do not know at this point what her punishment will be nor do we know if and how long it will take her to get her life back on track once she has served her sentence.
 
I am writing this because of my concern about Tyler. His other grandmother has been keeping him and has had him a good portion of his life while the mother has worked, etc.  My son, Ben Causey, lives here in Mississippi and would like for Tyler to come live with him. I believe he needs his father. Tyler's mother, Stephanie Marie Campe, believes she can make the decision about where Tyler lives. His grandmother in Port Orange has stated to me that she is "exhausted and about to have a breakdown".  My son is willing and happy to have his son come live with him.  However, we have no papers saying that he will be under my son's custody. Stephanie knows that we need the paper to get him enrolled in school here and also to get medical help. She has expressed to her mother that she probably won' t sign anything. Tyler usually comes to Mississippi for Christmas, however, we are trying to get some paperwork done before he flies here so there will be no concern with kidnaping.
 
The social worker there is Mrs. Brown. She has not returned Jennifer's(grandmother) call. I felt like she would know what needs to be done. Even if Stephanie served no sentence, she will not be ready to have Tyler back. I am hoping that you can help us with this matter. My son's attorney is drawing up papers now. We do not want Tyler going to a foster home since he has a loving father and family here. His grandmother there states that she will sign papers saying Tyler needs to be with his father. 
 
Anything you can do to help will be greatly appreciated.
Tyler's mother is Stephanie Marie Campe, DOB 9/20/78. Her booking number is ws660989.

                                            Sincerely,
 
                                               Ann Causey
                                               Jackson, MS

> Subject: Law of Contracts
> 
> 
> Dear Governor Bush:
> 
> A contract dispute with the Home Depot was sent to
> their Tampa office over a year ago.  The job was done
> from their Columbia office in the state of Maryland.
> The motto of Satisfaction Guaranteed was not observed.
> Then, I sent detailed photocopies of all related in-
> formation to the Florida State's Attorney's office.
> Again, complete lack of analysis and action.  So, I
> took the case to our Maryland State's Attorney's office.
> There, they did try very much to resolve the matter,
> but it ended with one of Home Depot's personnel stating
> that they would not discuss the matter any more, etc.
> They ignored all the relevant facts, of omitting three
> important parts to the roof contract.  This now seems
> to have added up to about five years.  I stopped all
> action, some months ago, but thought they still need
> correcting at their various offices involved in this
> case. Some think that after three years, by Statute of
> Limitations, that they no longer owe, and that there is
> no case.  However, on the back of their contracts, they
> specify that any dispute has to go through Arbitration
> (I think it is the American Arbitration Association.)
> at the Tampa location. No one contacted explained if
> the company pays or what?  The Annapolis office, the
> Columbia office, the Tampa office and eventually, the
> Georgia executive office all ignored the facts, and
> even our Dept. of Licensing and Attorney General's staff
> could not get them to honor their own contract and
> Satisfaction Guarantee.  Maybe your office could remind
> them of their obligations.  No response to me is re-
> quired, but for the hours of effort to correct this,
> it seemed that something should be done to  prevent
> this sort of result.  Thank you for your interest.
> 
> Ms.  Mary L. Hooker
> 2128 Folkstone Road
> Timonium, Maryland   21093
Thank you for the reply.  I thought that I could not
take it to the court system, because the company
contract states that any dispute has to be arbitrated
right there in Florida.  Also, I thought that there was
a service for such matters, connected with the state's
attorney's office.  Which office deals with Home
Improvement complaints?  These interstate cases are
very inconvenient, after about five years, what could
one expect, "Their minds are made up, don't confuse
them with the facts."  Neither arbitration nor courts
were necessary, the office in Columbia had eye witnesses
but the contract office is in Tampa, Florida.  I will
and did not lose the case, no matter what they all did,
or did not do.  It is like one said:  Who won the
San Francisco earthquake?

From:	mdiaz3@metlife.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 5:17 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Pleading for Life


Dear Governor, 

My name is Mildred Diaz a Florida Resident, actively pursing my education in the Criminal Justice field.  I'm a hard working single mother of 2 (ages 8 and 2), with only 23 years of life.  I'm not the most intelligent person and definitely not the best when it comes down to writing to an Honorable person as yourself, but here it goes. 

Yesterday, I receive a phone call from my mother to turn the news on and watch the case of Angel Nieves Diaz.  I must admit that to my surprise this was not the local news, it was the news in Puerto Rico.  I've been going around in circles trying to find the logic in this case.  I've read a few articles on the media and correct me if I'm wrong, but this case is just bogus.  At only 1 hour from the execution of this individual which I don't know but believe his innocence is fact, how is it possible for a person not to receive an interpreter at trial when there is a language barrier.  That being said, where are our civil rights as United States Citizens?   

From what I have read in simple black in white, how is it possible for this person to be executed when the key prosecution witness at the trial in 1985 of Angel Nieves Diaz has recanted his testimony, which had been a key part of the evidence that convicted Angel Nieves Diaz of murder.  Due to the Judge refusing to provide the sworn affidavit that Ralph Gajus signed stating that his testimony was false, now we have an individual being sentenced to death for lack of communication, lack of judgement, flaws in the justice system, and lack of evidence.  How can we (citizens of the US) feel secure and safe with a justice system that instead of making justice, they're constantly committing injustice acts.  How many people have been proven innocent after having served many years and prison? 

The reason behind my anger is why would I want to continue to pursue my education in the Criminal Justice field if I myself don't believe the justice system is right. 

Why deny the right to live to a person that has been convicted with very few and petty evidence.  Why not rethink this whole scenario and reopen the case and let him prove his innocence, if that's what he says he is.   

Remember:   A person is always innocent until proven guilty and in this case that lacks evidence "How do we know he is not innocent"? 

I appreciate your time and hope you can do something for this individual, although, by the time you read this he might already be executed. 

Have a blessed day and Happy Holidays for you and your loved ones. 


Thank You,

Mildred Diaz
New Business Specialist I
Life Underwriting Department
18210 Crane Nest Drive
Tampa, FL  33647
(813) 983-6807

Dear Governor,
I wish to appeal to you on behalf of Angel Nieves Diaz, who is due to be executed on dec. 13, 2006. My sympathies go out to the family and loved ones of Joseph Nagy, and I agree this was a very tragic event that cannot go unpunished. However, ending the life of the person who has been convicted is never a solution to the problem of crime facing our society ( particularly when there is strong evidence that Angel Nieves Diaz is innocent). 
It is my belief that Angel Nieves Diaz deserves a stay of execution on the basis of coerced testimony, the fact that he was allowed to represent himself despite a lack of knowledge of the law and a language barrier, and also because of the influencing of the jury through extensive security measures.
It is not too late to correct this miscarriadge of justice. There are simply too many questions regarding Mr. Diaz'sguilt. In view of he information mentionned above, I urge you to act quickly to correct this situation and spare Angel Diaz's life.
Thank you for your time and your consideration of this important and urgent matter.

sentence but Angel Daz is getting death sentence.I can't see that it is fair.His crime was
robbing that shop of Mr.Nagy.I also want to question his competency to stand trial and
represent himself.
Ralph Gajus,a key prosecution witness at the trial has now recanted his testimony against 
Angel Daz.I therefor doubt the reliability of the jury's verdict and moreover 4 jurors did not
vote for the death sentence.Without the testimony of Ralph Gajus more of the jurors would have
voted against the death sentence. 
Also I want to point out that recent research  has found serious problems with Florida's capital 
justice system,including geographic and racial disparities,and the lack of a requirement for
unanimity in jury sentencing decisions. 
Dear Governor,I would like you to intervene to stop this execution.

Banyoles, 13 de diciembre de 2.006.



Sr. Gobernador:


Como persona y ser humano quiero manifestar mi apoyo a la 
familia de Joseph Nary, pues yo tambin he perdido a un ser 
querido, concretamente a mi hermano cuando slo contaba ste 
17 aos. No pretendo en ningn momento restar importancia a la 
gravedad de este crimen y puedo ser bien conocedora del 
sufrimiento que ha causado a familiares y allegados.

Me dirijo a usted para manifestarle mi preocupacin por la 
reputacin de su pas ante la comunidad internacional pues 
moralmente me opongo a creer que la justicia verdadera 
sea: Ojo por ojo, diente por diente. Ante un crimen como el 
que padeci el Sr. Joseph Nary la justicia debe actuar, pero 
segn mi modo de ver la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz no es 
una solucin pues:

1.- Son diversas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad 
para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo. 

2.- Creo que se ha concurrido en una disparidad de condenas en 
este caso, pues uno de los acusados ha recibido una pena de 
cadena perpetua y el otro una condena a muerte, pese a los 
testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los 
disparos.

3.- Supongo que su experiencia como conocedor del sistema 
judicial americano le ha demostrado en ms de una ocasin que 
el uso de un informador encarcelado como testimonio es poco 
fiable.

4.- Cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la 
pena de muerte. 

5.- Una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas 
en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en su estado 
(Florida): la existencia de disparidades geogrficas, raciales 
y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad para imponer la 
pena.

Le ruego que intervenga para detener esta ejecucin. En el 
caso que mi carta llegue ya tarde le pido humildemente que 
tenga en cuenta mis razones en otros casos similares y que 
todo ello lleve a una reflexin social en su pas y la futura 
abolicin de esta pena capital.

Atentamente.

Anna Ma. Bou i
Nolla.

From:	Wanda Rodriguez <wandarodz@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 1:02 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

Estimado Sr. Gobernador el Estado de la Florida, USA.:
 
Con esta comunicacin quiero expresar lo siguiente en torno al caso del Sr. Angel Nieves Diaz.
 
Quiero exponer:
 
1.  Mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, y aclaro que no pretendo restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni al sufrimiento que ha causado.
 
2.  ME OPONGO TERMINANTEMENTE a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, debido todas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo.
 
3. Sealo la disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos.
 
4.  Sealo que Ralph Gajus, testigo de cargo fundamental en el juicio, se ha retractado de su testimonio contra ngel Daz, lo que pone an ms en duda la fiabilidad del veredicto emitido por el jurado.
 
5.  Sealo que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte, lo que indica una posible duda residual en su mente sobre la culpabilidad del acusado y sugiere que, sin el testimonio de Ralph Gajus, es posible que ms miembros del jurado hubieran votado contra la condena de muerte.
 
6.  Sealo adems que una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena.
 
7.  Por estos motivos pido al Honorable Gobernador del Estado de la Florida, clemencia para Angel Nieves Diaz.
 
 
Que Dios todopodereoso ilumine sus almas y corazones y no permitan que el hombre interprete la justicia tomando en sus manos una vida por otra vida.
 
Dios les Bendiga!
 
Atentamente,
 
Wanda Rodrguez
San Juan, PR

Por favor tenga misericordia

From:	karina Escobar <karinaescobarm@yahoo.es>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 12:06 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: URGENT ACTION

Dear Warren:
 
Thank you for your reply and for taking the time to read my urgent action and for answering my request, I trust that Governor Bush will do the best for the community and also for ngel Daz as an individual human being.

----- Mensaje original ----
De: Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
Para: karina Escobar <karinaescobarm@yahoo.es>
Enviado: martes, 12 de diciembre, 2006 15:38:35
Asunto: RE: URGENT ACTION



  

Dear Friend:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush about a death row inmate.  The Governor appreciates your concerns and asked me to respond on his behalf.

 

Governor Bush believes that the death penalty is appropriate and warranted in certain capital murder cases, and supports its use by the courts in those cases.  The Governor also believes we should look not only to the issues surrounding the defendant, but also to the surviving victims, and to the effect the murder has on our community as a whole, in deciding whether the death penalty is an appropriate punishment.

 

Florida law provides numerous levels of appeals for the convicted individual before the sentence is moved.  Once a person is convicted of an aggravated first-degree murder and sentenced to death in Florida, the state voluntarily provides free legal representation to the convicted murderer until the sentence is carried out or reduced on appeal.  No other state has invested the public resources in capital post conviction legal representation that Florida has been providing for well over a decade. 

 

Governor Bush shares the concerns of many that the death penalty must be reserved for only the most heinous cases.  As the Governor has said many times, the signing of a death warrant is one of the most solemn and somber responsibilities he must undertake, and he does so with humble deliberation.

 

Again, thank you for taking the time to write about this very serious issue.

 

Sincerely,

 

Warren Davis

Office of Citizens Services

Nieves acepta de que cometio un crimen en Puerto Rico.  Sin embargo, este no 
fue el crimen que lo condena a la pena capital.  En una ocacion despues de 
las navidades para ser exacto un 2 de enero hiba a una actividad de la 
iglesia.  En el camino presencie como como un individuo apunalaba a otro en 
la ciudad de Chicago.  Yo estaba con mi actual Pastor y pudimos separarlos.  
Inmediatamente llamamos a la policia y la policia dijo que si queriamos ser 
testigos de lo ocurrido.  !Que sorpresa!  Nos enserraron a mi y al pastor 
porque habia que esperar por los detectives.  Nos trataron como si fueramos 
nosotros los delincuentes y hasta nos dijeron que teniamos derecho a un 
abogado.  Nos dejaron ir despues de largas horas.  Con esto voy a terminar.  
Pudimos ser victimas del sistema y gracias a Dios no paso nada.  Pero, que 
tal de aquellos que no tuvieron la misma suerte y son presos inocentes.  
!Por favor pare esta muerte!  Ojala que esta carta llegue a tiempo y lo 
conmueva.

From:	melliott3@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 11:22 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Diaz Clemency

 Dear Governor Bush,
 
Please use your lawful Executive Clemency process to commute the sentence of Angel Nieves Diaz to life in prison.  
 
The killing of Joseph Nagy was a tragedy.  The needless killing of yet another man is also a tragedy.  I have lost a loved one to murder and know the heartache of such a loss.  Nothing can be gained by the killing of someone already locked up in prison.  
 
The Governor says he is concerned about the effect that murder has on our community.  The uneccessary killing of an already locked up prisoner also has an effect on our community.  It simply teaches that killing out of anger and vengeance is acceptable, even praiseworthy.  The people of Florida look to you for guidance.  What better legacy to leave than one of the power of mercy, not the horror of needless homicide?
 
Christmas is the absolute worst time to subject the citizens of our great state to the "somber and solemn" spectacle of the uneccessary killing of a captive prisoner.  Jesus was an executed prisoner whose sentence was carried out on authority of the governor of Palestine.  In 2000 years, what have we learned?
 
Sincerely,
 
Mark Elliott

Clearwater, FL 33767

From:	John Ahearn <jjaeagle@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 10:06 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	the scheduled execution of Angel Nieves Diaz 

 December 13, 2006

 

Governor Jeb Bush

The capitol

400 South Monroe Street

Tallahassee, FL 32399

                                                                        

 

Dear Governor:

 

I am writing to you on matter of great concerned to many people in the international community and in our own country.  It is concerning the scheduled execution of Angel Nieves Diaz on December 13, 2006 the murders of Joseph Nagy in Miami.    My sympathy goes to the family and friends of Joseph Nagy.  In no manner do I excuse their death or to minimize the suffering it has caused.

 

I am opposed to his execution on the evidence which calls in to question his competency to stand trial and represent himself.  There is a disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman.

 

Ralph Gajus, a key prosecution witness at the trial, ahs now recanted his testimony against Angel Diaz, calling into further doubt the reliability of the jurys verdict.  Four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty indicating a possible residential doubt in their minds about the defendants guilt. It suggests that without the testimony of Ralph Gajus more of the jurors might have voted against a death sentence.  Recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and lacks a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

 

I call on you to intervene to stop this execution.

 

Thank you for your time and consideration in this matter. 

 

Sincerely,

John J. Ahearn

872 Massachusetts Ave. Apt 407

Cambridge, MA 02139

El propsito de estas cortas letras es muy simple; apelar a usted por la vida del Sr. ngel Nieves Daz. Al leer todo el artculo publicado en los diferentes medios se puede llegar claramente a la conclusin de que hubo fallas en el proceso judicial que se llevo a cabo. No hay que ser abogado ni tener un alto grado de educacin para analizar todas estas fallas las cuales quieren obviarse en estos momentos; ya sean por razones polticas, raciales o por el mero hecho de no dar el brazo a torcer. Que es peor, tener que lamentarse cuando finalmente se pruebe que el es inocente o el no actuar de inmediato y proveerle un nuevo juicio y la oportunidad de vivir? Solo espero que Dios lo ilumine y le de mucha sabidura para que usted pueda reanalizar este caso en sus meritos. Miles de personas en todo el mundo se lo agradeceran.

Vctor Serrano

From:	Viera, Danny <Danny.Viera@fairfieldresorts.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 9:31 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

 

Governor Jeb Bush 
The Capitol 
400 South Monroe Street 
Tallahassee, FL 32399 
U S A 
Fax:   001 - 850 - 487 0801 



Dear Governor, 


Reportedly, 

      Mr Angel Nieves Diaz, aged 55,

is scheduled for execution in Florida on 13 December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder, during a robbery, of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. 

I want to express my sympathy for the family of Mr Nagy and I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused. 

However, I oppose the execution of Mr Angel Nieves Diaz, as his competency to stand trial and represent himself must be called into question. There is a striking disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. Ralph Gajus, a key prosecution witness at the trial, has now recanted his testimony against Angel Diaz; this calls into further doubt the reliability of the jury's verdict. I must note that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty, indicating a possible residual doubt in their minds about the defendant's guilt; this lets me suggest that without the testimony of Ralph Gajus more of the jurors might have voted against a death sentence. 

Furthermore, I want to call your attention to the fact that recent research has found serious problems with Florida's capital justice system, including geographical and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions. It is to be noted that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty. 

Dear Governor, please intervene to stop this execution. 


Respectfully,

 

           Danny Joe Viera Otero

It is solely for the use of the individual(s) or the entity(ies) originally intended. Access to this electronic mail message by anyone else is unauthorized. If you are not the intended recipient, be advised that any unauthorized review, disclosure, copying, distribution or use of this information, or any action taken or omitted to be taken in reliance on it, is prohibited and may be unlawful. Please notify the sender immediately if you have received this electronic message by mistake, and destroy all copies of the original message."

avait dit quil avait abattu Joseph Nagy. Ralph Gajus a maintenant fourni

fournie  laccusation dans laffaire Diaz. Pendant les dlibrations du

From:	Elizabeth Carrasquillo <ecarrasquillo@dom.disciples.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 8:57 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Felix Ortiz; David Vargas; rogersc@ucc.org
Subject:	Scheduled Execution of Angel Nieves Diaz

Importance:	High

Dear Governor Bush:

 

As Co-Executives of Global Ministries, the missionary unit of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ, we write to request your intervention and clemency in the case of Angel Nieves Daz who has been sentenced to death by the State of Florida and whose execution is set for December 13, 2006.  As people of faith we believe that all life is sacred and that compassion for life does not negate the need to be accountable for violent crimes.  We believe that capital punishment does not abolish crime but rather feeds into the already present cycle of violence affecting our society.

 

Mr. Nieves Daz was convicted for the murder of Joseph Nagy and has been imprisoned for over 20 years.  While we have sympathy for the family of Mr. Nagy, we do not believe Mr. Nieves death will be just retribution for his loss.  In addition, our partner in mission, Amnesty International, has been brought to our attention that this execution may take place in spite of growing national concern about the numerous problems associated with the administration of the death penalty.  This execution is scheduled at a time when other groups such as the American Bar Association (ABA) are raising significant questions about the fairness of Floridas death penalty system.  

 

Recently, a blue-ribbon assessment panel appointed by the ABA revealed that Floridas capital punishment policies fail to meet basic standards of fairness and justice.  The nine-member assessment team concluded that the state does not provide adequate safeguards to prevent the execution of an innocent person; 22 people have been released from death row in Florida due to evidence of their wrongful conviction. 

 

It is deeply unsettling that this execution would proceed while Floridas capital justice system remains mired in geographic and racial disparities. Florida is also the only state in the country that does not require a jury to be unanimous in recommending the death penalty.  In this case, it should be noted that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty.

 

We humbly request that you demonstrate your respect for justice and human life by doing everything in your power to stop the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz.  Thank you for your time and attention to this serious matter.

 

Respectfully in Christ

Rev. Dr. David A. Vargas

Rev. Cally Rogers-Witte

Co-Executive Directors, Global Ministries

 

 

Rev. Elizabeth Carrasquillo

Program Associate for Latin America/Caribbean

Global Ministries     P.O. Box 1986     Indianapolis IN 46206 USA

Tel:  +1-317-713-2562   Fax:  +1-317-635-4323

ecarrasq@dom.disciples.org    www.globalministries.org

 

A common witness of the Division of Overseas Ministries, Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and Wider Church Ministries, United Church of Christ.  Global Ministries is committed to Critical Presence ... meeting God's people and creation at the point of deepest need:  spiritually, physically, emotionally, and/or economically

 

Un testimonio conjunto de la Divisin de Ministerios de Ultramar, Iglesia Cristiana (Discpulos de Cristo) y Ministerios Extendidos de la Iglesia Unida de Cristo.  Ministerios Globales se compromete a la Presencia Crtica ... encontrando al pueblo de Dios y la creacin en el punto de la necesidad ms profunda:  espiritualmente, fsicamente, emocionalmente, y/o econmicamente.

From:	Dominique Bataillon <d.bataillon@tiscali.fr>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 13, 2006 5:34 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Governor, 




I wish to appeal to you on behalf of ANGEL NIEVES DIAZ, who is due to be executed on Dec. 13, 2006.  My sympathies go out to the family and loved ones of Joseph Nagy, and I agree this was a very tragic event that cannot go unpunished. However, ending the life of the person who has been convicted is never a solution to the problem of crime facing our society (particularly when there is strong evidence that ANGEL NIEVES DIAZ is innocent). 

Mr. Diaz maintains that he was with his girlfriend in Connecticut the night of the shootings and did not learn of they until three days after they it had taken place.  This girlfriend ultimately testified against Diaz, but only after the police coerced her through the threat of drug charges.  At a post-conviction hearing, she admitted that she had lied. Mr. Diaz was offered a plea bargain, but chose to proceed with the trial, claiming 
innocence.  His cellmate and alleged co-conspirator Angel Toro also testified against Diaz.  Mr. Toro received a life sentence for his testimony. 

This disparity in the sentences handed out to the co-defendents highlights further irregularities in this case.  It may be noted that these disparities have taken place despite the uncertainty of who fired the fatal shot. 

Yet another questionable testimony against Mr. Diaz is that of Ralph Gajus, a prison informer, who admitted that his testimony against Angel Diaz was false and motivated by anger against the defendent.  Furthermore, he stated that he was not told who fired the fatal shot and remains unaware of the facts to this day.  The closeness of the jury's vote (a final outcome of 8 votes to 4), which took Mr. Gajus' testimony into account, suggests that a different outcome could very possibly have come about if Mr. Gajus had not given his false testimony. 

It is my belief that Angel Nieves Diaz deserves a stay of execution on the basis of coerced testimony, the fact that he was allowed to represent himself despite a lack of knowledge of the law and a language barrier, and also because of the influencing of the jury through extensive security measures. 

It is not too late to correct this miscarriage of justice.  There are simply too many questions regarding Mr. Diaz's guilt.  In view of the information mentioned above, I urge you to act quickly to correct this situation and spare Angel Diaz's life. 

Thank you for your time and your consideration of this important and urgent  matter.

Encara la familia un suspenso supremo

Por Jos A. Delgado / Enviado Especial

Confirma que no hay decisin an un vocero
del mximo foro judicial. 

RAIFORD, Florida - El Tribunal Supremo de Estados Unidos mantena
an en vilo a la familia del prisionero boricua ngel Nieves
Daz, quien puede ser ejecutado esta noche como consecuencia de su
condena por un caso de asesinato.
No hay decisin an, manifest anoche
una portavoz del mximo foro judicial estadounidense, con base en
Washington, D.C.
La falta de decisin pudiera alimentar las esperanzas de la familia
de Nieves Daz, que ha acampado en un municipio aledao a la
prisin estatal de Florida, ubicada en la localidad de Raiford, que
tiene slo cerca de 200 habitantes.
Pudiera dar esperanzas. Pero, hay ocasiones en que el Tribunal
Supremo no se expresa y el caso se torna acadmico,
indic Osvaldo Burgos, director ejecutivo de la Comisin de
Derechos Civiles, quien anoche viajaba desde San Juan a esta zona para
acompaar a la familia.
La defensa de Nieves Daz elev el lunes un recurso de
certiorari ante el Supremo estadounidense como parte de sus ltimos
esfuerzos por conseguir aplazar o detener la ejecucin del
prisionero puertorriqueo.
En los ltimos das el Tribunal Supremo de Florida y el
Tribunal de Apelaciones del Undcimo Circuito, con base en Atlanta
(Georgia), rechazaron los argumentos de Nieves Daz en reclamo de
un aplazamiento de la sentencia de muerte o un nuevo proceso judicial.
Autoridades puertorriqueas "incluidos el gobernador
Anbal Acevedo Vil y el comisionado residente en Washington,
Luis Fortuo-, grupos pro derechos civiles y sectores religiosos
han reclamado sin xito al gobernador de Florida, Jeb Bush, para
que se detenga la ejecucin y a favor de una conmutacin de la
pena de muerte.
La primera dama de Puerto Rico, Luisa Gndara, solicit ayer
la intervencin de la primera dama de Florida, Columba Bush.
Como Primera Dama del Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico,
respetuosamente, apelo a su sentido de compasin como nuestra
ltima esperanza de clemencia en nombre del puertorriqueo
ngel Nieves Daz, indic Gndara.
La Conferencia de Obispos Catlicos de Florida se uni
tambin recientemente a los pedidos de clemencia para Nieves
Daz. Al cumplir con esta orden de ejecucin, el
Estado le ensea a nuestros ciudadanos que matar a aquellos que han
matado a otro es aceptable, indica la carta que los obispos
catlicos floridanos le enviaron al gobernador Bush.

From:	George Perez <gperezcpa@onelinkpr.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 8:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Death Penatly of Mr. Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Mr. Bush:

 

The capital punishment is the most extreme form of cruel pain, cruel or degrading. The capital punishment constitutes a violation of the right to the life.  The capital punishment is irreversible and involves the risk of which it executes innocents. It has not been possible to never demonstrate that the capital punishment has greater dissuasive effect front to the delinquency that other punishments.

 

If this is so then are not the relatives of a killer are allowed take mortal revenge on those that put their family member to death?  I wonder how is it fair? And to whom? First, the deceased has a family, perhaps dependents, and these are left harmed and un helped for the most part. There is no restitution by the killer. And the innocents who have lost a loved one must also bear their trauma and suffer its exacerbation through a trial and dealing with lawyers for God's sake. Then there are the dependents and family of the killer who have losses through no fault of their own. The victims pay, the society pays, the friends and family of the killer pays. The killer simply leaves this "veil of sorrow." So where is the equity in that arrangement?  In sum, is it fair to kill a killer? The answer is a resounding "NO". It is not fair to the victims, the relatives of the victims, the relatives of the guilty party, to the society as a whole. Nor, truth be told, is it fair to the killer. How can he or she regain the humanity they lost? How can they redeem themselves? How can they repair the damages done?

 

I am writing to you solely to asking you to concede amnesty for Mr. Angel Nieves Diaz is asking for his right to live.  Let him pay for the rest of his life  in jail of course. Is the right thing to do, is what we expect from a governor that believes in the peoples right to life. The death penalty is the ultimate cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment. 

 

God be with you; I hope that this simple letter will help you make the right decision, you have the power to save a human life; do you have the will; I believe so.

 

Thanks for you time reading my email.

 

God bless you and your family

 

 

George Prez Borrero

PO Box 22705

UPR Station 

San Juan, PR

I would like to beg of you to PLEASE STOP the execution of Angel Diaz who remains scheduled for execution in Florida on the 13th of December even though there is  new infomation.

Further more four  jourors did NOT VOTE FOR THE DEATH PENALTY, indicating a possible residual doubt in their mind  sabout the defendant's guilt and also WITHOUT THE TESTIMONY OF Ralph Gajus MORE OF THE JURORS WOULD HAVE VOTED  AGAINST A DEATH SENTENCE.
 
Recent research has found SERIOUS PROBLEMS with Florida's  capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparitis, and the lack of requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

From:	Barbara English <barbjenglish@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 6:32 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Prevent Unjust Execution

December 12, 2006
The Honorable Jeb Ellis Bush
Governor of the State of Florida
PL 05 The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


Dear Governor Bush,

I appeal to you to do everything in your power to stop the execution of Puerto
Rican national Angel Nieves Diaz.  Mr. Diaz is scheduled to be executed on December
13, 2006, for the 1979 death of Joseph Nagy.

Post-conviction assessments by two mental health experts concluded that Angel
Diaz suffers from certain mental disorders, which contributed to his decision
to represent himself and undermined his ability to do so competently. The presiding
trial judge allowed Mr. Diaz to represent himself even though Mr. Diaz spoke minimal
English, had no knowledge about the law, and had not even completed high school.
Many mentally ill defendants have insisted on representing themselves despite
widespread evidence of their incompetence to do so.

Moreover, during the sentencing phase of this trial, acute disparities in sentencing
became apparent. Despite conflicting evidence about the actual gunman and the
use of unreliable testimony by a jailhouse informant, one defendant received a
life sentence while Mr. Diaz was condemned to death.  Furthermore, evidence was
not raised at the trial about Mr. Diaz's childhood abuse, history of mental problems,
and issues associated with longtime drug addition.  

I am also concerned to learn that a key prosecution witness at the 1985 trial
has recanted his testimony, which had been a key part of the evidence that convicted
Mr. Diaz of murder.

It is deeply unsettling that this execution would proceed while Florida's capital
justice system remains mired in geographic and racial disparities. Florida is
also the only state in the country that does not require a jury to be unanimous
in recommending the death penalty.  In this case, it should be noted that four
of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty.

I have tremendous sympathy for the family and friends of Joseph Nagy, but I
believe capital punishment only perpetuates the cycle of violence. 

Governor Bush, I strongly urge you to demonstrate your respect for justice and
human life by doing everything in your power to stop the execution of Angel Nieves
Diaz.  

Thank you for your time and attention to this serious matter.

Sincerely,

Barbara English
7 Sunbury Dr
Aliso Viejo, CA 92656-5284

From:	edurne arriazu gil <edur.ag@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 6:29 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; aauu@es.amnesty.org
Subject:	Ejecucion de Angel Nieves Diaz

Martes, 12 de Diciembre de 2006                                                              Edurne Arriazu Gil

                                                                                                           Tudela (Navarra)

                                                                                                                     Espaa

Estimado Gobernador de Florida, Don Jeb Bush:

Tengo a bien darle mis mas sinceras gracias y entregarle todo mi respeto por haber contestado a mi correo electronico comentandole que habia llegado a mi conocimiento el caso particular de Angel Nieves Diaz, ciudadano de Florida y condenado a pena de muerte en 1985 por el asesinato de Joseph Nagy, asesinado el 29 de Diciembre de 1979 en el bar que regentaba (Velvet Swong Lounge), cuando tres atracadores robaron en el establecimiento. No hubo testigos presenciales del disparo y Angel nieves Diaz y Angel Toro fueron condenados por asesinato en primer grado en 1984, pero el juicio se retraso hasta Diciembre de 1985, para entonces Angel Toro ya se habia declarado culpable de asesinato en primer grado a cambio de una pena de cadena perpetua.

   La exnovia de Angel Diaz testifico que, la noche del delito, este le dijo que Angel Toro habia disparado contra un hombre durante el robo. Ademas el testimonio de otras dos personas, que se encontraban en el bar durante el atraco declararon que Angel Diaz no habia sido el autor de los diaparos, sin embargo, un informador encarcelado, Ralf Gajus, declaro que, mientras estaban en la prision, Angel Diaz habia declarado que habia disparado a Joseph Nagy.

Ralf Gajus ha realizado ahora una declaracion jurada en la que dice su testimonio en el jucio fue falso, y que Angel Diaz nunca le confeso que fuera el autor de los disparos. Afirma que su testimonio en el juicio fue motivado por el deseo de obtener el favor de la fiscalia en su propio caso de asesinato. En el juicio declaro que no le habian prometido nada a cambio por su testimonio, sin embargo , en la determinacion de la pena de su caso, un policia habia testificado sobre la ayuda que Gajus habia prestado a la fiscalia.

Durante las deliberaciones del jurado en el caso de Angel Diaz, el jurado pidio copias del testimonio de Gajus, pero el juez se nego a proporcionarselas, y dio instrucciones al jurado de que basaran su veredicto en lo que el testigo habia dicho. El veredicto  del jurado fue de culpabilidad. La retraccion de Ralf Gajus pone aun mas en duda la fiabilidad del veredicto de 1985. 

El 27 de Noviembre, los abogados de Angel Diaz presentaron una nueva mocion basandose en este nuevo hecho, aun asi, sigue previsto que Angel Diaz sea ejecutado antes de acabar el ao.

Le agradezco que halla empleado parte de su valiso tiempo a leer mi correo electronico, y a poner en mi conocimiento todo lo referente a la ley de  pena de muerte que rige en el Estado de Florida, para nada estoy cuestionando la manera que tienen ustedes de juzgar a los presuntos delincuentes, lo unico que le pido es que Angel Nieves Diaz reciba un juicio justo, basado en las pruebas y testimonios fiables, y se le de la oportunidad de ser juzgado con todas las garantias que ofrece el sistema judicial de Florida, sin ser discriminado por su raza, credo o cualquier otra condicion que sea motivo de discriminacion.

Espero y deseo fervientemente que intervenga en este caso, y desde su ilustre persona se garantice que Angel Nieves Diaz reciba pues un nuevo juicio, donde sus abogados puedan demostrar que el no fue el autor de los disparos que causaron la muerte desgraciadamente de Joseph Nagy.

                                                                                                    Atenta y respetuosamente, Edurne Arriazu.




  _____  

From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
Subject: Regaarding a death row inmate
Date: Tue, 12 Dec 2006 11:13:24 -0500


Dear Friend:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush about a death row inmate.  The Governor appreciates your  concerns and asked me to respond on his behalf.

 

Governor Bush believes that the death penalty is appropriate and warranted in certain capital murder cases, and supports its use by the courts in those cases.  The Governor also believes we should look not only to the issues surrounding the defendant, but also to the surviving victims, and to the effect the murder has on our community as a whole, in deciding whether the death penalty is an appropriate punishment.

 

Florida law provides numerous levels of appeals for the convicted individual before the sentence is moved.  Once a person is convicted of an aggravated first-degree murder and sentenced to death in Florida, the state voluntarily provides free legal representation to the convicted murderer until the sentence is carried out or reduced on appeal.  No other state has invested the public resources in capital post conviction legal representation that Florida has been providing for well over a decade. 

 

Governor Bush shares the concerns of many that the death penalty must be reserved for only the most heinous cases.  As the Governor has said many times, the signing of a death warrant is one of the most solemn and somber responsibilities he must undertake, and he does so with humble deliberation.

 

Again, thank you for taking the time to write about this very serious issue.

 

Sincerely,

 

Warren Davis

Office of Citizens Services

From:	Roberto O.Torres Vaello <titotorres99@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 6:11 PM
To:	monitor@amnistia.cl; press@washingtonpost.com; WebEditors@newsweek.com; oped@nytimes.com; national@latimes.com; oped@globe.com; dwilson@MiamiHerald.com; tips@tribune.com; wsj.ltrs@wsj.com; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Plea for intervention by local governor in ngel Daz death penalty case

Estimados Seores,

Me dirigo a ustedes para oponerme a la ejecucin de ngel 
Nieves Daz, e indicar todas las seales que ponen en duda 
su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s 
mismo.

Primero, quiero manifestar mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph 
Nagy, asesinado en 1979, y dejar claro que no pretendo 
restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni del 
sufrimiento que ha causado.

Hay una gran disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el 
que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el 
otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios 
contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos.

Siento una gran preocupacin por el uso contra ngel Daz 
del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, que es un tipo 
de testimonio notoriamente poco fiable.

Les recuerdo que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no 
votaron a favor de la pena de muerte.

Sealo que una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios 
problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en 
Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades 
geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad 
en el jurado para imponer la pena.

Por estas razones pido al gobernador que intervenga para 
detener esta ejecucin.

Agradeciendo su atencin,


------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dear Sirs,

I m writing to you to oppose the execution of ngel Nieves 
Daz, based on a number of facts which cast doubt on his 
capacity to represent himself, and the fairness of his trial.

First of all I would like to manifest my support for the 
family of Joseph Nagy, killed in 1979, and explain that in no 
way do I mean to belittle the gravity of the crime 
committed, nor of the suffering it has caused. 

There is, however, considerable disparity in this case, in 
which one of the accused has been condemned to death, while 
another has received a life sentence, despite the 
contradictory testimonies about who fired the shots. 

I feel extremely concerned about the use of a testimony 
from somebody in jail against ngel Daz, because history has 
shown that these types of testimonies are notoriously 
untrustworthy.

I remind you also that four members of the jury did not 
vote in favour of the death sentence in this case. 

I also draw your attention to the fact that a recent 
investigation has identified serious problems in the system of 
the application of the death penalty in Florida, amongst 
which figure the geographic and racial disparities, and the 
fact that a unanimous decision by the jury is not required to 
impose the death penalty.  

For the above reasons I ask the governor to intervene and 
prevent the death penalty in this case. 

Yours sincerely,


-------------------------- 
Roberto Omar Torres
Providencia
Chile
-------------------------- 



From:	Judi E. Caruso <judi@hotspare.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 6:10 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please commute sentence of Angel Diaz to life without parole 

Dear Governor Bush:
 
Angel Diaz should not be executed on December 13th.  At a time when the Florida death penalty system is under serious question in terms of
its fairness and high risk of executing people for crimes which they have not commited (see findings of Florida special ABA commission
issued September 19, 2006) it is timely and appropriate to commute Angel Diaz's sentence to life without parole. Although I believe he
may be innocent of the crime of which he was convicted and sentenced to death, I would not ask you to pardon him but merely not to
allow his execution.   There are just too many questions both in his specific case regarding innocence and fairness and too many
questions regarding the fairness and accuracy of Florida's death penalty system to permit his execution.   Having said this, I feel 
tremendous sadness and sympathy for Joseph Nagy's family but I do not believe that the execution of a man who is very possibly 
innocent of the crime for which he was sentenced to death will ease their suffering. In fact, the death penalty in this case has created much 
more suffering for them than the alternative of life without the possibility of parole.  This may also be a timely juncture to consider a 
moratorium on the death penalty in Florida in light of the findings of the special ABA Florida commission.
 
Many thanks for your kind consideration,
 
Judith Caruso, attorney at law
 
   
 
From:	Pehuen <pehuench@entelchile.net>

Subject:	Re: Plea for intervention by local governor in ? death penalty case

Importance:	High


Seores:

Me dirigo a ustedes para oponerme a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, e indicar todas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo.

Primero, quiero manifestar mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, y dejar claro que no pretendo restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni del sufrimiento que ha causado.

Hay una gran disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos.

Siento una gran preocupacin por el uso contra ngel Daz del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, que es un tipo de testimonio notoriamente poco fiable.

Les recuerdo que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte.
Sealo que una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena.

Por estas razones pido al Gobernador que intervenga para detener esta ejecucin. 

Agradezco su atencin a este pedido humanitario,


------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dear Sirs,

I m writing to you to oppose the execution of ngel Nieves Daz, based on a number of facts which cast doubt on his capacity to represent himself, and the fairness of his trial.

First of all I would like to manifest my support for the family of Joseph Nagy, killed in 1979, and explain that in no way do I mean to belittle the gravity of the crime committed, nor of the suffering it has caused. 

There is, however, considerable disparity in this case, in which one of the accused has been condemned to death, while another has received a life sentence, despite the contradictory testimonies about who fired the shots. 

I feel extremely concerned about the use of a testimony from somebody in jail against ngel Daz, because history has shown that these types of testimonies are notoriously untrustworthy.

I remind you also that four members of the jury did not vote in favour of the death sentence in this case. 

I also draw your attention to the fact that a recent investigation has identified serious problems in the system of the application of the death penalty in Florida, amongst which figure the geographic and racial disparities, and the fact that a unanimous decision by the jury is not required to impose the death penalty.  

For the above reasons I plea the Governor to intervene and prevent the death penalty in this case. 

Yours sincerely,


-------------------------- 
Fernando Saravia
Santiago
Chile
--------------------------

12/12/06 12:10 PM
GOVERNOR BUSH,
 
WE ARE THE FAMILY OF ANGEL NIEVES DIAZ, WE IMPLORE TO YOU THAT YOU
PLEASE REVIEW THE INFORMATION I HAVE ATTACHED TO YOU IN REFERENCE TO MY
UNCLE'S CASE.
 
THERE WERE MANY ERRORS AND MIS INFORMATION IN THE LETTER YOU REPLIED TO
OUR GOVERNOR OF PR AND THE SENATE.
 
ANGEL N. DIAZ DID NOT RECEIVE JUSTICE IN HIS TRIAL. 
 
THIS HOLIDAY SEASON WE PLEAD THAT YOU HAVE MERCY AND ASK THAT YOU TAKE
A MINUTE OF YOUR TIME TO REVIEW THIS INFORMATION. OUR FAMILY CONSISTS OF
ATLEAST 400 MEMBERS AND THE SYSTEM IS SHATTERING THE CHRISTMAS OF
ATLEAST 150 CHILDREN IN THIS FAMILY. 
WE LOVE AND RESPECT MY UNCLE, ALL WE ASK IS THAT HE RECEIVES A FAIR
TRIAL.
 
WE ARE DEVASTATED, OUR CHILDREN ARE DEVASTED, OUR CHRISTMAS, A TIME
WHERE WE CELEBRATE THE LIFE OF JESUS CHRIST, WE ARE BEING FORCED TO BE A
PART OF THE DEATH OF AN INNOCENT MAN.
 
HE IS A WONDERFUL, FATHER, SON, BROTHER, GRANDPA, COUSIN, AND UNCLE. 
HE IS SUCH A WONDERFUL BEING, THAT ONCE ANYONE MEETS HIM, THEY ARE
CAPTIVATED AND WANT TO STAY CLOSE TO HIM.  THIS CONSISTS OF FRIENDS OF
THE FAMILY , SARGENTS, CAPTAINS, GUARDS , AND WARDENS. 
 
THE SHOOTER OF THIS CRIME HAS EVEN ADMITTED IN THE ATTACHED AFFIDAVIT
THAT HE IS AN INNOCENT MAN.
 
ONCE AGAIN I WOULD LIKE TO IMPLORE TO YOU, THAT YOU REVIEW THIS ONCE
MORE.
 
AT THE VERY MINIMUM PLEASE GRANT HIM 30 DAYS MORE, SINCE THE COURTS
HAVE BLOCKED ACCESS TO HIS APPEAL ATTORNEYS TO ANY FURTHER EVIDENCE OR
MATERIALS.  
 
IF THIS IS GRANTED THEY WILL BE ABLE TO SHOW YOU THAT THIS INFORMATION
IS TRUE.
 
GOD BLESS YOU AND HOPE THAT YOU ARE ABLE TO TAKE A MINUTE OF YOUR VERY
BUSY SCHEDULE TO REVIEW THIS ONE FINAL TIME.
 
 
 
SINCERELY, 
THE NIEVES, DIAZ, OTERO, TORRES, GONZALEZ, FAMILY

From:	natalia cardemil gil <natalialp_8@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 4:06 PM
To:	monitor@amnistia.cl; press@washingtonpost.com; WebEditors@newsweek.com; oped@nytimes.com; national@latimes.com; oped@globe.com; dwilson@MiamiHerald.com; tips@tribune.com; wsj.ltrs@wsj.com; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Plea for intervention by local governor in ngel Daz death penalty case

>
>Estimados Seores,
>
>Me dirigo a ustedes para oponerme a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, e indicar todas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo.
>
>Primero, quiero manifestar mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, y dejar claro que no pretendo restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni del sufrimiento que ha causado.
>
>Hay una gran disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos.
>
>Siento una gran preocupacin por el uso contra ngel Daz del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, que es un tipo de testimonio notoriamente poco fiable.
>
>Les recuerdo que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte.
>
>Sealo que una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena.
>
>Por estas razones pido al gobernador que intervenga para detener esta ejecucin.
>
>Agradeciendo su atencin,
>
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>Dear Sirs,
>
>I m writing to you to oppose the execution of ngel Nieves Daz, based on a number of facts which cast doubt on his capacity to represent himself, and the fairness of his trial.
>
>First of all I would like to manifest my support for the family of Joseph Nagy, killed in 1979, and explain that in no way do I mean to belittle the gravity of the crime committed, nor of the suffering it has caused.
>
>There is, however, considerable disparity in this case, in which one of the accused has been condemned to death, while another has received a life sentence, despite the contradictory testimonies about who fired the shots.
>
>I feel extremely concerned about the use of a testimony from somebody in jail against ngel Daz, because history has shown that these types of testimonies are notoriously untrustworthy.
>
>I remind you also that four members of the jury did not vote in favour of the death sentence in this case.
>
>I also draw your attention to the fact that a recent investigation has identified serious problems in the system of the application of the death penalty in Florida, amongst which figure the geographic and racial disparities, and the fact that a unanimous decision by the jury is not required to impose the death penalty.
>
>For the above reasons I ask the governor to intervene and prevent the death penalty in this case.
>
>Yours sincerely,
>
>
>--------------------------
>Natalia Cardemil
>La Serena
>Chile
>--------------------------



  _____

Cet e-mail a t envoy depuis un  tlphone i-mode. Pour en savoir plus : http://www.imode.fr, rubrique E-mail 
From:	Thomas Coates Welsh <tcoateswelsh@gmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 4:00 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Richard Paey

Governor Bush,
While your reply brings up legitimate issues with the question of 
clemency, it completely misses the point. Your email seems to suggest 
that Richard Paey's case should be handled by the Florida court system 
and Parole Commission. In case you are not already aware, Richard Paey 
has taken his case to the highest level possible in the Florida court 
system, and the court concluded that while the law was fair, his 
particular case was not and that he should appeal to you for clemency. 
The Florida Parole Commission is completely powerless due to the 
mandatory minimum sentence given. To shrug Mr. Paey's case off as "not 
my problem" is irresponsible and a failure of your duty to the state of 
Florida. The power of granting clemency was vested in you for a reason, 
and plenty of previous governors have not hesitated to use it in cases 
where it was necessary. Please do not use the "complicated rules and 
lengthly procedures" that you talk about as an excuse for ignoring an 
innocent man's plight.
Signed,
Thomas Coates Welsh

Governor Jeb Bush wrote:
> Dear Friend:
>
> Thank you for your letter regarding Richard Paey's criminal conviction and incarceration.  Governor Bush understands your concerns and asked me to respond on his behalf.
>
> As you may know, the Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in criminal court cases.  Each state attorney is an elected official charged with certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether or not to prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction.  This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt shown, and in the best interest of justice.  Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. 
>
> Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's control, determines the issues of control release and early release.  
>
> The clemency function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to await the outcome of court appeals.  For more information, you can write the Office of Executive Clemency at Building C, Room 229, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450.
>
> Thank you again for writing.  Governor Bush hopes this information is helpful.
>
> 						Sincerely,
>
>
>
> 						Warren Davis
> 						Office of Citizens' Services
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Thomas Coates Welsh [mailto:tcoateswelsh@gmail.com]
> Sent: Saturday, December 09, 2006 6:18 PM
> To: Governor Jeb Bush
> Subject: Richard Paey
>
>
> Governor Bush,
>
> I have been following the story of Richard Paey, a man who has served 
> three years of a 25 year minimum sentence for "drug trafficking" the 
> pain-killing drugs he needs to assist with his two well-documented 
> conditions, disorders which give him chronic and excruciating pain which 
> neither you nor I could likely imagine.
>
> In a recent decision, the Florida District Court of Appeals upheld his 
> 25 year minimum sentence, stating that the law had been applied 
> appropriately albeit in a way which evoked great dissent. Judge James 
> Seal even argued that it was an "unusual, illogical, and unjust" 
> sentence for a man who was simply searching for a way to alleviate his 
> excruciating physical condition.
>
> The court concluded that "Mr. Paey's argument about his sentences does 
> not fall on deaf ears, but it falls on the wrong ears." The 
> recommendation for Richard Paey was to seek clemency from the Governor, 
> an act which I hope you will deeply consider. Not only is Richard Paey a 
> pain-stricken lawyer with no previous criminal record, he is also the 
> father of three young children who now go through life without the 
> support of their father who currently resides under the roof of a state 
> penitentiary.
>
> I write to you now to urge you to please grant Richard Paey clemency for 
> his wrongful sentence. You are in the privileged position of being able 
> to change the fate of Mr. Paey, his family, and all of us who follow his 
> ordeal with great sympathy and enormous hope. By granting Richard Paey 
> clemency, you give us all hope for the true nature of the United States 
> justice system and the future of the country. Thank you for your 
> consideration.
>
>
> Signed,
> Thomas Coates Welsh
>
>

From:	action@24h-actions-urgentes.com on behalf of Thierry BAUDON <action@24h-actions-urgentes.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 6:34 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Un message de Thierry BAUDON de PARIS

          EMAIL 
  _____  


Destinataire : Gouverneur de Floride 
                                     email : jeb.bush@myflorida.com 

Expditeur   :  Thierry BAUDON de  PARIS
                        email : thierry.baudon@voila.fr 

Objet :             Floride. Excution prvue pour le 13 dcembre 

  _____  

MESSAGE :

 
Monsieur le Gouverneur, 

Jai appris que Angel Nieves Diaz, 55 ans, doit tre excut le 13 dcembre 2006. 

Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre de Joseph Nagy, le grant du bar du Salon Velvet Swing, commis le 29 dcembre 1979  Miami alors que trois hommes effectuaient un hold-up dans le bar. Laffaire est grave et pnible, puisquil sagit dun crime : justice doit tre rendue, et la famille de Joseph Nagy a droit  toute ma compassion. 

Avant lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, je tiens cependant, Monsieur le Gouverneur,  vous rappeler que plusieurs points mritent dtre vrifis, sous peine denvoyer un innocent sur la chaise lectrique.

Tout dabord, il ny avait pas de tmoin oculaire lorsque le coup de feu a t tir. 

Angel Toro, un autre membre du groupe du hold-up, a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit alors que certains lments indiqueraient que cest lui qui aurait tir le coup mortel. Dailleurs, quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort. Cette disparit des peines reste nanmoins trs surprenante et je mtonne que lunanimit du jury ne soit pas requise pour les condamnations  la peine capitale. 

Enfin, je tiens  souligner que le juge a lui-mme indiqu  Angel Diaz que compte tenu du fait quil ntait pas en mesure de sexprimer en anglais devant le tribunal, quil navait aucune connaissance en droit et quil avait arrt ses tudes avant la fin du secondaire, le tribunal considrait quil lui tait impossible dassurer lui-mme sa dfense. Ce que Angel Diaz a nanmoins fait. 

Je vous demande, Monsieur le Gouverneur, de bien vouloir prendre tous ces lments en compte et dempcher lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, dont la culpabilit ne me semble pas tablie. 

Je vous prie dagrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma considration distingue. 

 
Thierry BAUDON

  _____

Destinataire : Gouverneur de Floride 
                                     email : jeb.bush@myflorida.com 

Expditeur   :  BOURGEOIS ANAIS de  caligny
                        email : 24 h@24h-actions-urgentes;com 

Objet :             Floride. Excution prvue pour le 13 dcembre 

  _____  

MESSAGE :

 
Monsieur le Gouverneur, 

Jai appris que Angel Nieves Diaz, 55 ans, doit tre excut le 13 dcembre 2006. 
Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre de Joseph Nagy, le grant du bar du Salon Velvet Swing, commis le 29 dcembre 1979  Miami alors que trois hommes effectuaient un hold-up dans le bar. Laffaire est grave et pnible, puisquil sagit dun crime : justice doit tre rendue, et la famille de Joseph Nagy a droit  toute ma compassion. 

Avant lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, je tiens Monsieur le Gouverneur,  vous rappeler que plusieurs points mritent dtre vrifis, sous peine denvoyer un innocent sur la chaise lectrique : 
Tout dabord, il ny avait pas de tmoin oculaire lorsque le coup de feu a t tir. 
Angel Toro, un autre membre du groupe du hold-up, a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit alors que certains lments indiqueraient que cest lui qui aurait tir le coup mortel. Dailleurs, quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort. Cette disparit des peines reste nanmoins trs surprenante et je mtonne que lunanimit du jury ne soit pas requise pour les condamnations  la peine capitale. 
Enfin, je tiens  souligner que le juge a lui-mme indiqu  Angel Diaz que compte tenu du fait quil ntait pas en mesure de sexprimer en anglais devant le tribunal, quil navait aucune connaissance en droit et quil avait arrt ses tudes avant la fin du secondaire, le tribunal considrait quil lui tait impossible dassurer lui-mme sa dfense. Ce que Angel Diaz a nanmoins fait. 

Je vous demande, Monsieur le Gouverneur, de bien vouloir prendre tous ces lments en compte et dempcher lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, dont la culpabilit ne me semble pas tablie. 

Je vous prie dagrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma considration distingue. 

 
BOURGEOIS ANAIS

  _____

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Un message de Pavageau de Saintes

          EMAIL 
  _____  


Destinataire : Gouverneur de Floride 
                                     email : jeb.bush@myflorida.com 

Expditeur   :  Pavageau de  Saintes
                        email : mary17_p@hotmail.com 

Objet :             Floride. Excution prvue pour le 13 dcembre 

  _____  

MESSAGE :

 
Mister the Governor, 
I learned that Angel Nieves Diaz, 55 years, must be carried out on December 13, 2006. It was condemned to died in 1986 for the murder of Joseph Nagy, the manager of the bar of the Living room Velvet Swing, made on December 29, 1979 in Miami whereas three men carried out a holdup in the bar. The business is serious and painful, since it acts of a crime: justice must be returned, and the family of Joseph Nagy has right to all my compassion. 
Before the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, I hold Mister the Governor, to recall you that several points deserve to be checked, under penalty of sending innocent on the electric chair: First of all, there was no eyewitness when the shot was drawn. Angel Toro, another member of the group of the holdup, was condemned to the life sentence whereas certain elements would indicate that it is him which would have drawn the mortal blow. Moreover, four of sworn did not vote in favour of the death sentence. 
This disparity of the sorrows remains nevertheless very surprising and I am astonished that the unanimity of the jury is not necessary for the judgments with the capital punishment.
Lastly, I make a point of stressing that the judge indicated itself to Angel Diaz which taking into account the fact that it was not able to be expressed in English in front of the court, that it was not informed any in right and that it had stopped his studies before the end of the secondary, the court considered that it was impossible for him to ensure itself his defense. What Angel Diaz nevertheless did. 
I ask you, Mister the Governor, to be so kind as to take all these elements in account and to prevent the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, of which the culpability does not seem to me not established. 
Sincerely yours 
Mary
 
Pavageau

  _____

                        email : laurenefal@yahoo.fr 

Objet :             Floride. Excution prvue pour le 13 dcembre 

  _____  

MESSAGE :

 
Monsieur le Gouverneur, 

Jai appris que Angel Nieves Diaz, 55 ans, doit tre excut le 13 dcembre 2006. 
Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre de Joseph Nagy, le grant du bar du Salon Velvet Swing, commis le 29 dcembre 1979  Miami alors que trois hommes effectuaient un hold-up dans le bar. Laffaire est grave et pnible, puisquil sagit dun crime : justice doit tre rendue, et la famille de Joseph Nagy a droit  toute ma compassion. 

Avant lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, je tiens Monsieur le Gouverneur,  vous rappeler que plusieurs points mritent dtre vrifis, sous peine denvoyer un innocent sur la chaise lectrique : 
Tout dabord, il ny avait pas de tmoin oculaire lorsque le coup de feu a t tir. 
Angel Toro, un autre membre du groupe du hold-up, a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit alors que certains lments indiqueraient que cest lui qui aurait tir le coup mortel. Dailleurs, quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort. Cette disparit des peines reste nanmoins trs surprenante et je mtonne que lunanimit du jury ne soit pas requise pour les condamnations  la peine capitale. 
Enfin, je tiens  souligner que le juge a lui-mme indiqu  Angel Diaz que compte tenu du fait quil ntait pas en mesure de sexprimer en anglais devant le tribunal, quil navait aucune connaissance en droit et quil avait arrt ses tudes avant la fin du secondaire, le tribunal considrait quil lui tait impossible dassurer lui-mme sa dfense. Ce que Angel Diaz a nanmoins fait. 

Je vous demande, Monsieur le Gouverneur, de bien vouloir prendre tous ces lments en compte et dempcher lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, dont la culpabilit ne me semble pas tablie. 

Je vous prie dagrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma considration distingue. 

 
fallevoz laurene

  _____

Dailleurs, quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort. Cette disparit des peines reste nanmoins trs surprenante et je mtonne que lunanimit du jury ne soit pas requise pour les condamnations  la peine capitale. 
Enfin, je tiens  souligner que le juge a lui-mme indiqu  Angel Diaz que compte tenu du fait quil ntait pas en mesure de sexprimer en anglais devant le tribunal, quil navait aucune connaissance en droit et quil avait arrt ses tudes avant la fin du secondaire, le tribunal considrait quil lui tait impossible dassurer lui-mme sa dfense. Ce que Angel Diaz a nanmoins fait. 

Je vous demande, Monsieur le Gouverneur, de bien vouloir prendre tous ces lments en compte et dempcher lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, dont la culpabilit ne me semble pas tablie. 

Je vous prie dagrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma considration distingue. 

 
Devers Jean Claude

  _____

Monsieur le Gouverneur, 

Jai appris que Angel Nieves Diaz, 55 ans, doit tre excut le 13 dcembre 2006. 
Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre de Joseph Nagy, le grant du bar du Salon Velvet Swing, commis le 29 dcembre 1979  Miami alors que trois hommes effectuaient un hold-up dans le bar. Laffaire est grave et pnible, puisquil sagit dun crime : justice doit tre rendue, et la famille de Joseph Nagy a droit  toute ma compassion. 

Avant lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, je tiens Monsieur le Gouverneur,  vous rappeler que plusieurs points mritent dtre vrifis, sous peine denvoyer un innocent sur la chaise lectrique : 
Tout dabord, il ny avait pas de tmoin oculaire lorsque le coup de feu a t tir. 
Angel Toro, un autre membre du groupe du hold-up, a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit alors que certains lments indiqueraient que cest lui qui aurait tir le coup mortel. Dailleurs, quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort. Cette disparit des peines reste nanmoins trs surprenante et je mtonne que lunanimit du jury ne soit pas requise pour les condamnations  la peine capitale. 
Enfin, je tiens  souligner que le juge a lui-mme indiqu  Angel Diaz que compte tenu du fait quil ntait pas en mesure de sexprimer en anglais devant le tribunal, quil navait aucune connaissance en droit et quil avait arrt ses tudes avant la fin du secondaire, le tribunal considrait quil lui tait impossible dassurer lui-mme sa dfense. Ce que Angel Diaz a nanmoins fait. 

Je vous demande, Monsieur le Gouverneur, de bien vouloir prendre tous ces lments en compte et dempcher lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, dont la culpabilit ne me semble pas tablie. 

Je vous prie dagrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma considration distingue.

Objet :             Floride. Excution prvue pour le 13 dcembre 

  _____  

MESSAGE :

 
Monsieur le Gouverneur, 

En tant que membre d'Amnesty International, section franaise, je souhaite vous faire part de mes proccupations concernant Angel Nieves Diaz, 55 ans, qui doit tre excut le 13 dcembre prochain. 

Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre de Joseph Nagy, le grant du bar du Salon Velvet Swing, commis le 29 dcembre 1979  Miami alors que trois hommes effectuaient un hold-up dans le bar. Laffaire est grave et pnible, puisquil sagit dun crime : justice doit tre rendue, et la famille de Joseph Nagy a droit  toute ma compassion. 

Je souhaite nanmoins vous rappeler, Monsieur le Gouverneur, que plusieurs points mritent dtre vrifis, sous peine denvoyer un innocent sur la chaise lectrique. Tout dabord, il ny avait pas de tmoin oculaire lorsque le coup de feu a t tir. Angel Toro, un autre membre du groupe du hold-up, a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit alors que certains lments indiqueraient que cest lui qui aurait tir le coup mortel. Dailleurs, quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort. Cette disparit des peines reste nanmoins trs surprenante et je mtonne que lunanimit du jury ne soit pas requise pour les condamnations  la peine capitale. 
Enfin, je tiens  souligner que le juge a lui-mme indiqu  Angel Diaz que compte tenu du fait quil ntait pas en mesure de sexprimer en anglais devant le tribunal, quil navait aucune connaissance en droit et quil avait arrt ses tudes avant la fin du secondaire, le tribunal considrait quil lui tait impossible dassurer lui-mme sa dfense. Ce que Angel Diaz a nanmoins fait. 

Je vous demande, Monsieur le Gouverneur, de bien vouloir prendre tous ces lments en compte et dempcher lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz, dont la culpabilit ne me semble pas tablie. 

Je vous en remercie par avance et vous prie dagrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma considration distingue. 

 
Jerome ROYER
