Subject: URGENT: Yvonnes Property Management


Dear Special Agent Jacquelyn Bradway,
RE: Fraud - Yvonnes Property Management: (jacquelynbradway@fdle.state.fl.us
/ 863 607 3808),
It is encouraging that you are conducting an independent investigation into
Yvonne's Property Management in terms of their criminal liability into this
era of post-ENRON white collar crime.
We, the undersigned, are working collectively to resolve this serious
matter.
We would like to support your investigation and would like you to clarify
clarification of the following points:
1 When did your investigation start and What is the scope and terms of
reference of your investigation?

2 How were complaints (to various bodies such as DACS/BBB/DBPR et al), over
a long period of time, collectively heeded before Yvonnes decided to go out
of business?

3 Have you spoken to all (existing/previous) customers of Yvonne's?

4 Have you spoken to Yvonne's staff ( Hutch/Howard Hutcheson, Will Montalvo,
Miriam Cosme, Abby Caraballo, Lonka Carlos, Sherry Pursell, Kelly Jaspan,
Patricia Lampinski, Tim Lutz, Ismael Santiago, Annett Gladden, Farancia
Martin, Eric Allen, Neil Moore, Tim Kudlock etc ?)

5 Have you interviewed and investigated their sales representative Mike
Sills regarding potential real estate fraud or other illegal activities?

6 How are you taking into account the information on www.top-forums.com ,
mike.grogan@theledger.com and the whistle blowing incident as per
http://www.theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060928/REPORTER/[REDACTED]/1068/YOURTOWN29
etc

7 How many times has Yvonne's set up business and then filed for bankruptcy
(or simply gone out of business) only to open up shop again and start
fraudulent activity again (under same or different company name)?

8 How can Yvonne's bankruptcy be explained when their literature (attached)
suggested they could sustain hurricanes AND another 911 - Do you see this as
a gross violation of trade descriptions or not explicit fraud?

9 What legislation regulates setting up of a legitimate company and did
Yvonne's comply (if yes, who validated their application and on what
grounds)?

10 Has Yvonne's actually declared bankruptcy and what are the non-civil
implications and otherwise?

11 How can we find out if they have sufficient assets before spending more
dollars on a civil action (we have already suffered once and hope you do not
make us suffer again)?

12 What has Yvonne's done with all the paperwork including personal details,
bank information, termite certificates and licences?

13 If our personal information is used as part of identity fraud or phising
what action are you able to take?

14 Why were keys left outside Yvonne's property (collected by CONTEMPO at
Contempo Plaza, 43344 Hwy. 27. Davenport, FL 33837) - do you consider this
action by Yvonnes as gross negligence beyond civil boundaries e.g. thieves
could have just walked past, collected the keys (and god forbid) broken into
ALL of our homes ?

15 Can it be explained why relatives/staff of Yvonne's stayed in client
homes without approval - is this clear evidence that Yvonne's did not have
any intention to paying owners right from the beginning?

16 Can it be explained why some homes, under Yvonne's control, were broken
into items stolen and/or damaged - do you see this as gross violation of the
human right of owners?

17 When will you be able to confirm if Yvonne's did (or did not) operate
with deception and are worthy of being charged with fraudulent business
activity leading to criminal proceedings - can you please explain how we can
be engaged in this process?

18 What happens to Yvonne's funds if they are found to be criminally liable;
e.g. do homeowners receive the money that was stolen from them?
If found guilty, what penalty can Walter and Yvonne's expect and what can be
done to stop Yvonne and Walter Bernstein from setting up another business
and operating this scam again?

19 Can a lien be put against their assets and property until this matter is
resolved and can an injection be gained to stop them escaping abroad with
our money (unless they have already put our money in accounts outside the
United States of America ?

20 Please find the attached documents used to invoke the scam including
large payments for Google listing : can you specify other evidence you are
(and are not) taking into account including the sheriffs engagement in cases
of trespassing when owners legitimately requested their money?

We would like to reinforce the fact that this inquiry has nothing to do with
the contract we (property Owners) entered into but is specifically directed
at the enticement , deception, theft and fraud (please see attachments)
which was conducted by the Bernstein's through their management company:
hopefully as a state regulator/law enforcement official you can do something
about restoring justice as soon as possible.

If nothing is done to stop this from happening again it would, in effect,
make a mockery of the law and be appear indefensible and untenable for the
State of Florida Legislature to condone.

We are aware that there is significant media interest in this matter re :
Roth/Grogan, however, we have decided not to approach the media at this
stage.

We would be grateful if you could respond by Friday 11th November 2006.

We trust you will conduct a speedy yet though investigation and keep us
informed of your actions.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: roy rossini 
Sent: Thursday, December 07, 2006 2:26 PM
Subject: RE: Rossini vs Florida

Dear Mr. Rossini:

Thank you for writing Governor Bush.  The Governor understands your concerns and asked me to respond on his behalf.  
 
Questions about the guilt or innocence or the procedural fairness of a conviction must be addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. If you need assistance in locating an attorney, contact the Florida Bar's Attorney Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.

Decisions over movement within the system, rehabilitative or educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  For further assistance, please write to Department of Corrections, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2500.

Thank you again for writing.
 
                                                                        Sincerely,
 
 
 
                                                                        Warren Davis
                                                                        Office of Citizens' Services
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: roy rossini [mailto:rerossini@msn.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 06, 2006 3:01 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Rossini vs Florida


Roy Rossini
2913 Indian River Dr, 
Cocoa, Florida 32922
 
Governor Jeb Bush 
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
I write you today as a good citizen and a person who is at his wits end regarding our system of justice.  I'm pleased to say that I have always shouldered my responsibilities and accountabilities to move forward in life - trying to live a life as a giver and not a taker.  Now turning  50, never been in trouble, never even having a traffic accident, I'm now one step from being homeless because of an encounter with a police man and exercising what everyone I've talked to was good judgment.  However, these two incidents have hurt me beyond repair and I need your help to look at this objectively because no one else can.   
 
I'll try to explain a briefly as possible. Recently I went to court to explain my actions. Although the actions were seen as doing the right thing I was convicted due to the way the law is and how instructions were given to a jury in my case. There was no room for exercising common sense.  I'm now a convicted criminal, and I and my family believe I need to appeal my case to you - as this is my only hope for a redemption of getting my life back in order. 
 
Its been a down hill road that has cost me tens of thousands of dollars, a job, job offers, disgrace, and now near bankruptcy.  My water is off, electric will soon be turned off in a few weeks, bills not being paid, mortgage near foreclosure.    
 
On July 20th  I was flying home from a short work assignment as all of my work is out of State even though all of my family lives here and here is where I live and gladly pay my taxes.  On July 20th, 2006 I flew home and had several drinks in first class over the course of several hours. Upon landing and getting my bags after midnight, I went to the parking lot to retrieve my car. I got into my car, paid the parking bill, and immediately decided that I was not going to drive home - because I had been drinking. I called a family member to pick me up at the airport and I re-parked the car at the airport. Because that is the right thing to do.  
 
An officer came up to the window of my car about a half hour later, while I was waiting, parked. The officer was called by security because I parked and stayed in the car.... It was stated that perhaps I may be a threat - why was this man staying in the car and not leaving?  
 
The DA would not bother with my case and I was advised to have a jury hear the case.  I was found guilty of a DUI.  The reason I was found guilty was because of the instructions given to the Jury from the Judge upon requesting clarification. "You the jury, must return with a guilty verdict if I could have possibly driven the car home".  He went on to say that "it did not mater if the State cannot prove I was drunk when I parked the car", "or if the software was known to be wrong", "or even the fact that I did remove the keys from the ignition while parked". "He could have driven home because Mr. Rossini knew where the keys were". Note: My lawyer brought up the fact that the software in the breathalyzer was known for its defects and the State's expert agreed. My attorney thought this was a slam dunk case. But after those instructions I knew my life was altered for the worse forever. 
 
The officer actually wound up testified in my behalf, regarding my demeanor and sound judgment not to drive home.  Again, regardless of my specific actions, the judge told the jury that I must be found guilty if I had control over the car. And if I knew were the key were, I had control. That sealed my fate. Also per the Judge instructions, he said that the State dose not have to prove that I was impaired at the time I parked the car.  The outcome:
 
I was sentence to 10 days in jail first time in my life and it was disgraceful. The judge also ordered me not to drink for 1 year (no big deal, I'm not a big drinker anyway). No liquor in my home. A 5 year suspended license and 1 year probation with 100 hours of Alternative Community Work and on and on.   The reason for the harsh sentence was because two years ago and 4 blocks away from home,   on a 15 MPH road one late night again from the airport, an officer pulled me over for no reason - the car I was driving did not look good in a upper end neighbor hood. After pulling me over he said he thought my car was part of burglary in the area. Then he asked why I was speeding, I said I do not speed. After I pointed out some facts that proved I was not a burglar or speeding, he then said I think you have been drinking. I passed his roadside test. He then wanted me to pass a breath test.  I said no unless I had a witness present or his supervisor on the scene. I simply did not trust him after this time. His answer to me was that I did not have that option as far a witness, as Florida is a consent State,  and none of this incident had to be being video taped.  My word against his and too bad for me everyone told me. 
 
I received an automatic DUI for this first offence. The reason that this is important here is because it set me up for the second offence and a harsh life changing punishment that follows. And the scary part is I'm being set up for failure and will soon be in violation of probation and could serve years in Jail. The nightmare won't let up.  I can't get out of this hole. 
 
Like I said, I'm now on 1 year probation. I being asked to take a Greyhound bus 2 times a month to Orlando from Cocoa to meet with my probation officer - I really don't even have bus money. I told the probation officer that I needed to be working and I work out of State and  even the Judge understood and allowed me  to attend AA anywhere in the country, had no objections to transferring the case or even having me write in to my probation officer each month.  I could manage this even though it limited my ability to rent a car to work over the next 5 years.
 
But the kicker came when the probation officer said that she will not allow any of the Judges conditions because the Judge used words like no objection to the transfer and may use AA time for community service. In fact the probation officer is demanding that I see her twice a month and its my problem if I violate probation.  I'm now being set up for failure and may become a violator of probation because I cannot meet the new demands. 
 
Dear Governor, my life has come intolerable and I have no one else to turn too and I know writing you is a long shot. But I've got to help myself by asking you to look into this mess for me.  Like I said in the beginning, I've never asked for favors or never complained about anything. But I've got nothing left. I'm crying out for help. 
 
By the way I tried to go through the appeal process under public assistance but that is another three page letter I'm sorry to say. 
 
I hope you read this note. 
 
Sincerely,
Roy Rossini
2913 Indian River Drive
Cocoa Florida, 32922
321 504 0674

of my letter. I can not afford to file the documents needed to proceed
with my case. I can not take the time off from work to go to food

phone; however no one ever called me back and they had my cell phone so
I know I did not miss the call. None the less they declined my
application. As for "legal aid" the girl I talked to told me they do not

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Thursday, December 07, 2006 2:24 PM
To: Richter, Elise
Subject: RE: Urgent Request-Need Assistance With Child Custody/Support

Dear Ms. Richter:

Thank you for your recent e-mail to Governor Bush requesting assistance
with a child custody matter.  He has asked me to respond.
 
Custody and visitation rulings are under the jurisdiction of the
judicial system.  Under Florida law, the court's decision in these cases
is based on the best interest of the child or children involved.  Judges
review all of the information presented to them and apply the law to
make their decision.
 
The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters
that should be resolved through the court system.  If you are unhappy
with a ruling or feel a case has not been handled according to the law,
you should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be
available.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services
or the county legal aid association has information about the
availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number of Florida
Legal Services is (850) 385-7900.  Those dissatisfied with their
representatives should consider choosing another attorney.
 
In the meantime, if you have not already done so, you may wish to
contact your branch office for the Florida Department of Children and
Families.  This agency provides economic self-sufficiency services,
temporary cash assistance, Medicaid, food stamps and temporary
assistance for needy families.  That address and telephone number can be
located in your telephone directory.
 
Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the
problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.
Please know this is due to lack of jurisdiction, not lack of concern.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
 
Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services 
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Richter, Elise [mailto:ERichter@newspapersfirst.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 06, 2006 1:54 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: blue_byu@juno.com
Subject: Urgent Request-Need Assistance With Child Custody/Support


My name is Elise Ann Richter, I have been a resident of South Florida
since 1979 (I was 7). I recently ran into to a legal issue with my
ex-husband (Rodolfo A. Richter). He moved to N. Carolina with both of
our minor children; however the youngest (14) was not getting along with
him so he decided he was going to send her to live with me in Florida.
She has been here for about a month and a half. He is still collecting
child support for her from me and I can't afford a Lawyer to represent
us in court to gain custody & child support. When I call "Legal Aid"
they say I have to qualify in order for them to help me and they do not
know how long it will be before they can assist me if I do qualify. I
tried to apply for Food Stamps-however I work everyday and cannot get to
an appointment without losing a days pay. I can't help but think I have
never been so frustrated with the system in S. Florida as much as I am
with this situation. I have to pay $50.00 to file a motion for Child
Support & Custody. I also have to pay $85.00 for him to be served in N.
Carolina with the papers I file if I could afford to file them. Here is
the thing if a had beat, robbed, raped, murdered, or any other crime you
can think of I would get a Lawyer for free, however since I am not a
criminal my daughter & I must suffer. Not to mention if I quit my job I
would be able to get all they help I could ever need that seems very

> [Original Message]
> From: Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
> To: <hekeepsus7@earthlink.net>
> Date: 12/5/2006 9:16:54 AM
> Subject: RE: Personal Concern, IMPORTANT!!!
>
> Dear Ms. Lee:
>
> Thank you for writing Governor Bush.  The Governor understands the pain a
prisoner's family and friends endure and asked me to respond on his behalf.

>
> The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in criminal
court cases.  Each state attorney is an elected official charged with
certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to
prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction. 
This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt
shown, and in the best interest of justice.
>
> Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to
commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be
addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should
speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. If
you need assistance in locating an attorney, contact the Florida Bar's
Attorney Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.
>
> Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or
educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time
are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  For further
assistance, please write to Department of Corrections, 2601 Blair Stone
Road, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2500.
>  
> The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's
control, determines the issues of control release and early release.  The
Commission's address is Building C, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee,
Florida  32399-2450.
>  
> The Governor has no independent ability to pardon someone. The clemency
function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's
civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these
lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with
the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected
officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to
await the outcome of court appeals.  For more information, you can write
the Office of Executive Clemency at Building C, Room 229, 2601 Blair Stone
Road, Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450.
>  
> Thank you again for writing.  The Governor appreciates your kind words
and prayers.  The Governor also appreciates your best wishes for his family
during the holiday season and hopes this information is helpful to your
family.
>  
>                                                                        
Sincerely,
>  
>  
>  
>                                                                        
Warren Davis
>                                                                        
Office of Citizens' Services
>  
>

From:	Adrian Bellesguard <adrianbellesguard@mac.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 5, 2006 8:52 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Respect Justice: Stop Execution of A. Diaz

December 5, 2006
The Honorable Jeb Ellis Bush
Governor of the State of Florida
PL 05 The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


Dear Governor Bush,

I appeal to you to do everything in your power to stop the execution of Puerto
Rican national Angel Nieves Diaz.  Mr. Diaz is scheduled to be executed on December
13, 2006, for the 1979 death of Joseph Nagy.

Post-conviction assessments by two mental health experts concluded that Angel
Diaz suffers from certain mental disorders, which contributed to his decision
to represent himself and undermined his ability to do so competently. The presiding
trial judge allowed Mr. Diaz to represent himself even though Mr. Diaz spoke minimal
English, had no knowledge about the law, and had not even completed high school.
Many mentally ill defendants have insisted on representing themselves despite
widespread evidence of their incompetence to do so.

Moreover, during the sentencing phase of this trial, acute disparities in sentencing
became apparent. Despite conflicting evidence about the actual gunman and the
use of unreliable testimony by a jailhouse informant, one defendant received a
life sentence while Mr. Diaz was condemned to death.  Furthermore, evidence was
not raised at the trial about Mr. Diaz's childhood abuse, history of mental problems,
and issues associated with longtime drug addition.  

I am also concerned to learn that a key prosecution witness at the 1985 trial
has recanted his testimony, which had been a key part of the evidence that convicted
Mr. Diaz of murder.

It is deeply unsettling that this execution would proceed while Florida's capital
justice system remains mired in geographic and racial disparities. Florida is
also the only state in the country that does not require a jury to be unanimous
in recommending the death penalty.  In this case, it should be noted that four
of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty.

I have tremendous sympathy for the family and friends of Joseph Nagy, but I
believe capital punishment only perpetuates the cycle of violence. 

Governor Bush, I strongly urge you to demonstrate your respect for justice and
human life by doing everything in your power to stop the execution of Angel Nieves
Diaz.  

Thank you for your time and attention to this serious matter.

Sincerely,

Adrian Bellesguard
15110 Ports Of Iona Dr
Fort Myers, FL 33908-1890

            Angel Nieves Diaz doit tre excut en Floride le 13 dcembre 2006. Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre du grant de bar Joseph Nagy, commis en 1979  Miami lors dun vol  main arme. 

            Suite  ma lettre du 28 novembre, je renouvelle ici, Monsieur le Gouverneur, ma compassion pour la famille de Joseph Nagy, qui a t tu en 1979, et je ne cherche pas  minimiser la gravit de ce crime ni les souffrances quil a engendres.

            Enfin je vous exhorte, Monsieur le Gouverneur,  empcher cette excution.

            Je formule ma demande dans le seul souci de respecter et de faire respecter les Droits de la Personne Humaine et sur recommandation dAmnesty International qui est une organisation apolitique et non confessionnelle.

            Dans lattente dune rponse favorable  ma requte, je vous prie de bien vouloir agrer, Monsieur le Gouverneur, lexpression de ma respectueuse considration.

From:	Nicole GRAAS <nq@mims.be>
Sent:	Monday, December 4, 2006 4:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	death penalty : Angel Nieves Diaz, aged 55

Importance:	High

To Governor Jeb Bush, The Capitol, 400 South Monroe Street, Tallahassee, FL 32399, USA
Fax : +1 850 487 0801

 

Dear Governor,

Concern : death penalty : Angel Nieves Diaz, aged 55

As a member of Amnesty International, witch is, as you know an impartial organisation with purely humanitarian aims, I am expressing my sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was killed in 1979, I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused.

But I am opposed to the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, who wasnt competent to stand the trial and especially to represent himself.

There was a disparity in sentencing in this case, one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite the fact that there was no evidence about who was the gunman.

I am expressing concern at the use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel Diaz, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony

Four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty.

I am calling on the Governor to intervene to stop this execution.

Daring to hope that the dead sentence will be commuted in life sentence, I am sending my best salutations.

 

 

Nicole Quirynen-Graas





nq@mims.be
tl. : +32 84 468671
fax. : +32 84 468672

tl. Mobil : +32 473 902 600

 

From:	U. Plebs <u.plebs@t-online.de>
Sent:	Monday, December 4, 2006 3:51 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Appeal
Attachments:	ua 06 317 USA.doc

Dr. Wolfgang Cornely                                                                                  Dec. 4th, 2006

Lohstr. 30

45966 Gladbeck, Germany

 

 

 

 

 

Governor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399, USA
Email: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

 

 

 

 

 

 

Dear Governor,

 

As I have been informed by amnesty international, Angel Nieves Diaz is to be executed on Dec. 13th for having murdered bar manager Joseph Nagy in 1979.

 

I deeply feel for the family of victim Joseph Nagy and for all the people who were close to him and I do not want to underestimate the seriousness of such a crime.

 

However, there are a lot of doubts, if the death sentence stands its ground against all the objections that can be made:

*	Obviously Angel Diaz was not capable to defend himself properly according to the justified standards in a capital punishment case, in spite of his own claims to do so.
*	There are two defendants suspicious of having killed Joseph Nagy, Angel Nieves Diaz and Angel Toro, the latter being sentenced to a life sentence.
*	The key prosecution witness Ralph Gajus has now recanted his testimony, calling into further doubt the reliability of the jurys verdict. 
*	The sentence was not given unanimously by the jury; four out of twelve voted against the death sentence. With the recanted testimony, the majority jurors sure would have voted against the death sentence.
*	Recent research has found problems with Floridas capital justice system

 

 

That is why, Mr. Governor, I call on you to intervene to stop this execution.

 

Respectfully

 

 

 

Dr. Wolfgang Cornely

Subject:	 1 of 5   Ofc. Dumorange and his Family need your help and Prayers!!! 1 of 5

		
	  	
From:	Namar Mar <namar_12@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Sunday, December 3, 2006 8:38 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	embeuamx@state.gov
Subject:	death penalty-Angel Nievez Daz

Governor Jeb Bush
Dear governor:

Due to my humanitarian vocation and my interest in the elimination of death penalty and knowing that you are inclined to accept commentaries and suggestions, I hereby request  that the death penalty of  Angel Daz, with your help, be reconsidered.  Crime always causes a lot of suffering and I sincerely regret the harm done to Mr. Joseph Nagy's family as well as all that Mr. Diaz has had to face. 


 I consider that there are some elements which could lead to consider this death penalty  as a case with reasonable doubt as is the doubt of who really shot Mr. Nagy due to the contradictory testimonies and the fact that a very decisive witness, Ralph Gajus, who had swore that Angel Diaz had confessed to be the person who shot Mr. Nagy,  has now retracted himself from his previous testimony and this testimony was the base of the death sentence to Mr. A. Diaz.  Mr. Gajus has now confessed that the reason of his statement against Angel Diaz was to attract a favour from the district attorney to help him in his case.


 Another reason is that there seems to be enough evidence about his mental health as he decided to represent himself in his trial in spite of his ignorance of the laws of the U.S.A. as well as of the English language.


On the other hand, the difference between sentencing someone to death and his accomplice to life imprisonment is quite noticeable.


 Another fact to take in consideration regarding the death penalty  in Florida is the recent  investigation carried out by the American lawyers college,  which detected serious problems in the  capital penalty; among these are the geographic and racial differences as well as the fact that unanimity is not required in the jury to impose the death penalty as well as the little attention given to mental disability.  Anyway, four members of the jury did not vote for the death penalty on this specific case. 

 

           Due to the above-mentioned reasons Id like to ask for your intervention in the case of Mr. Angel Nieves Daz which is programmed to take place on 13th December of this year.  I honestly hope you could take these reasons in consideration to reevaluate Mr. Angel Diaz case.



 Thank you very much for your attention.


 


                                                          Urgent Action team,


                                                                   Namar

From:	pdiazsantiago@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, December 2, 2006 9:17 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	abogados@prtc.net
Subject:	Angel Nieves/Pena de Muerte

Dear Jeff:
 
Probably you remember me from the activity at the Banker's Club in Puerto Rico in 2002 where we had a great chating.  I was one of the sponsors together with Jerry Pierce Santos. My Wife and I had a great experience talking to you and were amazed by your great domain of Spanish Language and the fact that your wife was Latin American (Mexican).
 
They called me from a newspaper after the activity asking why I donated $10,000.00 then, if I had no interest or business in Florida and I said:  "I believe someone like him is an excellent candidate to represent Latinos in the U.S.," said Peter Diaz Santiago, 33, a Puerto Rico-based attorney who gave $10,000 to the state Republican Party."  October 14, 2002  South Florida Sun-Sentinel.
 
Now I have something to ask you.  Please do not take this wrong, it doesn't mean I am asking for a favor back but anyway, if I have to do it, I will never find a better occassion. 
 
A man will be executed in Christmass time. His name is Angel Nieves.  He claims he is innocent. I do not really know what he did it or not, but I don't think that should be the consideration.
 
Respectfully, the consideration should be that taking his life will show that we are willing to kill too.  You and only you have the Power to stop this execution.
 
Recently, I heard some people talking about the possibility of Latino discrimination and I was amazed because these people don't know that in fact, your Children are Latinos.  So I know for sure that you do not discriminate against us, but probably in the trial process there was discrimination.  My request goes directly to you and the sensibility you possess as a great leader.
 
Stop this execution!  This will be a great Christmass gift for us at the Puerto Rico Bar Association.
 
Thank you, and please say hello to your wife from me and my wife Noemi Rivera.
 
Peter Daz Santiago, Esq.
1612 Ponce de Len Avenue
Ninth Floor
San Juan, PR 00909
Phone: (787) 725-7918
Fax: (787) 725-7847

From:	Jeanine <jeanine.gregoire@skynet.be>

Importance:	High

 

                                                                                      



                                        Governor Jeb Bush

                                                                                         FL 32399                                  Etats-Unis

 

Monsieur le Gouverneur,





Angel Nieves Diaz doit tre excut en Floride le 13 dcembre 2006. Il a t condamn  mort en 1986 pour le meurtre du grant de bar Joseph Nagy, commis en 1979  Miami lors dun vol  main arme. 


Je voudrais vous exprimer toute la  compassion que je ressens pour la famille de Joseph Nagy et vous faire savoir que je ne cherche pas  minimiser la gravit de ce crime ni les souffrances quil a engendres .


Cependant, je m'oppose  lexcution dAngel Nieves Diaz en prenant acte des lments qui remettent en question son aptitude  tre jug et  assurer lui-mme sa dfense . Des examens mdicaux ont en effet prouv qu'Angel Diaz n'avait pas toute les aptitudes  ncessaires  pour assurer lui-mme  sa dfense.


Je tiens  faire tat de la disparit des peines infliges dans cette affaire, o un accus a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit et lautre  la peine de mort malgr la prsence de preuves contradictoires quant  qui a tir le coup mortel, et  vous  exprimer ma proccupation quant  lutilisation contre Angel Diaz du tmoignage dun codtenu, type de dposition bien connu pour son manque de fiabilit .

 
J'aimerais qu'il soit tenu compte du fait que quatre des jurs nont pas vot en faveur de la condamnation  mort.

Une tude rcente a mis au jour de graves problmes en ce qui concerne le systme dapplication de la peine capitale en Floride tels que les disparits raciales et gographiques dans lapplication de ce chtiment et le fait que lunanimit du jury nest pas requise pour la dtermination de la peine . 

 
C'est pourquoi je vous demande instamment, Monsieur le gouverneur d' empcher cette excution.
 
Veuillez croire, Monsieur le Gouverneur,  ma haute considration.
 
 
Jeanine Grgoire

From:	yuna carvajal perez <yuna_cp@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Saturday, December 2, 2006 2:32 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	amemb@embusa.es
Subject:	Nuevas pruebas en contra de la ejecucin de ngel N. Daz

Seor Gobernador de Florida Jeb Bush.

No s si le llegara, pues no he recibido contestacin ni acuse de recibo, pero el da 27 de noviembre le envi un e-mail comentndole mi gran preocupacin sobre la situacin de ngel Nieves Daz, condenado a la pena de muerte cuya ejecucin est prevista para el prximo da 13 de diciembre.

Como le comentaba en mi e-mail, no quiero restar importancia a la gravedad del crimen que se cometi contra la vida de Joseph Nagy y comparto plnamente el sufrimiento que ese hecho ha causado a la familia de la vctima. Pero, como usted puede comprobar, las circunstancias en las que se llev a cabo el juicio de ngel Daz as como las pruebas que llevaron al jurado a tomar la decisin de condenarlo a la pena capital, son de dudosa fiabilidad.  

Conociendo todas las circunstancias, no puedo sino reiterarle mi tajante oposicin a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz. 

 

Aparte de todas las seales que indican que ngel N. Daz no tena capacidad para llevar a cabo su propia defensa (problemas mentales diagnosticados posteriormente, barreras culturales y lingsticas y un nulo conocimiento del sistema judicial) le recuerdo la disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua (ngel Toro) y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos.

Por otro lado, y ms grave an si cabe, es el hecho de que parece ser que la condena de culpabilidad de ngel Daz se decidi fundamentalmente por el testimonio de Ralph Gajus (informador bajo custodia).

Ralph Gajus ha realizado ahora una declaracin jurada en la que manifiesta que su testimonio en el juicio fue falso, que ngel Daz nunca le dijo que fuera el autor de los disparos y que no saba por sus comunicaciones con Daz quin haba disparado a Joseph Nagy. Afirma que su testimonio en el juicio fue motivado por la furia contra ngel Daz y por un deseo de obtener el favor de la fiscala en su propio caso de asesinato. En el juicio, Ralph Gajus haba declarado que no le haban prometido nada a cambio de su testimonio. Sin embargo, en la vista de determinacin de la pena de su caso un polica haba testificado sobre la ayuda que Gajus haba prestado a la fiscala en el caso de Daz.

 

Durante las deliberaciones del jurado en el juicio de ngel Daz, los miembros del jurado pidieron copias del testimonio de Ralph Gajus, pero el juez se neg a proporcionrselas, y dio instrucciones de que el jurado se basara en su recuerdo de lo que el testigo haba dicho. El jurado emiti un veredicto de culpabilidad. La retractacin de Ralph Gajus pone an ms en duda la fiabilidad de este veredicto.

 

Aunque el jurado recomend la pena de muerte para ngel Daz, lo hizo por nicamente ocho votos contra cuatro, lo que indica una posible duda residual en la mente de los miembros del jurado incluso con el testimonio de Ralph Gajus. Sin l, es posible que ms miembros del jurado hubieran votado contra la pena de muerte.

 

La Comisin de California sobre la Administracin Imparcial de Justicia ha emitido recientemente su recomendacin sobre el uso de testimonios de informadores. La Comisin, establecida por el Senado de California para examinar las causas de las condenas errneas y formular recomendaciones para garantizar una administracin imparcial y fiable de la justicia penal en el estado, ha recomendado que la Cmara de Representantes adopte una ley que prohba el uso en juicios penales de testimonios de informadores bajo custodia si no existen pruebas o testimonios independientes que los corroboren.

 

Un estudio realizado recientemente bajo los auspicios del Proyecto de Aplicacin de la Suspensin de la Pena de Muerte, del Colegio Estadounidense de Abogados, identific serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos el elevado ndice de personas excarceladas del corredor de la muerte tras demostrarse su inocencia (22 desde 1973: ms que en Illinois, donde dio lugar a una suspensin de las ejecuciones), la existencia continuada de disparidades raciales y geogrficas, el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena y el hecho de que no se da peso suficiente a los efectos atenuantes de la discapacidad mental grave.

 

Como le comentaba en mi e-mail, tengo un gran cario a su pas. Mi padre, mi madrastra y dos de mis hermanos son americanos. 

No prentendo entrar ahora en un debate sobre la aplicacin de la pena capital o no, no tengo ningn inters poltico ni de otro tipo... Mi nico inters es intentar, dentro de mis limitadas posibilidades, ayudarle a comprender la vital importancia de detener una ejecucin que, por todos los indcios, puede llevar a sesgar la vida de una persona que podra ser inocente.

Desgraciadamente, ha habido demasiados errores ya en la aplicacin de la Pena de Muerte. Errores que tarde o temprano siempre se acaban descubriendo y que, a la vista de sus compatriotas y de la mirada internacional, dan una imagen lamentable del sistema judicial americano. Y lo que es peor... ante condenas de este tipo es imposible devolver la vida al ejecutado y "pedirle perdn".

Es preciso detener la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz. 

Confo en el sistema judicial de su pas y en que usted no ser capz de permitir que pueda cometerse una injusticia de este tipo, con tantas pruebas que ponen en duda la sentencia.

Un cordial saludo.

Yuna Carvajal Prez

Estudiante de Master en Comunicacin de Empresa y Publicidad

Zaragoza (Spain)

 

Yuna 

  _____  

Excursiones y escapadas a sitios mgicos. No te lo pierdas en MSN Entretenimiento 
From:	lukashermann@arcor.de
Sent:	Saturday, December 2, 2006 8:39 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Governor

Angel Nieves Diaz is scheduled for execution in Florida on 13 December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. First of all I want to express my sympathy for the family of Joseph Nay, who was killed in 1979, and want to explain, that I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused. Nevertheless I am opposing the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz. Also I want to note that there are evidence calling into question his competency to stand trial and represent himself. Furthermore I want to note that the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman and I want to express concern at the use of jailhouse information testimony against Angel Nieves Diaz, a notoriously unreliable from testimony. Also I want to mention that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions. I am calling on You to intervene to stop this execution.

Yours Sincerely
Hermann Lukas

From:	Paul Forster <pforster@uottawa.ca>
Sent:	Saturday, December 2, 2006 7:21 AM
To:	Paul Forster; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Execution of Angel Diaz

  _____  

From: Paul Forster
Sent: Fri 12/1/2006 3:42 PM
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Subject: Angel Diaz


Dear Governor Bush:
 
I wrote you a week or so ago to express concern about the case of Angel Diaz who is scheduled to be excecuted on December 13th, 2006 for the murder of Joseph Nagy back in 1979.   Since I wrote you I have learned from Amnesty International that the jailhouse informant used to incriminate Mr Diaz has recanted his testimony.  Since this testimony was crucial in contradicting the testimony of Mr Diaz's girlfriend and two people present when the shooting took place-- all of whom testified that Mr Diaz was not the gunman-- there are even more grounds for reviewing his case and suspending his death sentence.  
 
In addition to this, I remain concerned that evidence of Mr Diaz's competency to stand trial and to represent himself was not available to be considered at his trial.  Also, the prisoner who seems in fact to have been the gunman has been given only a life sentence, while Mr Diaz has been sentenced to death and this seems hardly equitable.  Moreover, even with the perjured testimony of a prison informant, 4 jurors refused to give Mr Diaz a death sentence, suggesting that the case was far from clear-cut.  Finally, there is concern that race played a role in securing the conviction. 
 
I want to reiterate what I said in my earlier letter.  I lost my own nephew at the age of 18 and no something of the pain of  the senseless death of a family member.  I have nothing but empathy for the suffering of Joseph Nagy's family and friends.  They are entitled to see justice done and there is no excusing his shooting.  My concern is that in executing Mr Diaz justice will not be served.  And so I implore you, once again, to please intervene and suspend the execution of Mr Diaz.
 
Thank you for considering my views.  I would appreciate any response you may care to share with me.
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
Prof. Paul Forster
Department of Philosophy
University of Ottawa

  _____  

From: Paul Forster
Sent: Fri 11/24/2006 3:13 PM
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Subject: Execution of Angel Diaz


 

Governor Jeb Bush, The Capitol, 

400 South Monroe Street, 

Tallahassee, FL 32399, USA

Email:   jeb.bush@myflorida.com

 

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I am a professor of philosophy at the University of Ottawa in Ottawa, Canada.  I have a strong interest in human rights issues in Canada and around the world and an active member of Amnesty International which, as you no doubt know, is a non-partisan human rights agency.  

 

I am writing to express concern about the case of Angel Nieves Diaz who is scheduled for execution on December 13, 2006 having been convicted in 1986 of murdering Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.  Having suffered through the death of a nephew, I have the utmost empathy for Mr Nagys family and friends.  Theirs is the sort of suffering that does not end and they are, of course, entitled to see justice done.  However, the information I have received makes me very worried that justice has not been served in the case of Mr Diaz.

 

In the first place, there is a substantial body of evidence to suggest he was not competent to stand trial and should not have been allowed to represent himself including the testimony of the lawyer charged to defend him and mental health assessments conducted after his trial. This evidence seems to have been disregarded to date. 

 

Second, the other accused person in this case, Mr. Angel Toro, pled guilty to the crime in exchange for a life sentence.  It is hard to justify a more severe sentence for Mr Diaz when there are no eye-witnesses to the shooting of Mr Nagy and conflicting evidence as to who fired the fatal shot.   (Two people in the bar testified that it was Mr. Toro, not Mr Diaz, who shot Joseph Nagy.)

 

Third, the evidence against Mr Diaz included testimony by inmates.  Study after study has shown such testimony to be unreliable.

 

Fourth, the American Bar Association has noted significant racial disparities in sentences in Florida courts.  (Mr Diaz is Puerto Rican and was forced to wear shackles throughout the trial, despite research findings suggesting this is prejudicial.)  The same report cites the failure in Florida courts to give due consideration to mental disabilities as mitigating factors in crime.  (Mr. Diaz is a victim of child abuse and has a record of mental problems.)  

 

Finally, notwithstanding all of the above, four jurors were against the sentence of death in this case.  I might add, as you know, the American Bar Association has also expressed concern that unanimity among jurors is not required in death penalty cases in Florida.

 

I have a different view of the death penalty than you do but this is not the issue I am raising here.  The issue here is whether the trial and sentencing of Mr Diaz meets the standards of justice the United States holds itself to and of which it is rightly proud.  It seems to me there is ample evidence this is not the case.  In light of this, I implore you to intervene and stop the execution of Mr Diaz on December 13th, 2006.

 

I would appreciate any further information you may have about this case.  Thank you for considering my concerns.

 

Sincerely,

 

Prof. Paul D. Forster

Department of Philosophy

University of Ottawa.

Ottawa, ON, CANADA

K1N 6N5 

From:	Elisabeth Petitjean <elisabeth-petitjean@wanadoo.fr>
Sent:	Friday, December 1, 2006 4:36 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Death Penalty - Angel Nieves Diaz

Governor Jeb Bush

The Capitol

400 South Monroe Street

Tallahassee

Florida 32399

United States

 

 

Dear Governor, 

 

I am writing to you in the name of Amnesty International, France. Through this organization, I have learned of the imminent execution, scheduled for December 13, 2006, of  Angel Nieves Diaz for the 1979 murder of  Joseph Nagy in Miami.

 

First I want to express my sympathy for the family and friends of Joseph Nagy and in no way do I seek to condone the crime that led to this tragic death or to minimize the suffering caused. However, I am opposed to the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz. 

 

Two mental experts concluded that Angel Diaz suffers from certain mental disorders which contributed to his decision to represent himself and undermined his ability to do so competently. I do not believe he adequately understood the legal system and the conduct of the trial due to cultural differences and language barriers, among other reasons.

 

In this case there is a disparity in sentencing the case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman, and I am therefore expressing concern at the use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel Dial, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony. Besides 4 of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty. 

 

I also want to draw your attention to the fact that recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

 

I therefore appeal to you Governor Bush to stop the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz.  Moreover I urge you to lend your full support for a moratorium of executions in the state of  Florida.

 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this grave matter

 

Sincerely

 

Elisabeth Petitjean

29 rue d'Angleterre

06000 Nice

France

Me dirijo a usted respecto al tema de la condena de ngen Nieves Daz puesto 
que me llena de gran perocupacin. Conocido es el inters de su pas y la

el motivo de mi escrito.

diciembre de 2006, los cuales me han conmocionado profundamente y lamento y 
condeno el fallecimiento de Joseph Nagy y envo todo mi apoyo a la familia

Toro era el autor material de disparo, pero se le cambi la pena capital por

hombre, espero tengan en cuenta la solicitud y actuen de una manera 
clemente.

Sr. Gobernador:

Me dirijo nuevamente a usted alarmado por la ejecucin de ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, prevista en su estado para el prximo da 13 de diciembre, despus de que Ralph Gajus, testigo de cargo fundamental en el juicio, se ha retractado de su testimonio contra ngel Daz.

Ralph Gajus ha realizado ahora una declaracin jurada en la que manifiesta que su testimonio en el juicio fue falso, que ngel Daz nunca le dijo que fuera el autor de los disparos y que no saba por sus comunicaciones con Daz quin haba disparado a Joseph Nagy. Afirma que su testimonio en el juicio fue motivado por la furia contra ngel Daz y por un deseo de obtener el favor de la fiscala en su propio caso de asesinato. Cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte, y sin el testimonio de Ralph Gajus, es posible que ms miembros del jurado hubieran votado contra la condena de muerte. La ex novia de ngel Daz y otras dos personas, que estaban en el bar en el momento del robo, indicaron que ngel Daz no haba sido el autor de los disparos. Incluso, en un memorndum, el fiscal escribi: " El acusado Toro dispar contra Nagy una vez en el pecho, causndole la muerte".


La investigacin llevada a cabo por la Northwestern University de Illinois ha demostrado que los testimonios prestados por personas que se encuentran bajo custodia o se enfrentan a procesamientos penales son frecuentemente poco fiables.
Me preocupa tambin la reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el elevado ndice de personas excarceladas del "corredor de la muerte" tras demostrarse su inocencia, 22 desde 1973. Penselo bien por que en este caso no habra marcha atrs y la reputacin de Florida se perjudicara a nivel internacional.

Le insto a que intervenga urgentemente para detener esta ejecucin. Le pido que conmute la pena de muerte a Angel Diaz Nieves por un castigo mas humano.
Si luego se demuestra su inocencia la vergenza ser grande y tendr que vivir con el remordimiento.
 
En espera de respuesta me despido atentamente.
 
 
 
 
 
                                                       Francisco Javier Martin Villarreal

Governor Jeb Bush

Dear Governor

Thank you for to pay attention to my letter. I write this letter to him to
express my preoccupation. Angel Nieves Diaz is scheduled for execution in
Florida on 13 December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the
murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.

I want to make notice my solidarity with Joseph Nagy and family; I try
neither excuse the crime that cost your life nor to minimize the sufferings
caused to his familiy.

But I am set against the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz. I believe that the
single human life is of God. In addition it is necessary to consider the
tragic history of the defendant and his mental problems. The development of
the process demonstrates its incapacity to be judged and to defend itself to
itself.

A key prosecution witness at the 1985 trial of Angel Nieves Diaz has
recanted his testimony, which had been a key part of the evidence that
convicted Diaz of murder. On 27 November, lawyers for Angel Diaz filed a new
motion in court on the basis of this new evidence

A defendant has received a sentence of life imprisonment and other one a
penalty of death, in spite of the contradictory testimonies of the one who
was the author of the shots; in addition, against ngel Daz has considered
the testimony of a jailed informer, a slightly trustworthy testimony. Four
of the members of the jury did not vote in favour of the capital punishment.

I go to you, dear governor, to supplicate him that it takes part to stop
this execution.
Please, dear Governor, stop this execution and you grant I pardon to Angel
Nieves Diaz.
Please, in the name of God, compassion and pity.
Please, please, thank you, please.

Sincerely,

Federico Barber
Valencia, Spain

Dear Governor 

We are writing as members of Amnesty International to express sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was 
killed in 1979. 

Although not in any way seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused
we do oppose the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz. 

We note:


*	 the evidence which calls into question his competency to stand trial and represent himself;
*	the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite there being conflicting evidence about who was the gunman;  
*	that Ralph Gajus, a key prosecution witness at the trial, has now recanted his testimony against Angel Diaz.
*	We also call into further doubt the reliability of the jury's verdict; in particular  the fact hat four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty, indicating a possible residual doubt in their minds about the defendant's guilt, and suggest that without the testimony of Ralph Gajus more of the jurors might have voted against a death sentence;


W also draw your attention to the  recent research has found serious problems with Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions. 

We therefore call on you, as Governor, to intervene to stop this execution. 

Yours sincerley

Mr A and Mrs M Baird.
Stockport.
UK


cc.
His Excellency Mr Robert Holmes Tuttle, 
Embassy of the United States, 
24 Grosvenor Square,  London
http://www.usembassy.org.uk

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: November 29, 2006 3:15 PM
To: Patty Katterhenry
Subject: RE: Cory Katterhenry


Dear Mr. Katterhenry:

Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush.  He asked me to respond.

As you may know, the decision to charge a person for crimes is made by the
state attorney, a locally elected official.  Deciding whether or not to
charge a person is based on the best interests of justice and on the
quantity and quality of the evidence of criminal activity.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that
should be resolved through the court system.  If you believe a person is
innocent, or not guilty of all charges, you may wish to obtain the services
of an attorney experienced in criminal defense. If you need assistance in
locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at
1-800-342-8011.  

Those who are facing criminal charges for which prison time is a
possibility, may be appointed an attorney by the court.  For further
assistance in this regard, please contact the office of your locally elected
public defender.  Please be sure the attorney is provided with all of the
evidence you believe shows innocence.

The Governor trusts justice will be served in this case.

						Sincerely,



						Warren Davis
						Office of Citizens' Services

From:	STEVE OGILVIE <sogilvie@msn.com>
Sent:	Thursday, November 30, 2006 11:15 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Death penalty / Legal concern Angel Nieves Diaz

Importance:	High

Governor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee FL 32399
Email: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

Dear Governor,

I am writing to you as a member of Amnesty International.

I sympathize for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was killed in 1979, and I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused;

I oppose the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, please note evidence calling into question his competency to stand trial and represent himself;

Please note the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman;

Please note that Ralph Gajus, a key prosecution witness at the trial, has now recanted his testimony against Angel Diaz, calling into further doubt the reliability of the jury's verdict;

Please note that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty, indicating a possible residual doubt in their minds about the defendant's guilt, and suggesting that without the testimony of Ralph Gajus more of the jurors might have voted against a death sentence;

Please note that recent research has found serious problems with Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions;

I ask you Governor to intervene to stop this execution.

Thank you for your time in this urgent matter.

Warm Regards,

Steve Ogilvie

7165 Gallagher Road
North Gower, Ontario

Dear Governor,

I 

am a Computer Scientist born in Spain, educated in Great Britain and resident for the last 7 years in Greece. Human rights is one of my greatest concerns and that is why I have been given details by International Amnesty about the ANGEL DIAZ case. 

First of all, I need

to express my condolences and support to Joseph Nagy's family, murdered in 1979. Without resting importance to the terrible crime committed and to all of the suffering caused by it I feel the execution of Angel Diaz is against Human Rights and call for the sentence to be commuted. 

The main reason for this request is the unfair trial he went through, without a proper defence lawyer and being obvious that he was not capable to represent himself .

The actual killer of Joseph Nagy, who did have a proper representation, had a less severe sentence while Angel Diaz received the maximum sentence. It does look like he is being made guilty based on the single testimony of the informer in prison. This testimony is by all means not reliable. 

Moreover, four members of the jury did not consider ANGEL DIAZ guilty of murdering Joseph Nagy but still the decision of making him pay for this crime was made. How many innocent people are to be executed until Florida changes its system to a unanimous vote from the jury.

I am asking your Excellency to have a more progressed and civilized Florida. Please, stop ANGEL DIAZ's execution. The eyes of people who care about Human Rights all over the world are today on you.

Dear Governor

Ich wende mich an Sie in der Angelegenheit von Angel Nieves Diaz.
Amnesty international hat mich informiert, dass beabsichtigt ist, diesen Mann am 13. Dezember hinrichten zu lassen.

Ich versichere Ihnen, dass ich die Trauer und das Leid der Angehoerigen und Freunde von  Joseph Nagy nachempfinden und verstehen kann. Ich will die schreckliche Tat in keiner Weise entschuldigen oder herunterspielen.

Ich wende mich aber  wie Amnesty international - entschieden gegen die Todesstrafe.
 
Im Fall von Angel Nieves Diaz wurde erwiesenermassen in Frage gestellt, ob er die Kompetenz habe, die Gerichtsverhandlung durchzustehen und sich selbst zu verteidigen.
Es ist mir unverstaendlich, warum in diesem Fall der eine Angeklagte zu lebenslanger Haft und der andere zum Tode verurteilt wurde, obschon die Zeugen sich widersprechen, wer der Schuetze gewesen ist.

Ich moechte Sie nochmals darauf aufmerksam machen, dass Ralph Gajus, ein Hauptbelastungszeuge, jetzt seine Aussage widerrufen hat. Das laesst weitere Zweifel an der Zuverlaessigkeit des Urteils der Jury aufkommen.

Ausserdem hatten vier der Juroren nicht fuer die Todesstrafe gestimmt, da sie Zweifel an der Schuld des Angeklagten hatten. Ohne die Zeugenaussage von Ralph Gajus haetten sich moeglicherweise noch mehr der Geschworenen gegen die Todesstrafe ausgesprochen.

Neueste Untersuchungen haben schwerwiegende Probleme in Floridas oberstem Justizwesen aufgezeigt. So gibt es geografische und rassenspezifische Unterschiede und ein Mangel an Voraussetzungen fr die Einstimmigkeit des Urteils der Geschworenen.

Ich bitte Sie dringend, das alles zu bedenken und die Exekution von Angel Nieves Diaz zu stoppen. 

Hochachtungsvoll gruesst Sie

From:	Michelle <michelle@foodsmatter.com>
Sent:	Thursday, November 30, 2006 4:17 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Governor 

 RE:  Angel Nieves Diaz

 I understand that Angel Nieves Diaz is still due to be executed on December 13th for the murder of Joseph Nagy in 1979.

 While I feel deep sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy and in no way wish to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused I do none the less oppose the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, both because I oppose any use of the death penalty and because his competency to stand trial and represent himself seems deeply questionable.

I understand that there was a major disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another a death sentence, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. I am also very concerned by the use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel Diaz in this case as it is a notoriously unreliable form of testimony.

Moreover, Ralph Gajus, the key prosecution witness at the trial, has now recanted his testimony  which calls the reliability of the jurys verdict into further question.

I also note that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent research has found serious problems with Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

I therefore call on you, Mr Governor, to intervene to stop this execution.

Respectfully,


Michelle Berriedale-Johnson

Editor - Foods Matter

5 Lawn Road, London NW3 2XS

Tel: 020 7722 2866

Fax: 020 7722 7685

Check out our new website at http://www.foodsmatter.com



From:	Barr S.P. <S.P.Barr@swansea.ac.uk>
Sent:	Thursday, November 30, 2006 4:11 AM
To:	Davis, Warren
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: APPEAL

Dear Warren Davis,

 

Many thanks for your speedy reply. Since the sending of my mail to Governor Bush I have learned that a key prosecution witness at the 1985 trial of Angel Nieves Diaz has recanted his testimony, which had been a key part of the evidence that convicted Diaz of murder.  On 27 November, lawyers for Angel Diaz filed a new motion in court on the basis of this new evidence.  Ralph Gajus has now provided a sworn affidavit stating that his testimony at the trial was false; that Angel Diaz never told him that he was the gunman; and that he did not know from his communication with Diaz who had shot Joseph Nagy.  He states that his testimony to the contrary was motivated by anger at Angel Diaz and a desire to gain favour from the state on his own murder charge.  Ralph Gajus had testified at the trial that he had not been promised anything in return for his testimony.  However, at his own sentencing a police officer had testified about the assistance Gajus had provided to the state in the Diaz case. 

During the jury's deliberations at the trial of Angel Diaz, the jurors requested copies of the testimony of Ralph Gajus, but the judge refused, instructing the jury to rely on its recollection of what he had said. The jury returned a guilty verdict.  Ralph 
Gajus's recantation further calls into question the reliability of their verdict. 

Although the jury recommended a death sentence for Angel Diaz, they did so only by eight votes to four, indicating possible residual doubt in the minds of the jurors even with the testimony of Ralph Gajus.  Without it, it is possible that more of the jurors would have voted against a death sentence.

 

Given these serious doubts as to the efficacy of this sentence I call on the Governor to intervene to stop this execution.

 

Many thanks for your assistance in this matter

..

 

Sean Barr

  _____  

From: Davis, Warren [mailto:Warren.Davis@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: 29 November 2006 16:06
To: Barr S.P.
Subject: RE: APPEAL

 

 

Dear Friend:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush about a death row inmate.  The Governor appreciates your  concerns and asked me to respond on his behalf.

 

Governor Bush believes that the death penalty is appropriate and warranted in certain capital murder cases, and supports its use by the courts in those cases.  The Governor also believes we should look not only to the issues surrounding the defendant, but also to the surviving victims, and to the effect the murder has on our community as a whole, in deciding whether the death penalty is an appropriate punishment.

 

Florida law provides numerous levels of appeals for the convicted individual before the sentence is moved.  Once a person is convicted of an aggravated first-degree murder and sentenced to death in Florida, the state voluntarily provides free legal representation to the convicted murderer until the sentence is carried out or reduced on appeal.  No other state has invested the public resources in capital post conviction legal representation that Florida has been providing for well over a decade. 

 

Governor Bush shares the concerns of many that the death penalty must be reserved for only the most heinous cases.  As the Governor has said many times, the signing of a death warrant is one of the most solemn and somber responsibilities he must undertake, and he does so with humble deliberation.

 

Again, thank you for taking the time to write about this very serious issue.

 

Sincerely,

 

Warren Davis

Office of Citizens Services

 

 S.P.Barr@swansea.ac.uk]

Dear Governor, 
I am an Irish librarian living in Wales, recently I have heard of the case of:

Angel Nieves Diaz

who is scheduled for execution in Florida on 13
December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder
during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.
I wish to express sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, am not seeking to
downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused.
I am opposing the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz as I note evidence
calling into question his competency to stand trial and represent
himself. I also note the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one
defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite
conflicting evidence about who was the gunman, and am concerned a 
th use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel
Diaz, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony.I also see that four of the jurors did not vote for the death
Penalty and must highlight recent research that has found serious problems with
Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial
disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury
sentencing decisions.I therefore call on you Governor to kindly intervene to stop this execution. 
Many thanks for your assistance in this matter, 
Yours, 

Sean Barr

From:	annika holmberg <iaholmberg@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Thursday, November 30, 2006 12:34 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	appeal

Dear Governor,
 
As a member of Amnesty International I would like to call upon your attention on the following case.
 
Angel Nieves Diaz is scheduled for execution in Florida on 13 December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.
I am expressing sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was killed in 1979, and I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused.
Still I am opposing the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, and calling into question his competency to stand trial and represent himself.
I  am noting the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman, and expressing concern at the use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel Diaz, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony.
Furthermore I am noting that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty.
Finally I am noting that recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.
I am calling on the Governor to intervene to stop this execution.

Yours sincerely,

Annika Holmberg, Sundbyberg, Sweden

November 29, 2006
 
Hon. Jeb Bush
Governor of the State of Florida
Office of the Governor
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399
 
Honorable Governor Bush:
 
This communication has the purpose to request your intervention to save the life of the Puerto Rican national ngel Nieves Daz, who was sentenced to death by this State of Florida over twenty years ago, and at this time is waiting to be executed.  You have ordered ngel's execution for this December the 13th.  All judicial appellate procedures have been exhausted.  
 
I am firmly opposed to the application of the death penalty.  The circumstances of this case deserve your immediate intervention.  There are plenty of reasons that convince me that prompt action has to be taken.  Among those reasons, we have to consider the age of ngel and the long time that Mr. Nieves Daz has been imprisoned -taking into account the terrible confinement circumstances of being in death row-.  Besides, a series of anomalies were observed in the judicial process, raising serious doubts about the fairness of the judicial process and even over the guilty verdict in Angel's case.  I humbly, but firmly request of you the immediate commutation of the death penalty for Mr. Nieves Daz.  In the alternative, we request a moratorium of the execution until all aspects of the case can be cleared, including further DNA tests.  
 
Sincerely,
 
Vidal Vlez
260 Seorial Mail Station
San Juan, Puerto Rico 00926
 
From:	Nebet . <nebet_@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, November 29, 2006 7:16 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz


November 29th 2006

Dear Governor:

With deep consternation I have heard of the sad news that Angel Nieves Diaz 
is scheduled for execution in Florida on December 13th 2006.

I do of course know that he was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder 
during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. Thus, please 
note that my present letter does of course not pretend to justify the 
violent death suffered by him. I would even appreciate being able to send my 
most sincere condolences to their relatives.

However, let me also point you out the disparity in sentencing in this case, 
with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite 
conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. I would like to remind you 
that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent 
research has found serious problems with Florida&#8217;s capital justice 
system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a 
requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

For the reasons I have exposed, I WOULD LIKE TO ASK YOU to intervene and 
stop this execution.

Hoping that you will be able to consider my request at your very earliest 
convenience, I look forward to receiving a favorable reply and remain

Sincerely yours
Signed:

Marta Cintas Pea, student.
Spain.

- je fais tat de la disparit des peines infliges dans cette affaire, o un accus a t condamn  la rclusion  perptuit et lautre  la peine de mort malgr la prsence de preuves contradictoires quant  lauteur du coup mortel, et jexprime ma proccupation quant  lutilisation contre Angel Diaz du tmoignage dun codtenu, type de dposition bien connu pour son manque de fiabilit ;

Thank you for your prompt reply.  I still don't think that any of you understand that nothing is being done due to lack of willingness.  I have not been able to present any evidence in reference to my allegations since no one seems to care, that is precisely the problem.  If after investigating my allegations someone, anyone, would tell me that maybe I was reading into things or that there was not enough evidence to proceed I would have been satisfied, however, every time I speak with someone they tell me it's not their job.
 
As far as the EEOC, of course I will follow the matter however, they will not be able to prosecute Fleming due to his fabrication of evidence or falsification of official records, that at this time is one of my main concerns, which obviously does not seem to matter to many.

Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> wrote:

Dear Ms. Peppin:

Thank you for your writing again to Governor Bush. It was my pleasure to speak with you recently regarding your concerns about your termination from employment and your allegations of misconduct by your employer, the Flagler County Sheriff's Department. Governor Bush asked me to respond in this regard.

As we discussed, the Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in civil and criminal court cases. It was my understanding you spoke with attorneys and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. That was the appropriate thing to do. I encourage you to work with legal counsel to resolve your concerns in this regard.

I also understand you spoke with the state attorney's office. Each state attorney is an elected official charged with certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction. This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt shown, and in the best interest of justice. 

For further assistance, you may wish to contact the Ethics Commission. That address is Post Office Drawer 15709, Tallahassee, Florida, 32317-5709, and the telephone number is (850) 488-7864.

Thank you again for writing. The Governor is sorry you were dissatisfied with the way this office has responded and wishes we could be of further assistance. Please know this is due to lack of jurisdiction, not lack of concern.


Sincerely,



Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

I sent a letter to Mr. Adams, and I also spoke with someone in your office, who suggested that I follow up with State Attorney Harry Shortstein, to see whether or not he was going to investigate the allegations made by myself against the Sheriff's Office of Flagler County and Sheriff Fleming. I was horrified to speak with this man, yes he did answer the phone and tried to be very polite, however, as a politician he explained that even though Mr. Adams had sent him a copy of the letter that I was referring to, he was not able to do anything about it since he did not feel he had the power to do. When I asked him if he felt that I was mislead or lied to, of course he replied "No", but I cannot do what they are saying I can. 

All I ever asked for was justice, and yes, I may be not have been born in this country however, I am not stupid, the only one that can intervene at this time is the Governor, I would prefer to be told he chooses not to, than to be continuesly sent on a wild goose chase. My unemployment has run out, I have no way to earn any monies, please note that I have worked in this country since I was 13 yoa, therefore, I am not asking for anything other than what I feel should be mine, a fair look into this case, and the right to earn a living, which I cannot do, since the Sheriff has fabricated evidence against me and falsefied official records, something else that Mr. Shortstein feels is not a criminal matter only a civil matter, I now have a better understanding as to why our judicial system doesn't work specially when our State Attorneys are not sure of the law.

At this time I know the governor refuses to do anything, but let me just see if I get this straight, Sheriff Fleming falsefies an official report by fabricating evidence, and this is only a civil matter, and not enough for the Governor to get involved, this on top of everything and every other problem Fleming is facing. Please enlighten me and tell me when will the Governor take a stand; when Fleming keeps falsifying official records to cover up his incompetence or he destroys the county is supposed to serve.

I hope you had a good holiday, since we could not afford one, and obviously our Christmas don't look any better. I hope yours is better.

Amnesty International submitted a second report of Angel Nieves Diaz.



Again I call on you to commute the death sentence of Angel Nieves Diaz who is scheduled for execution on 13 December 2006. I want to note that Ralph Gajus, a key prosecution witness at the trial, has now recanted his testimony against Angel Nieves Diaz. Dear Mr. Davis,
