>>> "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> 11/21/2006 4:05 PM
>>>
Dear Ms. Rowe:

Thank you for your recent e-mail to Governor Bush requesting assistance
with a child custody matter.  He has asked me to respond.

Custody and visitation rulings are under the jurisdiction of the
judicial system.  Under Florida law, the court's decision in these cases
is based on the best interest of the child or children involved.  Judges
review all of the information presented to them and apply the law to
make their decision.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters
that should be resolved through the court system.  If you are unhappy
with a ruling or feel a case has not been handled according to the law,
you should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be
available.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services
or the county legal aid association has information about the
availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number of Florida
Legal Services is (850) 385-7900.  Those dissatisfied with their
representatives should consider choosing another attorney.

Of course, should you suspect a child is in any danger, notify your
local law enforcement or the Department of Children and Families' hot
line, 1-800-96-ABUSE.

Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the
problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance. 
Please know this is due to lack of jurisdiction, not lack of concern.

Sincerely,



Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services 





-----Original Message-----
From: Patricia Rowe [mailto:prowe@alachuacounty.us] 
Sent: Sunday, November 19, 2006 7:31 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Information on getting inter-family adoption laws clarified
orchanged.


Dear Governor Bush,
                              My name is Patricia Rowe and I would like
your help, if you are able to assist.  My situation is unusual but not
too uncommon in today's society.  This is a long letter but I hope you
will take the time to read this letter.  I will try to make it as short
as I can.  On 11-22-96 my neice Michelle Lynn Hoffman gave birth to a
baby girl named Elin .  Michelle and Elin's birth father were not
married.  On 12-27-98 Michelle passed away.  In  June of 2000 my sister
and her husband, Michelle's step-father and Elin's step-grand-father
adopted Elin.  In July 0f 2000 my sister and her husband seperated.  In
November of 2000 my sister, Elin, and my nephew came to live with my
boys and I.  They lived with me until April of 2002, at which time my
sister and her children moved out of my house and moved in to a home of
their own.  On June 13th, 2002 my sister took her life and Elin and my
nephew came back to live with my boys and I.   Elin lived with me until
June of 2004.  My nephew had move out in 2002 as he had turned 18 and
moved out of state.  In June of 2004, Elin's adopted father had found
out he had cancer and asked to have Elin for the summer so he could
spend time with her.  He had gotten remarried. ( He was 64 and his wife
was 65, and Elin at this time was 7.)  He assured me that he would bring
Elin back to me in the fall as he knew Elin had been adopted back into
the family to stay with the family, after all we are her maternal blood
family.  In July of 2004 my family,(my mom, my nephew ) and I went to
see a family law attorney to find out if we had any rights to Elin.  We
were told that as long as her adopted father was alive he did not have
to let us see her because he was her legal parent, but that if he died
we could get her back.  I asked the attorney if he could have his new
wife adopt Elin and the attorney said no, not with out oour permission
because we were her blood family.  Elin's adopted father passed away the
day afterThanksgiving in 2005, and my family and I went to an attorney
to get Elin back.  At   that time we found out that Elin was adopted by
her step-mother.  We tried to have the adoption over turned, but that
was not a success, as the Judge that handled the adoption retired in
Febuary of 2006.  The new Judge would not over turn the adoption.  The
petition for the adoption had errors and misrepresentations.  The main
one being that her adopted father said he was the biological
grand-father and made no mention of Elin having other biological
relatives that had an interest in her.  
So my question is how do I get laws clarified or changed so that this
type situation does not happen to another child or family.  In my
oppinion this is legalized kidnapping.

Thank you for any help you can give me.  If you have any questions
please call @ (352)316-4240.

Sencerly, 
Patricia L.Rowe

From:	doug@cna.ne.jp
Sent:	Wednesday, November 29, 2006 3:12 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

												3-34, Nakacho,
												Hodono,
												Akita-Shi,
												Akita 010-0905,
												Japan.

												30th November 2006.

TO:	Governor Jeb Bush
	His Excellency Mr Robert Holmes Tuttle, Embassy of the United States


Dear Sirs,

	REF:	Angel Nieves Diaz 

I am writing to you as a British citizen and as a member of Amnesty International. I am most concerned about the impending execution of Angel Nieves Diaz on the grounds that he may have been incorrectly sentenced, another error of the capital justice system in the USA, which i personally oppose (although I am not an American citizen, so please excuse me). A key prosecution witness at the 1985 trial of Angel Nieves Diaz has recanted his testimony, which had been a key part of the evidence that convicted Diaz of murder.  On 27 November, lawyers 
for Angel Diaz filed a new motion in court on the basis of this new evidence.  

I wish to express sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was killed in 1979, and wish to explain that I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused; I oppos the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, noting evidence calling into question his competency to stand trial and represent himself; I note the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman; I note that Ralph Gajus, a key prosecution witness at the trial, has now recanted his testimony against Angel Diaz, calling into further doubt the reliability of the jury's verdict; I note that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty, indicating a possible residual doubt in their minds about the defendant's guilt, and suggesting that without the testimony of Ralph Gajus more of the jurors might have voted against a death sentence; I also note that recent research has found serious problems with Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions;

Finally, I call on the Governor to intervene to stop this execution. 

I look forward to any reply you care to make.


Regards,

	Douglas John Birbeck.

Its even more remote a chance now, surely, that you could sanction the execution of Angel Diaz, now that Ralph Gajus has retracted. Clearly, even more of the jurors would have voted against the death sentence if theyd known.
Please dont let Floridas judicial reputation be tarnished even further, and intervene to stop this execution. 

Yours sincerely,
Rod Evans

From:	Ana Aranguren <ana.aranguren@grupoci2m.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, November 29, 2006 8:14 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please, stop the execution!

Governor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399
ESTADOS UNIDOS

November 29th 2006

Dear Governor:

With deep consternation I have heard of the sad news that Angel Nieves Diaz is scheduled for execution in Florida on December 13th 2006.

I do of course know that he was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. Thus, please note that my present letter does of course not pretend to justify the violent death suffered by him. I would even appreciate being able to send my most sincere condolences to their relatives.

However, let me also point you out the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. I would like to remind you that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

For the reasons I have exposed, I WOULD LIKE TO ASK YOU to intervene and stop this execution.

Hoping that you will be able to consider my request at your very earliest convenience, I look forward to receiving a favorable reply and remain

Sincerely yours

Ana Aranguren

Dear Governor:
With deep consternation I have heard of the sad news that Angel Nieves Diaz is scheduled for execution in Florida on December 13th 2006.
I do of course know that he was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. Thus, please note that my present letter does of course not pretend to justify the violent death suffered by him. I would even appreciate being able to send my most sincere condolences to their relatives.
However, let me also point you out the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. I would like to remind you that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.
For the reasons I have exposed, I WOULD LIKE TO ASK YOU to intervene and stop this execution.
Hoping that you will be able to consider my request at your very earliest convenience, I look forward to receiving a favorable reply and remain
Sincerely yours

From:	jose maria flores delcan <josemariafloresdelcan@yahoo.es>
Sent:	Wednesday, November 29, 2006 5:39 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	amemb@embusa.es
Subject:	ANGEL NIEVES DIAZ

	

  Sr. Gobernador:
 
  Me dirijo a usted expresando en primer lugar mi oposicin a cualquier acto de violencia de la ndole que sea, as como expresando mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, en momentos en los que su dolor se recrudece al tener que recordar el episodio fatal ocurrido en aquella fecha, ante la inminente fecha de la ejecucin de la pena capital de Angel Nieves Diaz.
 
  Por otra parte, respecto a dicha condena de pena de muerte, mostrar mi firme conviccin de que ese no es el camino correcto para mostrar a la sociedad que la fuerza del Estado recae sobre las personas que pudieran actuar al margen de la ley en casos de extrema gravedad. Centrandome en el caso concreto de Angel Nieves Daz dudo en primer lugar que ste tuviera la capacidad para poder defenderse a s mismo con las garantas mnimas que el procedimiento requera, y es ms incluso para tener que ser juzgado como principal inculpado por el hecho material de haber disparado contra Joseph Nagy, provocando su muerte.
 
  Sealo aparte, la incongruencia que se muestra en el proceso al haber incluso disparidad de condenas, lo que a mi entender es muestra inequvoca de la poca claridad con la que se vean los hechos por el tribunal competente en el caso, ya que hay que subrayar que mientras Angel Toro fu condenado a cadena perpetua, Angel Nieves lo fu a pena de muerte pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quien fu el autor material de los disparos, y sobre todo findose del testimonio de un informador encarcelado que dijo haber escuchado del condenado a muerte que l haba disparado a Joseph Nagy, testimonio, a mi entender, poco fiable, incluso dira que movido por intereses personales de su compaero de celda para as poder sacar algn beneficio respecto a su condena, opinin, sta, muy personal, pero creo que nunca descabellada a la luz de la lgica ms lgica.
 
  Otro dato que corrobora al rechazo de que Angel Nieves Daz no sea ejecutado es que de los 12 componentes del jurado popular slo 8 lo condenaran, mientras que los 4 restantes no lo consideraron as, disparidad de criterios ante un mismo asunto a la vista, aparte de considerar que NADIE tiene poder para adoptar una medida como ejecutar mediante su voto a otra a la muerte, considero que en juicios de especial gravedad si el mtodo del jurado es el elegido el criterio de una mayora es inaceptable, como ha sido el caso, pero es que ni aunque fuera por unanimidad, e incluso ya en el caso de que fuera un juez quien lo decidiera. Con ste sistema no solo se ve el dolor de la familia del asesinado, ni solo del condenado y sus parientes, sino que esas personas que toman una decisin tan grave y que al final de cuentas hacen que el 16 de Diciembre de 2006 se pueda haber matado a una persona amparndose en las reglas del juego del Estado de Derecho.
 
  Sealar que investigaciones recientes detectan serios problemas en la aplicacin de la pena de muerte en el estado de Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales, y tambin el hecho de que no se requiera unanimidad por parte del jurado para ste tipo de casos.
 
  Por ltimo pedirle, Sr. Gobernador, que teniendo la posibilidad de detener la ejecucin del ciudadano y PERSONA: Angel Nieves Daz, haga todo lo posible para que as sea.
 
  Un saludo y gracias.

  _____

From:	Jess Mara Quintero Procopio <jm_qp@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, November 29, 2006 5:08 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	to the attention of the office of the governor


Governor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399
ESTADOS UNIDOS

November 29th 2006

Dear Governor:

With deep consternation I have heard of the sad news that Angel Nieves Diaz is scheduled for execution in Florida on December 13th 2006.

I do of course know that he was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. Thus, please note that my present letter does of course not pretend to justify the violent death suffered by him. I would even appreciate being able to send my most sincere condolences to their relatives.

However, let me also point you out the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. I would like to remind you that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

For the reasons I have exposed, I WOULD LIKE TO ASK YOU to intervene and stop this execution.

Hoping that you will be able to consider my request at your very earliest convenience, I look forward to receiving a favorable reply and remain

Sincerely yours
Jess Quintero

 Dear Governor/Sr. Gobernador:

   Este mensaje es para mostrar mi absoluto rechazo a
la condena a la pena capital a la que ha sido
condenado el preso Angel Nieves Diaz y que, si usted
no lo impide, se hara efectiva el proximo 13 de
diciembre.

   En primer lugar me gustaria mostrar mi apoyo y mis
condolencias a la familia de Josep Nagy, asesinado en
el bar Velvet Swing Lounge en 1979. Mi oposicion a la
ejecucion de Angel Nieves Diaz no va contra la
necesidad de impartir justicia a la que la familia del
asesinado tiene todo el derecho.

   Angel Nieves Diaz fue condenado por dicho asesinato
por un jurado popular en 1986 en proceso en el que
aparecen varias dudas:

   En primer lugar la votacion del jurado no fue
unanime si no de 8 votos contra 4 a favor de la
ejecucion.

   En segundo lugar hay numerosas seales durante el
proceso que ponen en duda la capacidad del acusado
para ser juzgado y para ejercer la capacidad de
representarse a si mismo en su defensa: falta de
dominio del idioma, problemas mentales resultado de la
adiccion a las drogas del acusado, etc...

    En tercer lugar le pido a usted que valore el
hecho de que, el otro acusado del asesinato, Angel
Toro, fue condenado a cadena perpetua con lo que se
muestra una disparidad de condenas entre ambos
acusados por los mismos delitos.

    Por todo ello, le solicito humildemente que tenga
a bien intervenir para detener esta ejecucion, sobre
la que tantas dudas razonables se plantean y que solo
significaria una triste vengaza por parte del Estado y
un retroceso de la verdadera justicia,

Atentamente,

Fernando Justo
Bilbao

From:	Hodges, Scott <Scott.Hodges@jacobs.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, November 28, 2006 4:05 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Keith Hodges
Subject:	RE: Taylor Wells

Mr. Davis, I am Keith Hodges' son and again, on behalf our family, thank you
for your reply to my father's email. Please feel free not to reply to this
email but because you are the first person to reply to us with any knowledge
and intelligence, I have a few questions that have been troubling me. I'm 28,
Taylor's closest family member and our family has somewhat flourished since
the time of his conviction (as we all know Taylor would have as well). At the
time of his arrest, we were not able to afford private representation and
Taylor was indeed a naive high school kid who was willing to cooperate with
his appointed attorney and authorities as indicated in all of the court
documents and police correspondence. I will be short because I am very
thankful for your time...if a kid was not read his rights when arrested, was
represented by an attorney who was later disbarred and convicted by a judge
who was lobbying for "gang laws" in Florida, who would our family or Taylor
contact so that these facts are addressed? Would the Florida Parole
Commission be the correct avenue? We have given clemency a shot but as you
stated, it is rarely granted. Our family has tremendous loyalty to Florida,
its officials and the Bush family. We are simply confused and a bit
frustrated what is deemed fair and unfair in the eyes of our great State. 

Again, we thank so much for at least listening and responding. I wish you all
the best in your future endeavors and please know our family will always be
supportive of all of you who represent us. 

Scott J. Hodges
 

-----Original Message-----
From: Keith Hodges [mailto:keith_hodges@co.escambia.fl.us] 
Sent: Tuesday, November 28, 2006 4:25 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: Hodges, Scott; Keith/Peggy Hodges; Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com
Subject: Re: Taylor Wells

Thank you Mr. Davis for your gracious and thorough response on behalf of 
Governor Bush.  We appreciate how the "system" is supposed to work and we 
have pursued vigorously every avenue made known to us.  However, it is 
disappointing that no matter how many questionable circumstances involving 
this case are raised, no matter how many unbiased individuals question the 
equity of the outcome of this case (including parties representing the 
Governor and the Cabinet) and no matter how exemplary Taylor's record has 
been since incarceration, it appears that the "system" is failing!  I 
personally don't know of anyone that has taken the time to meet Taylor, 
speak with Taylor or review the facts of Taylor's case that has believed 
that what is transpiring is justice; with the exception of the victim's 
mother and the winning prosecutor.  I recognize that you cannot render any 
optimism on this matter, but the reality is that Taylor's case is, in fact, 
the exception that warrants Executive intervention.  I personally witnessed 
the Clemency Board granting second chances to individuals who had far 
greater participation in serious crimes than Taylor, but what they had in 
their favor was forgiveness from victim's representatives.  I do wish to 
reiterate my gratitude to you for your response and likewise even moreso to 
Governor Bush for all of his efforts, tough decisions, dedication and 
devoted public service to Florida over all these many years!  Thank You! 
Respectfully , Keith B. Hodges


----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Keith Hodges" <keith_hodges@co.escambia.fl.us>
Sent: Monday, November 27, 2006 1:01 PM
Subject: RE: Taylor Wells


Dear Mr. Hodges:

Thank you for your thoughtful e-mail to Governor Bush regarding  your 
nephew, Taylor Wells.  The Governor understands your concerns in this regard 
and asked me to respond on his behalf.

As you know, each state attorney is an elected official charged with certain 
discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to prosecute 
any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction.  This 
decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt 
shown, and in the best interest of justice.  The Florida Constitution limits 
the Governor's intervention in criminal cases.  Questions about the guilt or 
innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to commit a crime, or the procedural 
fairness of their convictions must be addressed in the courts. Those who 
wish to contest judicial rulings work with an attorney about what appellate 
procedures may be available.

The Governor has no independent ability to pardon someone. The clemency 
function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's 
civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these 
lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with 
the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected 
officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to 
await the outcome of court appeals.  The Florida Parole Commission, an 
entity independent of the Governor's control, determines the issues of 
control release and early release.  The Commission's address is Building C, 
2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450.

Thank you again for writing and for sharing your concerns with Governor Bush 
about this important issue.

 
Sincerely,



 
Warren 
Davis
 
Office 
of Citizens' Services



-----Original Message-----
From: Keith Hodges [mailto:keith_hodges@co.escambia.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, November 22, 2006 12:57 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: Scott J. Hodges; Keith/Peggy Hodges
Subject: Taylor Wells


Dear Governor Bush:  This will most likely be one of my final e-mails to you 
as my Governor.  I want to personally thank you for your servanthood to our 
great state of Florida.  I likewise want to thank you for your unwavering 
support of your brother and my President!  Finally, I would like to plead 
one more time for my nephew, Taylor Glenn Wells.  Governor, you granted me 
the distinct honor of speaking before you, Governor-Elect Crist, and Cabinet 
Members Gallagher & Bronson on December 9, 2004.  As of that date, Taylor 
had experienced nearly twelve years of incarceration and had received no 
adverse disciplinary actions and, in fact, was designated as an "exemplary" 
inmate.  Time and again, unbiased aide's and investigator's that have 
interviewed Taylor and reviewed his history have been very favorably 
impressed.  Time and again, most everyone questions how this whole ordeal 
transpired and why the System's reformation success and an exceptional 
inmate's excellent conduct have not translated into a "second chance" for 
Taylor.  I have prayed for the mother of the deceased young man and I hope 
one day she can realistically recognize Taylor's minor and unwitting role in 
this tragedy and forgive him.  Likewise, I have kept my promise to pray for 
you!  Governor Bush, I pray once again that somehow, someway, recognition of 
all the positive results of Taylor's imprisonment over what is now nearly 
fourteen years will ultimately supersede bitterness and prevail in a 
decision to release Taylor Wells!!!  Thank you again for your service to our 
State and thank you again for your deliberations on Taylor's behalf. 
Respectfully submitted, Keith B. Hodges

it from your computer.

this case are raised, no matter how many unbiased individuals question the

Governor and the Cabinet) and no matter how exemplary Taylor's record has 
been since incarceration, it appears that the "system" is failing!  I 
personally don't know of anyone that has taken the time to meet Taylor, 
speak with Taylor or review the facts of Taylor's case that has believed 
that what is transpiring is justice; with the exception of the victim's 
mother and the winning prosecutor.  I recognize that you cannot render any 
optimism on this matter, but the reality is that Taylor's case is, in fact, 
the exception that warrants Executive intervention.  I personally witnessed 
the Clemency Board granting second chances to individuals who had far

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Keith Hodges" <keith_hodges@co.escambia.fl.us>
Sent: Monday, November 27, 2006 1:01 PM
Subject: RE: Taylor Wells


Dear Mr. Hodges:

Thank you for your thoughtful e-mail to Governor Bush regarding  your 
nephew, Taylor Wells.  The Governor understands your concerns in this regard 
and asked me to respond on his behalf.

As you know, each state attorney is an elected official charged with certain 
discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to prosecute 
any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction.  This 
decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt 
shown, and in the best interest of justice.  The Florida Constitution limits 
the Governor's intervention in criminal cases.  Questions about the guilt or 
innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to commit a crime, or the procedural 
fairness of their convictions must be addressed in the courts. Those who 
wish to contest judicial rulings work with an attorney about what appellate 
procedures may be available.

The Governor has no independent ability to pardon someone. The clemency 
function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's 
civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these 
lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with 
the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected 
officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to 
await the outcome of court appeals.  The Florida Parole Commission, an 
entity independent of the Governor's control, determines the issues of 
control release and early release.  The Commission's address is Building C, 
2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450.

Thank you again for writing and for sharing your concerns with Governor Bush 
about this important issue.

                                                                        Sincerely,



                                                                        Warren 
Davis
                                                                        Office 
of Citizens' Services

Members Gallagher & Bronson on December 9, 2004.  As of that date, Taylor 
had experienced nearly twelve years of incarceration and had received no 
adverse disciplinary actions and, in fact, was designated as an "exemplary" 
inmate.  Time and again, unbiased aide's and investigator's that have 
interviewed Taylor and reviewed his history have been very favorably 
impressed.  Time and again, most everyone questions how this whole ordeal 
transpired and why the System's reformation success and an exceptional 
inmate's excellent conduct have not translated into a "second chance" for

From:	Elke Varnskuehler <elke@varnskuehler.de>
Sent:	Tuesday, November 28, 2006 1:01 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Execution of Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Governor,

     Through amnesty international I heard about the execution of ANGEL
NIEVES DIAZ scheduled for December 13, 2006.
I would like to express my sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was
killed on December 29, 1979. I do not want to downplay the seriousness of
this crime or the suffering caused but I oppose the use of death penalty in
all cases on humanitarian grounds.

     In ANGEL NIEGEL DIAZ` case there is evidence calling into question his
competency to stand trial and represent himself. Further I see the disparity
in sentencing in this case with one defendant receiving a life sentence and
another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman. I am
very concerned at the use of jailhouse informant testimony against ANGEL
NIEGEL DIAZ, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony.

     The jury recommended a death sentence by eight votes to four. Recent
research has found serious problems with Floridas capital justice system,
including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement
for unanimity in jury sentencing decisions.

     I urgently ask you to commute the death sentence of ANGEL NIEGEL DIAZ
on the grounds mentioned above and on the basis that his execution would be
in violation of the right to life as proclaimed in the UN Declaration of
Human Rights.

     I look forward to hearing from you soon in connection with this serious
matter.

Yours respectfully
Elke Varnskuehler

From:	Oscar Muiz <oscarmuniz@gmail.com>

Subject:	Ejecucin

Sr. Gobernador de Florida

JEB BUSH

The Capitol, 400 South Monroe Street, Tallahassee, FL 32399, EE.UU.

 

Seor Gobernador: 

 

Me dirijo a Ud. para expresarle mi apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, sin pretender restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni el sufrimiento que ha causado. 

 

Me opongo a la ejecucin de Angel Nieves Daz, ya que en los procedimientos posteriores a la condena se han presentado pruebas y testimonios no presentados durante el juicio. Tengo en cuenta la infancia de abusos y problemas mentales de ngel Daz, y sobre su adiccin a las drogas desde los 16 aos. Tambin considero que se ha argumentado que la acusacin no desvel los indicios de que haba sido ngel Toro quien haba disparado a Joseph Nagy, adems en la vista de determinacin de la pena y pese a pedir representarse a s mismo, ngel Daz admiti ante el tribunal que no estaba capacitado para hacerlo adecuadamente. 

 

La disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado recibe una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos, y la existencia de un testimonio poco fiable hecho por un informante encarcelado, me llevan a expresarle mi preocupacin. 

 

Adems se debe tener presente que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte y que una   reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena. 


Por todo lo expresado solicito a Ud. Seor Gobernador de Florida, intervenir para que ordene la detencin de esta ejecucin. 

 

                                                      Oscar Muiz

>From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
>To: "richard lovold" <richard_lovold@hotmail.com>
>Subject: RE: wrongfully accused and jailed
>Date: Mon, 27 Nov 2006 16:05:46 -0500
>
>Dear Ms. Lovold:
>
>Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush regarding your husband's legal 
>situation.  He understands the pain friends and family experience in these 
>situations and asked me to respond.
>
>As you may know, the decision to charge a person for crimes is made by the 
>state attorney, a locally elected official.  Deciding whether or not to 
>charge a person is based on the best interests of justice and on the 
>quantity and quality of the evidence of criminal activity.
>
>The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that 
>should be resolved through the court system.  If you believe a person is 
>innocent, or not guilty of all charges, you may wish to obtain the services 
>of an attorney experienced in criminal defense. If you need assistance in 
>locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 
>1-800-342-8011.
>
>Those who are facing criminal charges for which prison time is a 
>possibility, may be appointed an attorney by the court.  For further 
>assistance in this regard, please contact the office of your locally 
>elected public defender.  Please be sure the attorney is provided with all 
>of the evidence you believe shows innocence.
>
>The Governor trusts justice will be served in this case.
>
>						Sincerely,
>
>
>
>						Warren Davis
>						Office of Citizens' Services
>
>

acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de 
muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de 
los disparos; estoy preocupada por el uso contra ngel Daz del testimonio 
de un informador encarcelado, un tipo de testimonio notoriamente poco 
fiable.

aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de 
disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere 
unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena.

From:	Gloria Riol Gallego <aglar_thirion@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Monday, November 27, 2006 8:12 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	amemb@embusa.es
Subject:	Oposicin a la pena de muerte ngel Nieves Diaz

Muy estimado Sr. Gobernador de Florida:
Mi nombre es Gloria y vivo en Espaa. Me dirijo respetuosamente a usted para 
expresarle mi oposicin a la ejecucin Angel Nieves Diaz, prevista para el 
prximo dia 13 de Diciembre.
Antes de exponerle las razones que me llevan a oponerme, debo decir que 
quiero manifestar todo mi apoyo a la familia del seor Joseph Nagy, 
asesinado en 1979 y que en ningn momento pretendo restarle gravedad a este 
crimen ni ignorar el sufrimiento que haya podido causar en su entorno.

Quisiera llamarle la atencin acerca de ciertos datos, a mi juicio 
importantes, que he encontrado mientras segua el caso.
En primer lugar,la disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un 
acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de 
muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de 
los disparos ya que no hubo testigos presenciales del hecho y el uso contra 
ngel Daz del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, un tipo de 
testimonio notoriamente poco fiable.
    Adems existen seales claras que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser 
juzgado y para representarse a s mismo, como son los antecedentes de 
abusos, problemas con las drogas, trastornos mentales y escasa cultura que 
el acusado ha sufrido desde que era un no. A esto hay que unir su escaso 
dominio del ingls.
He observado tambin ciertas irregularidades en la vista que se celebr 
antes del juicio para determinar su capacidad, como el hecho de que ni el 
acusado, ni el abogado de ste, ni uno de los doctores que dictaminaron 
sobre su estado estuvieran presentes en dicha vista. Asi mismo, he sabido 
que evaluaciones psiquitricas posteriores a la condena han revelado 
trastornos mentales en el acusado que impediran que pudiese ser juzgado o 
representarse a si mismo,lo cul fu confirmado tambin por su abogado.
Tambin creo que el hecho de que el acusado tuviese que hacer su alegato con 
grilletes puestos contribuira a que fuera percibido como ms peligroso por 
el jurado, lo cul podra haber tenido un peso decisivo en el veredicto 
final con el que, le recuerdo, hubo cuatro ciudadanos de doce que no 
estuvieron de acuerdo.
Para terminar, estoy segura de que tiene conocimiento de un estudio 
realizado recientemente bajo los auspicios del Proyecto de Aplicacin de la 
Suspensin de la Pena de Muerte, del Colegio Estadounidense de Abogados,que 
identific serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital 
en Florida, entre ellos el elevado ndice de personas excarceladas del 
corredor de la muerte tras demostrarse su inocencia (22 desde 1973 que, de 
haber sido ejecutadas no hubieran podido disfrutar de esta condicin), la 
existencia continuada de disparidades raciales y geogrficas, que no se 
requiera unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena y el hecho de que no 
se da peso suficiente a los efectos atenuantes de la discapacidad mental 
grave.

Habindole expuesto lo ms brevemente posible mis argumentos y confiando en 
su sentido de la justicia y la libertad de la que su pas es smbolo, le 
pido sincera y encarecidamente que intervenga para detener esta ejecucin.
Le reitero Seor Gobernador mi peticin as como mis ms humildes respetos.
Se despide de usted:
Gloria Riol Gallego
(Espaa)

Gobernador de Florida


Governor Jeb Bush, The Capitol, 400 South Monroe Street, Tallahassee, FL 32399, EE. UU .

Seor Gobernador:

                                   2.- Quiero hacerle llegar, con todo respeto, mi oposicin a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, a la vista de todas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo en el juicio. 

                                   3.- Considere, Seor, la disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos; tngase en cuenta, adems, el uso contra ngel Daz del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, un tipo de testimonio notoriamente poco fiable.

Dear Governor,

concerning the case of ngel Nieves Daz, 55 years old prisoner sentenced to death (see end of current text), please bear in mind the following: Ten commandments (The text of Deuteronomy 5:6-21):

   
 
6I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery; 7you shall have no other gods before me. 8You shall not make for yourself an idol, whether in the form of anything that is in heaven above, or that is on the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth. 9You shall not bow down to them or worship them; for I the Lord your God am a jealous God, punishing children for the iniquity of parents, to the third and fourth generation of those who reject me, 10but showing steadfast love to the thousandth generation of those who love me and keep my commandments. 11You shall not make wrongful use of the name of the Lord your God, for the Lord will not acquit anyone who misuses his name. 12Observe the sabbath day and keep it holy, as the Lord your God commanded you. 13For six days you shall labour and do all your work. 14But the seventh day is a sabbath to the Lord your God; you shall not do any workyou, or your son or your daughter, or your male or female slave, or your ox or your donkey, or any of your livestock, or the resident alien in your towns, so that your male and female slave may rest as well as you. 15Remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt, and the Lord your God brought you out from there with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm; therefore the Lord your God commanded you to keep the sabbath day. 16Honour your father and your mother, as the Lord your God commanded you, so that your days may be long and that it may go well with you in the land that the Lord your God is giving you. 17You shall not murder. 18Neither shall you commit adultery. 19Neither shall you steal. 20Neither shall you bear false witness against your neighbour. 21Neither shall you covet your neighbours wife. Neither shall you desire your neighbours house, or field, or male or female slave, or ox, or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbour.

PBLICO ndice AI: AMR 51/177/2006 24 de noviembre de 2006

AU 317/06 Pena de muerte / preocupacin jurdica

EE. UU. (Florida) ngel Nieves Daz, de 55 aos de edad

Est previsto que ngel Nieves Daz sea ejecutado en Florida el 13 de diciembre de 2006. Fue condenado a muerte en 1986 por el asesinato, durante un robo, de Joseph Nagy, encargado de un bar, en Miami en 1979. 
Joseph Nagy era el encargado del bar Velvet Swing Lounge. Muri de un disparo el 29 de diciembre de 1979 cuando tres hombres robaron en el establecimiento. No hubo testigos presenciales de los disparos. ngel Daz y ngel Toro fueron acusados de asesinato en primer grado en 1984, pero el juicio se retras hasta diciembre de 1985. Para entonces, ngel Toro se haba declarado culpable de asesinato en segundo grado a cambio de una pena de cadena perpetua.
ngel Daz, originario de Puerto Rico, estuvo representado por un abogado hasta poco despus de la seleccin del jurado. Justo antes de la apertura de su juicio, y contra el consejo de su abogado, decidi encargarse l mismo de su defensa. El abogado inform al juez de que ngel Daz haba "mostrado tendencias bastante extraas" en los das anteriores, con conductas como no responder a las preguntas del abogado o dar respuestas irracionales. Tambin dijo que, en las 24 horas anteriores, ngel Daz haba rechazado la estrategia de defensa que haban elaborado en los meses anteriores.
El juez interrog al acusado sobre su decisin. Mediante un intrprete (su ingls era limitado), ngel Daz dijo que nunca haba ledo un libro y no tena "ni idea" de cmo se llevaba a cabo un juicio en Florida o "qu cosas puedo alegar". El juez le dijo: "Puesto que no puede hablar ingls ante este tribunal, no conoce la ley, y no [concluy sus estudios escolares], este Tribunal opina que a usted le resultara imposible actuar como abogado en su propia defensa". ngel Daz mantuvo su decisin y el juez resolvi que la haba tomado de manera libre e inteligente.
El juez hizo que dos psiquiatras evaluaran a Daz tras los procedimientos de ese da para determinar si estaba capacitado para ser juzgado. Mientras tanto, el juicio dio comienzo: Daz hizo su alegato de apertura y la fiscala present a cinco testigos antes de que se dictara un receso para el resto del da. Los dos psiquiatras evaluaron a ngel Daz esa tarde. A la maana siguiente se celebr una vista para determinar la capacidad del acusado, sin que estuvieran presentes ni ngel Daz ni el abogado que le ayudaba. Las actas de esa vista se componen de unas pocas frases. Uno de los psiquiatras dijo al juez: "ngel Daz es apto. Pero me dijo que le gustara tener alguna ayuda legal tcnica para su defensa". El juez dijo a continuacin que tena un informe del otro mdico (que no estaba presente) que deca que ngel Daz estaba "muy capacitado". Despus de eso se permiti que el juicio continuara.
Las evaluaciones realizadas tras la condena por dos expertos en salud mental concluyeron que ngel Daz sufre ciertos trastornos mentales que contribuyeron a su decisin de representarse a s mismo y minaron su capacidad para hacerlo de forma competente. El abogado que lo represent hasta la apertura del juicio firm una declaracin jurada en la que deca: "No creo que ngel Daz estuviera capacitado para representarse a s mismo. A consecuencia de ello, hizo preguntas que no debera haber hecho y no pudo protestar a ciertas preguntas y pruebas despus de que yo le aconsej, a travs del intrprete, que lo hiciera. No creo que comprendiera adecuadamente el sistema judicial y la forma de realizarse el juicio, a causa de las diferencias culturales y las barreras lingsticas, entre otras razones".
Durante el juicio, ngel Daz fue obligado a permanecer con grilletes. Durante la seleccin del jurado, su abogado haba protestado contra esta medida, pero el juez respondi que Daz poda cubrirse los grilletes con los pantalones o el abogado poda colocar su maletn delante de las piernas del acusado. Sin embargo, una vez que ngel Daz empez a representarse a s mismo los grilletes quedaron a la vista del jurado, lo que plantea dudas sobre su efecto perjudicial respecto a la presuncin de inocencia. Adems, se ha demostrado que la aparente peligrosidad de un acusado es un factor sumamente agravante a los ojos de los jurados de casos de pena capital que deciden entre condenas de muerte o de cadena perpetua.

La ex novia de ngel Daz testific que, la noche del delito, ste le haba dicho que ngel Toro haba disparado contra un hombre durante el robo. El testimonio de otras dos personas, que estaban en el bar en el momento del robo, indicaba que ngel Daz no haba sido el autor de los disparos. Sin embargo, un informador encarcelado declar que, mientras estaban en la misma celda, ngel Daz haba indicado que haba disparado a Joseph Nagy. El testimonio de este tipo de informadores es notoriamente poco fiable. La Comisin sobre Pena Capital, establecida por el gobernador de Illinois tras dictar una suspensin de las ejecuciones en el ao 2000, examin la cuestin de estos testimonios y, en su informe de abril de 2002, concluy que, incluso con las salvaguardias ms estrictas, "la posibilidad de que se presenten testimonios de fiabilidad dudosa sigue siendo elevada, y no es aconsejable imponer una condena de muerte en tales casos".
El jurado se retir a deliberar sobre la cuestin de la culpabilidad. Durante sus deliberaciones, pidieron copias del testimonio de la ex novia y el informador encarcelado, pero el juez se neg a proporcionrselas, y dio instrucciones de que el jurado se basara en su recuerdo de lo que los testigos haban dicho. El jurado emiti un veredicto de culpabilidad.
La vista de determinacin de la pena se celebr dos semanas despus. Al inicio, pese a pedir representarse a s mismo, ngel Daz admiti ante el tribunal que no estaba capacitado para hacerlo adecuadamente. El tribunal entonces nombr como representante durante esa fase del proceso al abogado que ayudaba al acusado. ngel Daz se neg a permitir que el abogado interrogara a los primeros testigos de la acusacin. El abogado aleg como atenuante que Daz slo haba sido cmplice del delito, pero no present ningn nuevo testimonio a este respecto. El jurado recomend una condena de muerte por ocho votos contra cuatro.
En los procedimientos posteriores a la condena se han presentado pruebas y testimonios, no presentados durante el juicio, sobre la infancia de abusos y problemas mentales de ngel Daz, y sobre su adiccin a las drogas desde los 16 aos. Tambin se ha argumentado que la acusacin no desvel los indicios de que haba sido ngel Toro quien haba disparado a Joseph Nagy. En un memorndum fechado el 6 de febrero de 1984, el fiscal escribi: "En algn momento, los tres sujetos sacaron armas y anunciaron que se trataba de un robo. Se realizaron disparos. Al parecer, el acusado Toro agarr a Gina Fredericks por el cuello y la llev de vuelta hacia la oficina, donde se encontraba la caja fuerte. Parece ser que la vctima Nagy sali de la oficina en ese momento. El acusado Toro dispar contra Nagy una vez en el pecho, causndole la muerte".
Un estudio realizado recientemente bajo los auspicios del Proyecto de Aplicacin de la Suspensin de la Pena de Muerte, del Colegio Estadounidense de Abogados, identific serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos el elevado ndice de personas excarceladas del "corredor de la muerte" tras demostrarse su inocencia (22 desde 1973), la existencia continuada de disparidades raciales y geogrficas, el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena y el hecho de que no se da peso suficiente a los efectos atenuantes de la discapacidad mental grave. 

ACCIONES RECOMENDADAS: Enven sus llamamientos para que lleguen lo antes posible, en ingls o en su propio idioma:

- manifestando su apoyo a la familia de Joseph Nagy, asesinado en 1979, y explicando que no pretenden restar importancia a la gravedad de este crimen ni del sufrimiento que ha causado;
- oponindose a la ejecucin de ngel Nieves Daz, e indicando todas las seales que ponen en duda su capacidad para ser juzgado y para representarse a s mismo;
- sealando la disparidad de las condenas en este caso, en el que un acusado ha recibido una pena de cadena perpetua y el otro una condena de muerte, pese a los testimonios contradictorios sobre quin fue el autor de los disparos; expresando adems preocupacin por el uso contra ngel Daz del testimonio de un informador encarcelado, un tipo de testimonio notoriamente poco fiable;
- sealando que cuatro de los miembros del jurado no votaron a favor de la pena de muerte;
- sealando que una reciente investigacin ha detectado serios problemas en el sistema de aplicacin de la pena capital en Florida, entre ellos la existencia de disparidades geogrficas y raciales y el hecho de que no se requiere unanimidad en el jurado para imponer la pena;
- pidiendo al gobernador que intervenga para detener esta ejecucin.

LLAMAMIENTOS A:
Gobernador de Florida
Governor Jeb Bush, The Capitol, 400 South Monroe Street, Tallahassee, FL 32399, EE. UU.
Correo-E.: jeb.bush@myflorida.com

Angel Nieves Diaz

December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder
during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.
I wish to express sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, am not seeking to
downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused.
I am opposing the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz as I note evidence
calling into question his competency to stand trial and represent
himself. I also note the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one
defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite
conflicting evidence about who was the gunman, and am concerned a 
th use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel
Diaz, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony.I also see that four of the jurors did not vote for the death
Penalty and must highlight recent research that has found serious problems with
Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial
disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury
sentencing decisions.I therefore call on you Governor to kindly intervene to stop this execution.

Sean Barr

Dear Governor Bush,
 
    Hi, my name is Miranda Williams, I am a 23 year old student and mother from Wesley Chapel, Fl. I have recently read an article in the Tampa Tribune which really upset me, and I want my voice heard!!!!!  Let me start by telling you the article.  "Driver Given Life Sentence In Death Of Trooper"
"Lake City
    A driver convicted of second degree murder for causing a crash that killed the FHP chasing him recieved the maximum sentence Wednesday of life in prison.  Gregory Hampton Platt had taken a life that cannot be replaced, said Third Judicial Circuit Judge Paul Bryan. "If any sentence would bring him back to life, I would do it," Bryan said.  Platt also was sentenced to 15 years in prison for fleeing a police officer in a high speed pursuit and an additional 15 years in prison for leaving the scene of an accident resulting in a death.  He also recieved 60 days in jail on a charge of driving with a suspended or revoked license, but recieved credit for time already served.  He is already serving 55 years in prison from additional charges in citrus county, where he was captured after the April 2004 wreck that killed Sgt. George "Andy" Brown III." She was headed home to Okeechobee when a man crossed the center line and hit her head on going approx. 60 miles an hour.  She had no where to go and no time to react.  The 20 something year old man that killed her had been drinking, had not slept in 72 hours, and had been contemplating suicide.  This man lived, he will never be able to walk again but that is a very small price to pay for killing someone.  To make matters worse he was not sentenced to any jail time, let alone life in prison.  Now I am upset with this article because that man recieved life in prison for killing a state trooper.  I'm sorry if this comes out the wrong way but why was that state troopers life more valuable than my grandmothers?  Was it because he was a state trooper? My grandmother was a very hard working, honest, loving, and intelligent woman who deserves the same justice as that state trooper.  I know to many years have passed by for anything to be done about it now but I dont feel that it is right the way this justice system has come to this conclusion.  Imagine if this had happened to your family, wouldn't you want the same kind of justice that the state trooper received?  This man destroyed my family, literally, and my grandmother got no justice!!!  I appreciate your time in reading this letter and I hope I hear a response back from you as this is an important matter to me.
 
Yours Truly,
  Miranda Williams

Dear Governor,
As a member of Amnesty International , I write of my anxiety that  
Angel Nieves Diaz (m), aged 55 is facing the death penalty for a crime 
committed nearly 27 years ago. You will no doubt be aware of the 
numerous inconsistences of his trial, including the disparities in this 
case where one defendent has been sentenced to life imprisonment and 
the other sentenced to death,  and the fact that the jury in the case 
of  Angel Nieves Diaz were not unanimous in their verdict. Would you 
not agree with me that the verdict therefor must be considered unsafe.

From:	 Pam Brown (UWClub) <pambrown@uwclub.net>
Sent:	Sunday, November 26, 2006 4:33 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Governor,
I am writing to express my concern at the proposed execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, on 13th December.
 
I have the utmost sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy, who was killed in 1979, and am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused. However, I oppose the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, and would point out that there is evidence which calls into question his competency to stand trial and represent himself.
 
I would further ask you to note the disparity in sentencing in this case, with one defendant receiving a life sentence and another death, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman, and am concerned at the use of jailhouse informant testimony against Angel Diaz, a notoriously unreliable form of testimony.
 
I would point out that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty and that recent research has found serious problems with 
Florida's capital justice system, including geographic and racial disparities, and the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury 
sentencing decisions.
 
I therefore call on you as Governor to intervene to stop this execution. 
 
Yours respectfully and sincerely,
Pam Brown


From:	Michael Bechard <mbechard@uwo.ca>
Sent:	Saturday, November 25, 2006 4:25 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Angel Nieves Diaz

Governor Jeb Bush, 

The Capitol, 

400 South Monroe Street, 

Tallahassee, FL 32399, USA

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

My name is Michael Bechard.  I am a Roman Catholic priest and a professor at The University of Western Ontario in London, Ontario, Canada.  I grew up in Windsor, Ontario which is only minutes from Detroit, Michigan.  I also completed my graduate studies in the United States of America.  I have a great deal of affection for your country.

 

I am also a volunteer with Amnesty International and I write to you concerning the immanent execution of Angel Diaz.  As a fellow Christian, I implore you to stop the execution.  


The research that I have done on the matter indicates that at the time of trial that not all of the jurors voted in favour of the death penalty.  Further to this, it is a basic lack of justice to allow one defendant a life sentence while the other is given the sentence of death.  As I am sure you are likely aware, much of the evidence to convict Mr. Diaz was provided by a jail house informant.  This information coupled with statistical evidence noted elsewhere shows serious defects in Floridas capital justice system.

 

In the end, it has been proven time and time again that capital punishment does not serve as a deterrent to crime.

 

In no way do I want to downplay the seriousness of the crime.  I cannot begin to imagine the pain that Mr. Nagys friends and family must still feel.  Yet, as a Christian and a believer in the One who came to bring peace and justice through offering his life as a ransom for many we who are Christians cannot ever willingly and knowingly take the life of another.  God alone is the giver and taker of life.

 

Please do all that you can do to commute his sentence and to work towards an abolition of capital punishment in your great country.

 

Know that I will keep you and this intention in my prayers.

 

I look forward with anticipation to your response.

 

Sincerely,

 

(Rev.) Michael Bechard

Michael Bechard (Rev.)

King's University College

266 Epworth Avenue

London, Ontario

Dear Governor,


Amnesty International gave an account of Angel Nieves Diaz, who is scheduled for execution on 13 December 2006. He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979. 


I am writing to you to express my deep sympathy for the family of Joseph Nagy.


It is my opinion that no one has the right to kill another person. This also means that I strictly oppose death penalty, because no one has the right to kill another person. I want to state my unconditional opposition to the death penalty, as the ultimate cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment and violation of the right to life.


Dear Governor, I want to explain that I am not seeking to downplay the seriousness of this crime or the suffering caused, but I call on you to stop the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz, and to commute his death sentence. I also want to note that four of the jurors did not vote for the death penalty.


I thank you for your attention to this important matter.

From:	Katie Calcaterra <katie_calcaterra@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Saturday, November 25, 2006 11:58 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush

Dear Governor,

I am writing to opose the execution of Angel Nieves Diaz.

I would first like to convey my sympathy for the the family of Joseph Nagy, 
who was killed in 1979 and I am in no way trying to downplay the seriousness 
of the crime of murder or the suffering it causes.

However, I do oppose the death sentence in this case for the following 
reasons. Post conviction assessments by two mental health experts concluded 
that Angel Nieves Diaz suffers from certain mental health disorders which 
contributed to his decision to represent himself and undermined his ability 
to do so competently.

As well,  there is disparity in this case with one defendent receiving a 
life sentence and Angel Nieves Diaz the other defendent receiving the death 
penalty, despite conflicting evidence about who was the gunman.  I would 
also like to note that I have concerns about the jailhouse informant who 
testified against Angel Nieves Diaz.  Jailhouse informants are notoriously 
unreliable and should not be the only form of evidence needed to convict 
someone of the death penalty.

I would also like you to take into consideration the fact that four jurors 
voted against the death penalty.  They obviously felt that there was lack of 
evidence in this case to sentence a man to the death penalty.

I am sincerely asking that you reconsider this case and intervene to prevent 
the execution of a man who may be innocent.

Thank you

Sincerely,

Katie Calcaterra
Amnesty International

From:	Marshall, Melanie L. <Ml.Marshall@ucc.ie>
Sent:	Friday, November 24, 2006 7:16 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Don't execute Angel Nieves Diaz

Dear Governor, 

I write as the wife of a US citizen and as a frequent visitor to Florida
during my childhood (we visited Florida in October every year). I have fond
memories of your wonderful state, although I haven't had an opportunity to
visit recently.

My sympathy goes out to the family of Joseph Nagy; they have suffered a
great deal as a result of the heinous crime that was his murder in 1979. I
do not seek to downplay the seriousness of the crime, but I must oppose the
execution of Angel Nieves Diaz. The reasons for my opposition are as
follows:

1. it is questionable whether he was competent to stand trial and in
particular to represent himself, and there is evidence from his original
lawyer and others to this effect;
2. in spite of uncertainty over who was the gunman, one defendant has
received a life jail term and the other a death sentence--a great disparity
in sentencing;
3. the case relied in part upon notoriously unreliable jailhouse informant
testimony against Angel Diaz;
4. the vote for the death penatly was not unanimous--four of the jurors did
not vote for the death penalty.

Finally, as you are doubtless aware, the American Bar Association identified
serious problems with Florida's capital justice system, including geographic
and racial disparities, the lack of a requirement for unanimity in jury
sentencing decisions, and failure to give sufficient weight to mental
disability. 

I beg you, Governor, to intervene to stop this execution. 

Respectfully yours,

Dr Melanie Marshall
Department of Music
University College Cork
Cork
Ireland
From:	Michael Craig <michael@focusproductions.net>
Sent:	Friday, November 24, 2006 4:00 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	basic justice and legal integrity

TO:   Governor Jeb Bush, The Capitol,
400 South Monroe Street,
Tallahassee, FL 32399, USA




  Dear Governor,  


I am writing to ask you to intervene in the case of Angel Diaz who is scheduled for execution in Florida on 13 December 2006.   He was sentenced to death in 1986 for the murder during a robbery of bar manager Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.


This is not simply a death penalty issue where I might, as an Amnesty International member, argue against execution under any circumstances.  This case, as I read it, touches on issues of basic justice and the integrity of the American legal system.


Mr. Bush, if you or your officials study the court records of the trial and conviction of Mr. Diaz, I am sure you will see that:
a)  he "defended" himself even though, because of his lack of familiarity with court procedure and poor English skills, he was incompetent to do so;
b)  he appears to have been suffering at the time from mental illness;  and
c)  there is evidence to indicate that he was not the shooter when, during a robbery, the victim was killed.


Are these not grounds for clemency?  Do you, does America, care about basic justice -- about the right of an accused to adequate legal representation?  Will you not intervene in this situation to ensure that the justice system of Florida is seen to be fair and just?


I look forward to your answers to some of these fundamental questions.


Thank you,


Michael Craig





34 Parkdale Road

Toronto, ON.  M6R 1E2

 ph 416-533-3830      fx 416-533-3831





From:	Paul Forster <pforster@uottawa.ca>
Sent:	Friday, November 24, 2006 3:13 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Execution of Angel Diaz

 

Governor Jeb Bush, The Capitol, 

400 South Monroe Street, 

Tallahassee, FL 32399, USA

Email:   jeb.bush@myflorida.com

 

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I am a professor of philosophy at the University of Ottawa in Ottawa, Canada.  I have a strong interest in human rights issues in Canada and around the world and an active member of Amnesty International which, as you no doubt know, is a non-partisan human rights agency.  

 

I am writing to express concern about the case of Angel Nieves Diaz who is scheduled for execution on December 13, 2006 having been convicted in 1986 of murdering Joseph Nagy in Miami in 1979.  Having suffered through the death of a nephew, I have the utmost empathy for Mr Nagys family and friends.  Theirs is the sort of suffering that does not end and they are, of course, entitled to see justice done.  However, the information I have received makes me very worried that justice has not been served in the case of Mr Diaz.

 

In the first place, there is a substantial body of evidence to suggest he was not competent to stand trial and should not have been allowed to represent himself including the testimony of the lawyer charged to defend him and mental health assessments conducted after his trial. This evidence seems to have been disregarded to date. 

 

Second, the other accused person in this case, Mr. Angel Toro, pled guilty to the crime in exchange for a life sentence.  It is hard to justify a more severe sentence for Mr Diaz when there are no eye-witnesses to the shooting of Mr Nagy and conflicting evidence as to who fired the fatal shot.   (Two people in the bar testified that it was Mr. Toro, not Mr Diaz, who shot Joseph Nagy.)

 

Third, the evidence against Mr Diaz included testimony by inmates.  Study after study has shown such testimony to be unreliable.

 

Fourth, the American Bar Association has noted significant racial disparities in sentences in Florida courts.  (Mr Diaz is Puerto Rican and was forced to wear shackles throughout the trial, despite research findings suggesting this is prejudicial.)  The same report cites the failure in Florida courts to give due consideration to mental disabilities as mitigating factors in crime.  (Mr. Diaz is a victim of child abuse and has a record of mental problems.)  

 

Finally, notwithstanding all of the above, four jurors were against the sentence of death in this case.  I might add, as you know, the American Bar Association has also expressed concern that unanimity among jurors is not required in death penalty cases in Florida.

 

I have a different view of the death penalty than you do but this is not the issue I am raising here.  The issue here is whether the trial and sentencing of Mr Diaz meets the standards of justice the United States holds itself to and of which it is rightly proud.  It seems to me there is ample evidence this is not the case.  In light of this, I implore you to intervene and stop the execution of Mr Diaz on December 13th, 2006.

 

I would appreciate any further information you may have about this case.  Thank you for considering my concerns.

 

Sincerely,

 

Prof. Paul D. Forster

Department of Philosophy

University of Ottawa.

Ottawa, ON, CANADA

K1N 6N5

for doing nothing wrong and I feel that just like everyone else,  you could

days of 3 years probation, paid all fines and fees ahead of schedule, has 
done nothing against the law in all that time but regardless of the facts of 
the case, Judge OConnor sentenced him to 5 years for "willfully, violating

even my own family, being white, this would not have happened.  This young 
family is in jeopardy of losing their home and no one seems to be able to 
help.  He has a public defender for his appeal, but the appeal has somehow 
been lost, and another  lawyer for the resisting arrest as it is in another 
county.  It is a catch 22 as he would not be serving any time if he could 
appear in court in Martin County but he is in Miami. He requested a speedy 
trial, but had been unable to appear in court because he is in prison in 
another county.  Every time it comes up on the docket, he gets a bench 
warrant because he can't be there.  The judge in Broward would have to 
release him and drop the sentence if he could just appear in Martin County 
and get the charges here dropped.  Then there would be no violation of 
probation, which there never should have been any way.  It was 1:00 AM and 
they had to take him in on something until they could get it all figured 
out.  The officer told Mario that he would speak with his probation officer 
but neglected to do so.  By the time he spoke up in court, it was too late, 
as the judge was not interested in listening to reason.  As I am a white 
woman, I don't know that much about the NAACP but I have also written them 
asking for help.  This is one of those occasions that if we could just get 
someone in authority to look at this case, they would see how ridiculous it 
is before this family loses their home.  Mario has a new daughter that he 
hasn't even seen yet.  All he did was buy a boat trailer and try to show the 
officers a reciept.  There were 6 patrol cars and many officers at his house 
in the middle of the night.  His civil rights have been violated and no one 
cares.  I am so naive that I thought that because I voted for all the Bushes 
and believed in them that maybe one of them would be able to help Mario. 
This experience has been a real eye opener.  If you have any other ideas 
that may help, please write again.  I wrote Mark Foley before his problems 
began and was pleased that someone from his office called me back.  She told 
me that nothing could be done at that time as he hadn't been sentenced yet. 
At that time, we believed that justice would prevail.  What a joke.  There 
are real criminals out there all over the place but my tax dollars are 
keeping an innocent young man in prison.

Pam Twombly



----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "ptwombly" <ptwombly@bellsouth.net>
Sent: Tuesday, November 21, 2006 4:08 PM
Subject: RE: We need your help!!!


Dear Ms. Twombly:

Thank you for writing Governor Bush.  The Governor understands the pain a 
prisoner's family and friends endure and asked me to respond on his behalf.

Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to 
commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be 
addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should 
speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. If 
you need assistance in locating an attorney, contact the Florida Bar's 
Attorney Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.

Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or 
educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time 
are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  For further 
assistance, please write to Department of Corrections, 2601 Blair Stone 
Road, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2500.

The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's 
control, determines the issues of control release and early release.  The 
Commission's address is Building C, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, 
Florida  32399-2450.

Thank you again for writing.

                                                                        Sincerely,



                                                                        Warren 
Davis
                                                                        Office 
of Citizens' Services


-----Original Message-----
From: ptwombly [mailto:ptwombly@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Friday, November 17, 2006 10:41 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: We need your help!!!


Dear Mr. Bush,
I am writing to you about an injustice that involves a close family friend. 
We are so confused as to what to do now.  His name is Granville "Mario" 
Williams.  When he was 17, in June 2000, Mario made a bad decision under the 
influence of a family member to traffic in cocaine.  He was sentenced to 3 
years and then 3 years probation.  He served the 3 years in a juvenile 
facility and also did all but 6 days of his probation.  He paid all his 
fines and cost of supervision early.  Since he was released 3 years ago, he 
has attended IRCC, started several businesses, bought a house, and is a 
wonderful father to his 2 sons.  He is a bright, hard working young man and 
has totally turned his life around.  In June 2006, he bought a boat on Ebay 
and then bought a trailer to go pick it up with.  He paid for the trailer 
and got a receipt.  Upon his return from picking up the boat,  several 
Martin County Sheriffs deputies came to his house in the middle of the night 
and accused him of stealing the trailer.  He went into his van, which was 
still attached to the trailer with deputies in the boat and surrounding his 
vehicle to get the receipt.  He turned the key on to turn on the interior 
light.  A deputy tapped his flashlight on the window and told him to get out 
of the vehicle.  Mario complied with everything that was asked of him.  He 
was arrested for resisting arrest without violence.  The next day, he bonded 
out, paid to get the trailer out of impound and located the true owner of 
the trailer.  He returned it to him and offered to buy tires for the trailer 
because of the trip to NY.  The owner refused and told Mario that he knew 
that he was not involved at all.  Mario then proceeded to buy another 
trailer for his boat.  On July 1st, Mario, his pregnant fiance, his 2 sons, 
and my son were out on our boat.  Mario went a bit too fast in a no wake 
area and was pulled over by Marine patrol.  When they checked his licence, 
to everyone's surprise, there was a warrant for his arrest for violation of 
probation.  He was taken to the Martin County jail and then sent to Broward 
county.  Even though the officer testified at his trial that Mario complied 
with everything that was asked of him that night, Judge O'Connor sentenced 
him to 5 years for "willfully violating his probation".   This young man is 
an honest, hardworking member of society who tries to do everything right in 
an effort to make up for the mistake of his youth.  He only had 6 days left 
of his probation and bought a boat trailer from a boat yard here in Martin 
county.  He had no idea that it was a stolen trailer or would never have 
bought it.  We fail to understand why he has been sentenced to longer than 
his original sentence.  I truly believe that if he were not a young black 
man living in East Stuart, none of this would have happened.  He has been in 
jail for 5 months for doing nothing wrong!!!  He missed the birth of his 
daughter and his businesses have no one to run them with him gone.  At the 
present time, he is trying to appeal the sentence.  If the charges in Martin 
county are dropped then there was no violatioin of probation and the 
sentence would have to be overturned.  Now with the holidays right around 
the corner, the wheels of justice are turning slower and slower.  I have no 
doubt that if this had happened to my son, a white young man, in our 
neighborhood in Stuart, it would never have gone anywhere.  I understand 
that they wanted to bring him in until they got it all figured out as it was 
in the middle of the night, but to then keep him in prison for 5 months 
while all the ducks get put back in a row is a grave injustice.  Is there 
anyway to get this man home to his family and back to work before the 
holidays?  This is America and things like this are not supposed to happen. 
This is like some nightmare that you read about in a magazine not something 
that happens to our friends and family.  It is such a catch 22.  Mario 
requested a speedy trial but everytime it gets on the docket in Martin 
county, he is unable to be there as he is at the South Florida Reception 
Center.  His discharge date right now is 7/19/2008.  For What??? For turning 
on the key in his van to turn on the lights to find the sales receipt? 
Where was he going to flee? With deputies surrounding his vehicle and 
standing in the boat?  With his young sons and pregnant fiance in the house? 
This is so crazy.  Where is the justice for Mario?  No one that hears of 
this case can believe that he is still in prison but the end is way in the 
future.  Judge O'Connor is such an imposing woman that he had a difficult 
time finding a lawyer who would represent him in her court.  Any help that 
you can offer would be greatly appreciated. My son and I are working with 
his father to try to get his released but we keep running into brick walls. 
I just don't understand why someone doesn't see how unfair this is and just 
let him come home.  This is like every bad joke ever heard about southern 
justice.

Thank you,
Pamela Twombly
2448 SE Harrison Street
Stuart, FL 34997
772-631-9079

From:	Patricia Rowe <prowe@alachuacounty.us>
Sent:	Saturday, November 18, 2006 6:28 PM
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Help on trying to clarify some adoption laws.

Dear Governor Bush,

                                   My name is Patricia Rowe and I have
an inter family adoption situation and I'm not sure who
to turn to for help.  On November 22, 1996, my neice Michelle Lynn
Hoffman gave birth to a little girl named Elin.  my neice and Elin's
father were not married.  On December 27, 1998 my neice passed away.  My
sister, who is my neice's mother and her husband, my neices step-father
adopted Elin to keep her in the family.  Soon after the adoption my
sister and her husband serparated.  My sister, Elin, and my sister's
yougest son, came to live with my boys and I.  They lived with me from
November of 2000 till April of 2002.  In April of 2002 they moved out. 
On June 13th, 2002 my sister took her life and Elin and my youngest
nephew came back to live with me.  Elin lived with me untill June of
2004, when her adopted father asked to have her for the summer.  He was
64 years old, found out he cancer, and wanted to spend the summer with
Elin.  He had just gotten remarried. His wife was 65 almost 66 at the
time.  He assured me that he would bring Elin back to me at the end of
the summer.  My family, (my mom,Elin's biological great-grandmother, my
nephew, Elin's biological uncle and myself her biological great-aunt)
went to a family attorney to find out if we had any rights to her.  We
were told that as long as he was alive, we had no rights to her because
he was her legal father, but that if he passed away we could have her
back because we are blood family.  I asked the attorney if he could have
his new wife adopt Elin and the attorney said no not with out the
families' permission.  Elin's adopted father passed away the day after
Thanksgiving 2005 and my family hired an attorney to try to get Elin
back, we found out that he had his wife adopt her.  So we hired another
attorney and tried to get the adoption over turned.  During that process
we found out that Elin's adoptive father lied on his petition to have
his new wife adopt Elin.  He claimed to be the b iological grand-father
and made no mention of Elin having any other biological family.  Eveen
on the paper work thst he had to fill out on where Elin had lived of the
five years,from 2000-2005)  who she lived with, and whatr relation they
were to her, he failed to mention that we were biological.  The judge
that handled the adoption, retired in Feb. of 2006, we tried to get be
fore him to have him over turn the adoption but he retired befor we
could get a court date.  The new judge would not over turn the adoption,
and no attorney will take the appeals because there is no trans-script
of the hearing.  Attornies havee speculated that the judge ruled the way
he did based on misinformation but with out a trans-scripted no one can
be sure.  So we arewith out Elin and can not see.  He adopted mother
will not allow us to even though we were the only family she knew for
the first seven years of her life.  

Whjat I would like your help with is who do I get in touch with or how
dio I go about getting inter family adoption laws changed or clarrifed? 
This should not be aloud to happen to any other child or family.  I'm
not trying to change regular adoption laws,just inter family.  In a case
like this her blood family should have standing, because we are her
blood.  Yet I was told I didn't have standing because I wasn't her
mother or father.  My sister adopted EWlin to keep her with her blood
family.  I don't think this is right or fair to Elin or my family.  If
you can assist me with any informationor stear me in the fight direction
I would greatly appreciate it.  This law need to be clarified.  I hope I
made myself clear.

Thank you for your time in reading this lette, and thank you for the
years you have spent as our Governor.

Sincerly, Patricia L. Rowe
