From:	Etienne, Jessie <JEtienne2@um-jmh.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, November 15, 2006 1:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Death Row and Health Care.doc

Dear Governor Jeb Bush, 

 

I was assigned a project in my Health Law Class that would address a legal issue along with five questions to ask a local or state official. I chose you as the state official and I would appreciate if you would immediately address the five questions listed below for completion of this assignment.  Below are some facts that I have researched to provide you with an overall understanding of my assignment. Thank you in advance for your immediate response.

 

1.	According to the U.S. Surgeon General, one in five Americans suffer from a mental illness.

 

2.	Since 1983, over 60 people with mental illness or retardation have been executed in the United States; 283,000 in 1998 were incarcerated in U.S. jails and prisons. 

 

3.	It is estimated that 10% of death row inmates suffer from serious mental illness.

 

4.	Only a third of mental health illnesses are treated in Americans in the United States.

 

5.	Many of these offenders are poor, uneducated and lack insurance coverage and are Due to the budget cut in mental health services, they limit accessibility to the necessary drugs for treatment of those illnesses.

 

Questions

1.	What is the best argument for the death penalty and is it without error? 

 

2.	Does evidence imply that the death penalty deters murder more than any form of punishment by law? 

 

3.	How much discretion should be given to states to determine whether an individual is "mentally retarded", and therefore protected against infliction of death penalty under Atkins v Virginia?
4.	Due to the reduction/lack of mental health care services, do you believe that this has consequently provoked unnecessary murders and suicides that could have been prevented?

 

5.	Are the conditions of correctional facilities deplorable? If so, have those conditions inhibit poor health among inmates in the institutions of Florida?

>From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
>To: "Joan Drolle" <jdrolle@hotmail.com>
>Subject: RE: A moment if you please
>Date: Thu, 9 Nov 2006 12:55:49 -0500
>
>Dear Ms. Drolle:
>
>Thank you for your e-mail to Governor Bush.  The Governor understands your 
>concern and has asked me to respond.
>
>The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that 
>should be resolved through the court system.  If you are unhappy with a 
>ruling or feel a case has not been handled according to the law, you should 
>speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available.  
>For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services or the county 
>legal aid association has information about the availability of pro bono 
>counsel.  The main telephone number of Florida Legal Services is (850) 
>385-7900.  Those dissatisfied with their representatives should consider 
>choosing another attorney.
>
>Although the Governor appreciates the opportunity to review your concerns, 
>this is a local government matter.  As you may know, our government is 
>structured on the notion that local communities can best assess the needs 
>of their residents.  You would do well to continue to work with your 
>locally elected officials to resolve this problem.
>
>If Governor Bush can help you with a concern in the area of state 
>government, please let him know.
>
>						Sincerely,
>
>
>
>						Warren Davis
>						Office of Citizens' Services
>

Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to

addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings

On 11/7/06, Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@myflorida.com> wrote: 

Dear Ms. Mullen:

Thank you for your letter regarding a Florida criminal case.  Governor Bush is sorry to learn of your concerns. 

Each state attorney is an elected official charged with certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether or not to prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction.  This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt shown, and in the best interest of justice.  Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. 

Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's control, determines the issues of control release and early release. 

The clemency function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to await the outcome of court appeals.  For more information, you can write the Office of Executive Clemency at Building C, Room 229, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450. 

Thank you again for writing.

                                                                       Sincerely,



                                                                       Warren Davis 
                                                                       Office of Citizens' Services

From: Jean Mullen [mailto:jean.mullen@gmail.com ]
Sent: Monday, November 06, 2006 4:53 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:


Dear Governor:

I am a mother of an eleven year old boy. A boy who is warm and caring. He is blessed to have love from two committed parents & we are blessed to have him. As you know, pre-teen and teen years can be so disarming - sometimes children make bad decisions. It's our job to make sure he makes good choices. A couple of years ago - when he was nine - he and another boy were playing 'sword fighting' with palm fronds from a tree. My son hit & damaged a growing tree in a neighbors backyard. The neighbor yelled at my boy, banned him from her yard, instructed him never to play with her children again. She never mentioned this to me or my husband. My boy kept this to himself for 2 months, the entire summer. One day we were riding in the car & he asked 'If someone did something very bad & kept it secret, would you forgive him for not telling the truth?'. He started telling me the story of the Star Wars battle of the palm fronds. 

I learned that day - that I hadn't taught him to confide in me immediately. That sometimes bad decisions are made (in this case  - the palm frond battle) - but you should count to ten, catch your breath & go get mom or dad. We can't fix everything - but as adults, we have had to make a lot more decisions than a boy and we can get through whatever it is together. He would have received punishment,  we could have replaced the baby tree. He didn't have to be chastised by the neighbor family for the entire summer. 

We have spent many hours since that day talking about decision making and consequences. I have talked with my boy about Josh Phillips. Josh was just a boy, who initially just made a bad decision. When he first hurt Maddie with the ball - he should have told a parent. He needed to slow down, and get help. Instead he made a child's decision. A child's decision that ended her life and ended his childhood  forever. 

We, as a society have failed Josh. We decided that he was an adult, we punished him as an adult. We sent him to live the rest of his life as an adult with adult prisoners.

Josh was 14, not an adult. Josh did not make an adult decision. An adult would not have hidden her under his bed. 

Now it is time for us to act like adults. Act like parents of a society that has made a wrong decision and correct it. Josh needs to be punished - but as a child - not as an adult. You have the power to do this. I implore you to do the right thing - make it easier for us to sleep tonight, knowing that we have not failed another child. I believe in you -  I know that you will make the right decision for all of us. 

Sincerely,

Jean Mullen

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, November 07, 2006 10:10 AM
To: pg reception
Subject: RE: Help

Dear Ms. Esposito:

Thank you for writing Governor Bush.  The Governor understands the pain a
prisoner's family and friends endure and asked me to respond on his behalf.
Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or
educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time
are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  For further
assistance, please write to Department of Corrections, 2601 Blair Stone
Road, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2500.
 
The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's
control, determines the issues of control release and early release.  The
Commission's address is Building C, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee,
Florida  32399-2450.
 
Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to
commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be
addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should
speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. I
understand this case is currently in the appeals process.  If you are
dissatisfied with the legal counsel representing your husband and need
assistance in locating an attorney, contact the Florida Bar's Attorney
Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.
 
The Governor has no independent ability to pardon someone. The clemency
function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's
civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these
lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with
the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected
officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to
await the outcome of court appeals.  For more information, you can write the
Office of Executive Clemency at Building C, Room 229, 2601 Blair Stone Road,
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450.
 
Thank you again for writing.
 
 
Sincerely,
 
 
 
 
Warren Davis
 
Office of Citizens' Services

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: killen04 
Sent: Tuesday, October 31, 2006 2:14 PM
Subject: RE: Please Read! Thank you!

Dear Friend:
 
Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush about someone facing criminal charges.  He understands the pain friends and family experience in these situations and asked me to respond.

 

As you may know, the decision to charge a person for crimes is made by the state attorney, a locally elected official.  Deciding whether or not to charge a person is based on the best interests of justice and on the quantity and quality of the evidence of criminal activity.

 

The Florida Constitution limits the Governors intervention in matters that should be resolved through the court system.  If you believe a person is innocent, or not guilty of all charges, you may wish to obtain the services of an attorney experienced in criminal defense. If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bars Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  

 

Those who are facing criminal charges for which prison time is a possibility, may be appointed an attorney by the court.  For further assistance in this regard, please contact the office of your locally elected public defender.  Please be sure the attorney is provided with all of the evidence you believe shows innocence.

 

The Governor trusts justice will be served in this case.

 

                                                                        Sincerely,

 

 

 

                                                                        Warren Davis

                                                                        Office of Citizens Services

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Monday, October 30, 2006 3:52 PM
To: Ivette Medina
Subject: RE: 

Dear Ms. Medina:

Thank you for your recent e-mail to Governor Bush requesting assistance with a child support matter.  He has asked me to respond.
 
The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that should be resolved through the court system.  The person who can best answer your legal questions is an attorney.  If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  Those who have limited financial resources should consider contacting their local legal aid office or foundation.
 
As you may know, the Florida Department of Revenue is the state agency that houses the Child Support Enforcement Program.  This agency is responsible for establishing paternity, enforcing child support obligations, and locating non-custodial parents.  Enforcement tools include: wage withholding, contempt of court, interception of unemployment benefits, IRS refunds, and lottery winnings, and liens on personal property and real estate.
 
You may wish to contact this agency at your earliest convenience to inquire what methods are available to enforce the court ordered payment of child support.  Please call your local branch offices for the Department of Revenue.  That number can be found in your local telephone book or by calling directory assistance.  If you need immediate assistance, please contact the state offices for the Department of Revenue at (850) 922-9590.
 
Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.  Please know this is due to lack of jurisdiction, not lack of concern.
 
Sincerely,
 
Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Melba Mauldin 
Sent: Monday, October 30, 2006 9:05 AM
Subject: RE: Will you please help?

Dear Ms. Mauldin:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush to share your concerns about a friend's legal situation.  The Governor is sorry to learn of her difficulty, and has asked me to respond on his behalf.
 
The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that should be resolved through the court system.  Governor Bush does not have legal jurisdiction to intervene in dissolutions of marriage or child custody cases.  

The person who can best answer your friend's legal questions is an attorney.  If your friend needs assistance in locating an attorney, please have her call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services and your friend's local legal aid office have information about the availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number for Florida Legal Services is 850-385-7900.
 
Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems your friend is facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.  Please feel free to forward this information to your friend at your convenience.
 
                                                                        Sincerely,
 
 
 
                                                                        Warren Davis
                                                                        Office of Citizens' Services
 
 
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Melba Mauldin [mailto:mjoymauldin@msn.com]
Sent: Friday, October 27, 2006 6:43 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Will you please help?


Hello Governor Bush:

I am actually a resident of Colorado.  My husband and I are Republican and we support your brother, George W. Bush 100%.  My husband and I have raised two beautiful daughters.  Both of them graduated from colleges in Florida.  Our youngest daughter, Holly Mauldin Filer, is now a High School Physical Education teacher in St. Petersburg, Florida.  Recently, I visited my daughter in Florida.  While attending a volleyball tournament, of which  Holly's team was playing in, I met one of the team players mother.

Here is my request.  I am so burdened for this woman, and she is struggling to find help for herself and for her daughter.  I am repeating to you some of the information that this woman shared with me, because of her fear, her frustration and her lack of ability to take on the judicial system of which her husband is a part of.   This woman was married to a man who is a prominent lawyer in the Clearwater, Tampa area.  She was married for thirty some years.  She has been a "stay at home" mother and her husband took care of all financial matters for the family.  

According to this mother, her husband of some thirty years had an affair and is asking her for a divorce.  Now, this matter is directly between them, and I understand that.  However, a real injustice has occurred for this woman in the judicial system in Florida for the following reasons:  According to the information supplied to me by this woman the following has happened to her.

    1.  Her husband and his law firm partner have both divorced their wives and have successfully hidden funds (their monthly earnings) from their former wives.  Leaving them with only the $4,000 dollars a month income ordered by the court.  She has no ability to get to what was once their savings accounts or checking account money.

    2.  This woman's husband has been ordered to pay for her attorney, and has not done so.  She has lost three attorney's to represent her because he will not pay the money for the lawyers up front and so they drop her case.  She also feels that these attorneys drop her case because of intimidation by her lawyer/husband towards these attorneys.

    3.  The last attorney was going to ask the present judge presiding over this case to remove himself from the case because of personal ties to the husband/lawyer.  However, because the attorney had not been paid, (in which the husband was required to pay) she dropped the case and did not file the needed papers in the allotted time to have this judge removed from the case.

   There are many, many more issues at hand for this woman and her family.  She has raised two sons and has their third child, a daughter still in High School.  She is responsible for the financial burden of raising this daughter based on the amount of money that her husband/the lawyer gives to her.  None of the children want anything to do with their father.  He is angry with the wife and the children and is making their lives miserable by withholding funds for their care.  The judge sits back and does not make him follow through with his responsibilities.  She states that at a couple of the hearings he has been allowed to talk to the judge and when she tries the judge cuts her off.

My question and request to you is this:  

    1.    This woman has no money, because her husband has total control of all funds

    2.    This woman cannot get representation because her husband/a lawyer has
           intimidated each lawyer she has hired and then he does not pay them for
           her representation (per the judges instruction)

    3.    This woman cannot get a lawyer to take her case pro bono and none will take
           her case without $10,000 dollars of money up front.  (She can't get money from
           her husband, and he refuses to pay her lawyers.  The judge sits back and does
           nothing.

In your state, who is there to protect the woman (a stay at home mother) that hasn't worked for over thirty years, has no money and has to battle a legal system of which her husband is a part of and his actions of intimidation and "good ole boy" club is preventing her from getting legal and fair representation.

To whom, in your state of Florida, can this woman turn to for for help and for a fair and just hearing in this divorce proceeding?  The legal system in your state is failing her and her husband is using his position as a lawyer, to manipulate the system, the other lawyers involved, and the legal process.   She stated to me that a criminal is afforded legal representation (at no cost) otherwise known as a "public defender", but a stay at home mother, who has not worked, has no money, no representation and no "public defender" available to her.

Will you please contact this woman at: NancyFuller@juno.com with information of where she can go for help, legal advice and financial support to equip her with the legal defense she needs to represent her side of the story and her children.

I normally do not get involved in situations like this, but this woman has lived in a lifestyle where her husband was bringing in 20,000 dollars a month.  He now gives her $4,000 dollars a month and expects her to still care for her high school daughter, make the house payment on the existing home that they have lived in for years, and this money is suppose to cover all up-keep and utilities expenses. 

This case needs to be looked into to make sure that the judicial process is not corrupt and that a woman who is having to depend upon the judicial system in which her husband, as a lawyer, is a part of, is not being unethical.

Will you PLEASE help this woman by placing her in touch with the proper individuals that can help her and investigate this situation.

I respectfully place my request for your help in this matter.  This is a matter of integrity and a case where the judicial system needs to be monitored to make sure that each citizen is given a fair and equal voice in an unfortunate divorce case.

Thank you in advance for your help to this woman, Nancy Fuller and I trust that your office will conduct a proper and legal investigation into this matter.

Kindest Regards,

Melba J. Mauldin
2210 So. DeVinney Street
Lakewood, CO  80228
(303)986-3870
mjoymauldin@msn.com

>From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
>To: "deborah fulton" <familyfulton@msn.com>
>Subject: RE: Please save my family
>Date: Fri, 27 Oct 2006 11:02:11 -0400
>
>Dear Ms. Fulton:
>
>Thank you for writing Governor Bush.  The Governor understands the pain a 
>prisoner's family and friends endure and asked me to respond on his behalf. 
>  Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or 
>educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time 
>are under the authority of the Department of Corrections.  For further 
>assistance, please write to Department of Corrections, 2601 Blair Stone 
>Road, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2500.
>
>The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's 
>control, determines the issues of control release and early release.  The 
>Commission's address is Building C, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, 
>Florida  32399-2450.
>
>Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to 
>commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be 
>addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should 
>speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. If 
>you need assistance in locating an attorney, contact the Florida Bar's 
>Attorney Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.
>
>The Governor has no independent ability to pardon someone. The clemency 
>function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's 
>civil rights, or commute punishment.  There are complicated rules for these 
>lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with 
>the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected 
>officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to 
>await the outcome of court appeals.  For more information, you can write 
>the Office of Executive Clemency at Building C, Room 229, 2601 Blair Stone 
>Road, Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2450.
>
>Thank you again for writing.
>
>						Sincerely,
>
>
>
>						Warren Davis
>						Office of Citizens' Services
>
>

> From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
> Date: 2006/10/26 Thu PM 02:34:01 EDT
> To: <durra300@bellsouth.net>
> Subject: RE: [*] Re: Re: please help my grandchildren
> 
> Dear Ms. Durrant:
> 
> Thank you for writing to Governor Bush regarding grandparents' rights.  The Governor has asked that I respond on his behalf.  
> 
> Current policy in Florida is for families to resolve differences over grandparents' visitation within the family.  When families are unable to resolve grandparent visitation differences, the family should participate in any formal or informal mediation services that may be available.  If a petition is filed due to unresolved differences, the court must refer the case to family mediation in accordance with rules promulgated by the Supreme Court.
> 
> The Florida Supreme Court ruled against past legislation introduced regarding grandparents rights, holding that there is an inherent problem in permitting governmental interference into a family's private life on a threshold finding of the best interest of the child when there is no demonstration of harm to the child's health or welfare.  Despite the potential benefits to preserving the familial bond between grandparents and grandchildren, there is no compelling state interest which would warrant government intervention in parental privacy rights to rear children.
> 
> Custody and visitation rulings are under the jurisdiction of the judicial system.  Under Florida law, the court's decision in these cases is based on the best interest of the child or children involved.  Judges review all of the information presented to them and apply the law to make their decision.
> 
> The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that should be resolved through the court system.  If you are unhappy with a ruling or feel a case has not been handled according to the law, you should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services or the county legal aid association has information about the availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number of Florida Legal Services is (850) 385-7900.  Those dissatisfied with their representatives should consider choosing another attorney.
> 
> To further assist you in this regard, I am forwarding a copy of your e-mail to the Florida Department of Children and Families for their review.
> 
> Again, thank you for writing on this very important issues. 
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> 
> 
> Warren Davis
> Office of Citizens' Services
>

>From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
>Reply-To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
>To: "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
>Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, October 20, 2006
>Date: Fri, 20 Oct 2006 15:17:11 -0400
>
>For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
>Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
>
>http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
>
>The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
>
>
>FLORIDA RECEIVES $33 MILLION FOR STRENGTHENING FAMILIES
>
>On Monday, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings announced the U.S. Department of
>Health and Human Services' Administration for Children and Families awarded
>nearly $33 million to 13 organizations in Florida for services to help
>strengthen Florida's families during the next five years. Lt. Governor
>Jennings was joined by U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Deputy
>Secretary Alex M. Azar II and Florida Department of Children and Families
>Secretary Lucy Hadi to award the grants, totaling $6.6 million this fiscal
>year, for services aimed at keeping Florida families healthy and secure.
>Florida's grant awards went to ten programs to promote healthy marriage and
>three programs to promote responsible fatherhood, providing 13 
>organizations
>across the state with additional funding for education, outreach and
>awareness activities.  Florida is among the top three states in the nation
>in total grant dollars, along with California and Texas.  For more
>information on the Florida Department of Children and Families'
>Strengthening Families Initiative, please visit www.floridafamilies.org.
>
>
>NATIONAL HURRICANE CENTER DIRECTOR MAX MAYFIELD HONORED
>
>On Tuesday, members of the Florida Cabinet and I passed a resolution
>honoring the more than 30 years of public service by Max Mayfield, director
>of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) National
>Hurricane Center located in Miami.  Director Mayfield, who has led the
>National Hurricane Center since January 2000, will retire at the end of 
>this
>year. Director Mayfield's career of service and leadership has resulted in
>improved forecasts, enhanced warning coordination and increased
>preparedness.  Mayfield came to the National Hurricane Center in 1972,
>following a 2-year stint as a forecaster with the U.S. Air Force.  He has
>served the National Hurricane Center in various professional capacities,
>rising from the position of Satellite Meteorologist through the ranks to 
>the
>position of Deputy Director in 1998, then Director in 2000. Early in his
>career, Max recognized that the battle against hurricanes is won outside of
>hurricane season.  He has successfully developed the annual 'hurricane
>hunter' preparedness tours, visiting vulnerable locations along the United
>States and Caribbean coasts to educate residents on the dangers of severe
>tropical events.  For more information on hurricane preparedness, please
>visit: www.Floridadisaster.org.
>
>
>FLORIDA BUSINESSES ENCOURAGED TO HIRE PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES
>
>On Wednesday, business and government leaders across Florida joined persons
>with disabilities in recognizing Disability Mentoring Day.  Part of 
>National
>Disability Employment Awareness Month, the event brings together community
>business leaders as mentors to persons with disabilities interested in
>exploring employment opportunities. The mentor/mentee relationships help
>break down barriers to employment while educating employers on the
>contributions persons with disabilities make to the workplace. As mentors,
>the Lt. Governor and I know firsthand the enrichment that comes from 
>sharing
>work experiences with an individual who is anxious to join Florida's 
>growing
>workforce.  Nationally, Florida has been recognized for initiatives
>encouraging employers to recruit, hire and train persons with disabilities.
>Persons with disabilities have on average a 65 percent unemployment rate
>while two-thirds of those who are unemployed would prefer to work. For more
>information on hiring qualified workers with disabilities, visit
>http://apd.myflorida.com.
>
>
>POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO BETTY JO KNOTT
>
>Congratulations!
>
>To read more about this week's winner, please click here:
>http://www.flgov.com/release/8285

I'm no genious, I'm a mom and a wife of twenty five years. My public servants have failed me and my family. Why make it illegal to run up liens in one companies name, transfer all it's assets into a brand new companies name without the liens on paper, sell the same hundreds of thousands of dollars in assets that don't disclose those liens to a third company, take the money and pay the federal government becuase they have assessed a 117000 tax lien on this person from his last wheelings and dealings. No we are not big busineess people andmabie not smart enough to know! how to be a lawyer but we had over 70 employees and 40 small business vendors and all of us were paying alot of taxes. I wish I could make it more complicated but the truth is our property was transfered with paper, out of our name with no notice or disclosures, no filings, no liens, no mortgages, no late fees...don't you find that odd? Don't you think if there was a real reason that we would know it? Do't you think with the thousands of bank regulations that someone would have called us and said, ok, dumb people the law says this and this is what happened to you and these are your options...right? If a lawyer calls them and says yes it's criminal to transfer real estate with liens on it to another companies name without paying the liens (DUH) or disclosing or paying THE OWNERS (DUH). Now the lien holders are comming to get all the resteraunts equipment right while it's making folks lunch! What i! s this guy saying? Not much. His name is Howard Shane Shafer.
Call the last two victems, my family was number one we think...904-874-4504 is victem number Basil Chandler two-Shafer took the tranferred and refinanced real property amd assets/equipment and so it looked like it was free and clear, not complicated, just crooked, Shafer got all his and his brothers money and now the lien hlders are coming to get the equipment, our equipment that Shafer stole from us after refinancing it and transferring it into his name and selling it free and clear, then Al Ridreguis- ex-bank examiner has put down 10,000 to buy said same equipment AGAIN but got lucky and connected the dots but has yet to get his deposit back.
An us...the ones who the equipment belongs to and we own and we never ever gave it away or sold it. From:	Russ Eanes <russeanes@atlanticbb.net>
Sent:	Friday, October 20, 2006 8:40 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Arthur Dennis Rutherford

Dear Warren,
Thank you for writing back.
Please mention to the governor that while it may appear that while "Governor Bush shares the concerns of many that the death penalty must be reserved for only the most heinous cases." it should be noted that it never is efficacious. There is no evidence that the death penalty is a deterrent to crime and there is strong evidence that it may have the opposite effect. While I appreciate the Governor's concern for victims, it is also true that execution is basically a form of vengeance on the part of the state and it rarely brings closure to the suffering of victims.
Respectfully,

Pastor Russ Eanes
russeanes@atlanticbb.net


We cannot love God unless we love each other. We know him in the breaking of bread, and we know each other in the breaking of bread, and we are not alone anymore. Heaven is a banquet and life is a banquet too, even with a crust, where there is companionship. 
-Dorothy Day


On Oct 18, 2006, at 5:20 PM, Governor Jeb Bush wrote:



Dear Friend:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush about a death row inmate.  The Governor appreciates your  concerns and asked me to respond on his behalf.
 
Governor Bush believes that the death penalty is appropriate and warranted in certain capital murder cases, and supports its use by the courts in those cases.  The Governor also believes we should look not only to the issues surrounding the defendant, but also to the surviving victims, and to the effect the murder has on our community as a whole, in deciding whether the death penalty is an appropriate punishment.
 
Florida law provides numerous levels of appeals for the convicted individual before the sentence is moved.  Once a person is convicted of an aggravated first-degree murder and sentenced to death in Florida, the state voluntarily provides free legal representation to the convicted murderer until the sentence is carried out or reduced on appeal.  No other state has invested the public resources in capital post conviction legal representation that Florida has been providing for well over a decade.
 
Governor Bush shares the concerns of many that the death penalty must be reserved for only the most heinous cases.  As the Governor has said many times, the signing of a death warrant is one of the most solemn and somber responsibilities he must undertake, and he does so with humble deliberation.
 
Again, thank you for taking the time to write about this very serious issue.
 
Sincerely,
 
Warren Davis
Office of Citizens Services

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Naomi Blom" <kittyblom@ntlworld.com>
Sent: Wednesday, October 18, 2006 4:40 PM
Subject: RE: [*] Fw: Emailing: IMG003, IMG004, IMG005


Dear Mr. Blom:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush.  The Governor is sorry to learn of 
your concerns, and has asked me to respond.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that 
should be resolved through the court system.  I understand you obtained 
legal counsel to assist you in this regard.  That was the appropriate thing 
to do and I encourage you to continue working with your legal counsel to 
resolve this situation to your satisfaction.  If you are dissatisfied with 
your attorney need assistance in locating another attorney, please call the 
Florida Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to 
afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services or your local legal aid office has 
information about the availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone 
number for Florida Legal Services is 850-385-7900.

For further assistance, you may wish to contact the Florida Department of 
Health whose Division of Medical Quality Insurance regulates health care 
practitioners including doctors and nurses.  The Florida Department of 
Health also reviews and responds to complaints against health care 
practitioners and determines whether complaints warrant investigation.  I 
encourage you to contact this state agency in writing at 4052 Bald Cypress 
Way, Bin #A00, Tallahassee, Florida, 32399-1701 or by calling (850) 
245-4321.

Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems 
you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.

Sincerely,



Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

Dear Mr Bush

My husband and I were on L1 and L2 Visas respectively whilst residing in
Florida.

We are now living back in the UK having set up our internet bulb company in
the USA.  We have been in business since 1860  and supply many members of
the British Aristocracy, not to mention supplying historic houses etc. in
the UK.

Whilst being treated at Celebration Hospital over three and a half years ago
my wife was subjected to extreme cruelty.  I contacted Pat Hall and also
engaged the well respected firm of Bogin, Munns and Munns to deal with this
matter.

Too date this matter has not been resolved, although we now live in the UK,
as Bogin, Munns and Munns decided to drop the case.

My wife, Naomi Blom suffers from panic attacks and was on the drug Xanax, at
the time she took 10 X 2mg of these tablets, she was extremely anxious, as
her best friend in Malaysia had just died and on the same day discovered
from her mother in the UK that her father had cancer.  She panicked, after
taking these tablets and I immediately took her to ER at Celebration
Hospital ( at this conjesture, I must add that she had afull unopened bottle
of 100 X 2mg of this drug, so, obviously her intention was not to kill
herself).  We have three boys whom we both love dearly.

I am sending you these photographs of her hand, where an orderly grabbed her
whilst I was out of the hospital trying to reach the British Embassy,  the
incident with the ordrly left her hand disfigured, not to mention the severe
PTSD she still suffers.  I thought that you should be aware of this incident
as it happened in your State.  Pat Hall has always been and continues to be
most supportive of both myself and my wife.

Whilst writing, I must congratulate you on the high standards of education
in Osceola County, our children flourished whilst they were there, in
particular my eldest son Chris, who took part in band and had the
opportunity to play at Disneyworld.  He is now studying A Levels here and
hopes to be able to attend medical School in New York.
The hospitality we received from your fellow citizens was fantastic and we
were very sorry to have to leave when business brought us back to the UK.

By nature, we are Conservative and therefore Republicans.
Your brother, The President is doing a fantastic job, it's a pity that more
world leaders do not have his strength and absolute resolve.

I am sorry that I have had to contact you with regard to this, however would
not like this sort of incident to occur to anyone else.

Yours most sincerely

Paul Blom

From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, October 18, 2006 1:29 PM
To: edavis103@cfl.rr.com
Subject: RE: Help

 

Dear Mr. Davis:

 

Governor Bush received your e-mail and asked me to respond on his behalf.

 

Unfortunately, the Governor's Office has no jurisdiction over matters in the criminal justice system.  You may need the services of an attorney.  

If you need assistance in locating a lawyer, please call the Florida Bar's Attorney Referral Service toll-free at 1-800-342-8011.  

 

Those who cannot afford attorney's fees, but are facing criminal charges for which prison time is a possibility, are appointed an attorney, free of charge, by the court. 

 

Thank you for writing and I hope this matter can be resolved.

 

Sincerely,

 

Rex T. Newman

Citizens' Services

> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
> To: "Robert & Michele" <fourbear@earthlink.net>
> Sent: Tuesday, October 10, 2006 9:39 AM
> Subject: RE: Serious concerns and questions
>
>
> Dear Ms. Ripley:
>
> Thank you for writing to Governor Bush.  The Governor appreciates your 
> questions and asked me to respond on his behalf.
>
> The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in criminal 
> court cases.  Each state attorney is an elected official charged with 
> certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to 
> prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction. 
> This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of 
> guilt shown, and in the best interest of justice.  I understand you 
> directed your questions regarding a criminal case to the state attorney's 
> office and you are dissatisfied with their response, however, that is the 
> office that has legal jurisdiction in this regard.  For further 
> assistance, the person who can best answer your legal questions is an 
> attorney.  An attorney is also the one you should speak with regarding the 
> cancellation of your license. If you need assistance in locating an 
> attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 
> 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal 
> Services or your local legal aid office has information about the 
> availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number for Florida 
> Legal Services is 850-385-7900.
>
> To further assist you in this regard, I am forwarding a copy of your 
> e-mail to the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles for 
> their review.  Should you wish to contact that agency directly, please use 
> the contact information provided below.
>
> Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the 
> problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.

-----Original Message-----
>From: Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
>Sent: Oct 18, 2006 11:24 AM
>To: naplesbob1@earthlink.net
>Subject: RE: Injustice
>
>Dear Mr. Jenkins:
>
>Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush about someone facing criminal charges.  He understands the pain friends and family experience in these situations and asked me to respond.
> 
>As you may know, the decision to charge a person for crimes is made by the state attorney, a locally elected official.  Deciding whether or not to charge a person is based on the best interests of justice and on the quantity and quality of the evidence of criminal activity.
> 
>The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that should be resolved through the court system.  If you believe a person is innocent, or not guilty of all charges, you may wish to obtain the services of an attorney experienced in criminal defense. If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  
> 
>Those who are facing criminal charges for which prison time is a possibility, may be appointed an attorney by the court.  For further assistance in this regard, please contact the office of your locally elected public defender.  Please be sure the attorney is provided with all of the evidence you believe shows innocence.
> 
>The Governor trusts justice will be served in this case.
> 
>                                                                        Sincerely,
> 
> 
> 
>                                                                        Warren Davis
>                                                                        Office of Citizens' Services
>

From:	Sherri <SStanleyHufford@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Saturday, October 14, 2006 8:42 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] RE: [*] Please help us regarding a family who has been displaced due to unfair laws - RE:  Mary Nemeth

If Governor Bush read the letter, he will see that she does have an
attorney.  The problem we are facing is he is unable to get a court date
until February 6, 2007. 

It is unfortunate that she has had to leave her home that she is buying,
without any help from her ex-boyfriend.  But the ex-boyfriend gets to live
in the home and accrue the bills that she has to pay for.

They have a son together and she has a 17 year old daughter.  The three of
them are now residing in my home since August 5, 2006.  

How can the laws allow him to remain in her home and her and her children
homeless?  Why is it up to me and my family to have to take care of them
when this isn't our problem?  Why can't the court system do an emergency
hearing to get her back in her home prior to February 6, 2007?

Even her attorney doesn't understand why he can't get a hearing sooner than
that.

I understand Governor Bush is busy, but this is a law that is in place in
Florida that needs to be looked at.  There should be times that the court
system can make special circumstances to arrange an emergency hearing
instead of making people go homeless for six (6) months before getting a
court date.  

I hope that Governor Bush would take a few minutes out of his busy schedule
just to see if he can have any input in helping her get her date moved up.

Thank you again for taking the time to look into this matter,

Sherri Stanley-Hufford

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Friday, October 13, 2006 2:15 PM
To: Sherri
Subject: RE: [*] Please help us regarding a family who has been displaced
due to unfair laws - RE: Mary Nemeth

Dear Ms. Stanley-Hufford:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush about a legal problem your
sister-in-law is facing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of her difficulty,
and has asked me to respond.
 
The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that
should be resolved through the court system.  The person who can best answer
your sister-in-law's legal questions is an attorney.  If she needs
assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral
Service at 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida
Legal Services or your local legal aid office has information about the
availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number for Florida
Legal Services is 850-385-7900.
 
Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems
your sister-in-law is facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.  
 
 
Sincerely,
 
 
 
 
Warren Davis
 
Office of Citizens' Services
 
 
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Sherri [mailto:SStanleyHufford@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Wednesday, October 11, 2006 10:59 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush; stat.rev@leg.state.fl.us; leg.info@leg.state.fl.us;
andercrenshaw@mail.house.gov; john.mica@mail.house.gov;
bill.mccollum@mail.house.gov; Bill.Young@mail.house.gov;
ask.adam@mail.house.gov; katherine.harris@mail.house.gov;
alcee.pubhastings@mail.house.gov
Subject: [*] Please help us regarding a family who has been displaced due to
unfair laws - RE: Mary Nemeth


October 11, 2006
 
 
To All Florida Congressmen/Congresswomen
 
RE:  Mary Nemeth
 
Dear Congressmen and Congresswomen:
 
My name is Sherri Stanley-Hufford.  I am writing this letter to all of you
in hopes you may be able to help my sister-in-law, Mary Nemeth.
 
Mary has been purchasing a home in Merritt Island for over six (6) years
now.  She was residing there with her boy friend Sean Finnegan, her daughter
Tiffany Nemeth, and her son Sean Finnegan Jr.
 
During the past two (2) years, Mary has been sleeping on her couch while her
boy friend took over her bedroom.  Their relationship has not been a boy
friend/girl friend relationship for over two (2) years.  Mary has asked Sean
Sr. to move out of the house many times, but he would not leave.
 
Sean Sr. has not been helping Mary financially for many, many years.  Mary
has been the sole provider for the entire family.
 
At the end of July, Mary went to the court house in Viera to get an
Injunction to be served on Sean Sr.  It was served and they went to court on
August 4th, 2006.  Sean Sr. denied that there was ever any abuse.  Mary was
not able to get the DCF records to prove otherwise prior to the court date.
The judge dismissed the Injunction.  The judge informed Mary to file for an
Eviction to get Sean Sr. removed from her home.
 
Sean Sr. returned to Mary's home on August 4th, 2006.  On August 5th, Mary
and the children left their home and came to live at mine.  The reason for
leaving was the attitude that Sean Sr. was displaying the Mary and the
children.  Sean Sr. was verbal abusive towards all of them.  Sean Sr.
informed Mary and the children he would drag the custody and get possession
of the home for however long it takes for him to win.
 
On August 7th, 2006, Sean Sr. was served with a three (3) day Eviction
Notice.  
 
On August 10th, 2006, Mary hired attorney, Billy Thomas, located in
Melbourne.  Before filing the necessary documents, Mary's attorney, Billy
Thomas contacted Sean Sr's. attorney, Kenneth Rhoden, located in Cocoa to
see if Sean Sr. would leave the house and let Mary and the children return
home.  Mr. Rhoden stated that Sean Sr. would remain in the home.
 
 
 
Before Mr. Thomas could process the necessary documents to evict Sean Sr.,
Mary was served with court documents for Custody and Division of Property.  
 
Within a week or two, Mary started receiving notices in the mail to help her
home be saved from foreclosures.  Mary is not in foreclosure.  She has been
making ALL of the mortgage payments.
 
Mary went to the Merritt Island office of her attorney and was informed that
Sean Sr. and his attorney had filed a "Notice of Lis Pendens".  Since this
was filed, an eviction process is not an option.
 
Sean Finnegan Sr. is not on the mortgage paperwork, nor is he on the deed on
Mary's home.  Sean Sr. has not been helping make any of the payments toward
the mortgage nor any of the utilities, insurance and/or food for the family.
 
Due to the paperwork that was filed from Sean Sr.'s attorney, Mr. Rhodes,
Mary and her children had to leave their home.  They left their home on or
around August 5th, 2006, and have been residing with my family since that
time.
 
We own a four (4) bedroom home that is in the middle of construction.  We
have my husband (Mary's brother), my son, my step-daughter, my father and me
living here prior to Mary and her children moving in.
 
There are now eight (8) people residing in my home.  We have had to make
arrangements for Mary and her children to have a place to sleep and reside
for over two and a half months (2 ).
 
Mary was advised by her attorney to return home this past Saturday, October
7th.  When Mary arrived back home, she did install locks on all the bedroom
doors to prevent Sean Sr. from taking over the bedrooms.  Sean Sr. has in
the past walked in on her seventeen (17) year old daughter while getting
dressed.  
 
Since Mary was only allowed to take her personal belongings (clothes) and
the children's clothes, everything had to be left in the house.  When Mary
returned to house, she found all of her paperwork (copies of bills, previous
divorce papers, copies of checks, warranties, etc.) was missing.  Her
computer was gone as well as some furniture.  This is just a few of the
reasons for the locks on the doors.
 
On Saturday evening, Sean Sr. starting smoking in the house.  Their son,
Sean Jr., is asthmatic.  Mary asked Sean Sr. to stop smoking but he would
not.  He was mad because Mary returned back to the house.  Mary then,
contacted DCF in hopes they could help her to make Sean Sr. stop smoking in
the home.
 
When DCF came to the house on Sunday morning, they were upset that there
were locks on the bedroom doors.  They were also were upset that Mary didn't
leave again on Saturday night when Sean Sr. wouldn't stop smoking.  Mary did
have Sean Jr. sleep in the bedroom with a towel on the floor covering the
opening left by the door to help prevent the smoke from entering the room,
but he still had to use his inhaler both Saturday night and Sunday morning.
Sean Sr. was still smoking in the home when DCF showed up.

 
DCF gave Mary and Sean Sr. three (3) choices.  One, Sean Sr. could leave;
Two, Mary could stay there but would have to remove all the locks off the
doors and Sean Sr. would have to quit smoking in the house; Three, Mary and
the children would have to leave again.
 
Well, the decision was made for Mary and the children to again leave their
home and come back to my home to reside until the court hearing to help her
get temporary relief to move back into her home without Sean Sr. living
there.  The court hearing is not scheduled until February 6th, 2007.
 
Since Mary has been living in my home, she has had to continue paying the
mortgage for her home, even though she hasn't been living in it; had to
continue paying for all the utilities, even though she hasn't been the one
using the utilities.  But for over two months, Mary has had to pay for these
bills, NOT Sean Sr., even though he is the one that is accruing the bills.  
 
My home resides in Port St. John.  Mary's home resides in Merritt Island.
Her children go to school in Merritt Island.  Mary has to get the children
up earlier than normal to be driven to school in the morning.  She then
returns back to my house in Port St. John, unless she has doctor's
appointments to go to, then she has to return back to Merritt Island by
2:30pm to pick up her son from grade school, then sit around until about
3:30pm to pick up her daughter from high school.  Then she returns back to
my house.  She is averaging about 130 miles a day driving.  Gas alone has
cost her so much just to make sure her children make it to school and home
again.  She is on Social Security and is just able to make her normal bills
not additional expenses like paying for additional gas (especially at the
prices gas is at now), to get her children to school and back.
 
When she was living in her own home, she hardly ever used the air
conditioner to keep her home cool.  She did this to save money.  She would
use fans and keep her windows open to try to keep the house cool.  Her
average electricity bill would be around $50 a month.  The first electricity
bill she received with only Sean Sr. living by himself was $198 for one
month, then $226 for the next month.  She had to pay this as well as the
other utilities.  
 
Since she tried to go home this past Saturday and had to return back to my
home on Sunday, she has now cancelled all the utilities that were in her
name.  Now, when or if she gets to return back to her home, she will have to
reinstate all the utilities and have to pay a higher deposit to have them
turned back on.
 
Mary had to leave all her food at the house for Sean Sr. to eat.  She was
not allowed to take any of it with her.  She has lived with me for over two
and a half (2 ) months.  She has been able to give me $200 to help offset
the additional expenses my family has incurred with her family living here.
My electricity has gone from $289 +/- a month to up to $416 a month.  My
water bill has gone from $19 +/- a month to over $50.  This is not to
mention my grocery bill.  That is almost doubled.  I have spent over $1400
since August just to make sure there is enough food in my home for all of
the meals to feed everyone.
 
We need some help and we need it fast.  How can the State of Florida allow a
home owner with two (2) children to leave their home to allow someone else
to reside in it?  How can the State of Florida allow the homeowner to have
to pay all the bills for the home if they are not residing in it?  How can
the State of Florida allow this person to live for free and make the
homeowner homeless?  How can the State of Florida make it my family's
responsibility to support this family?
 
We are so cramped up in my home.  We have air mattresses everywhere to make
room so they have beds to sleep on.  My home is under construction as I am
writing this to you.  We don't mind helping our family, but it has been over
two (2) months and now we are being told it could be until February 6th,
2007, before Mary could be able to return to her own home.  Since the
situation that occurred on Sunday, October 8th, Mary's attorney is trying to
move the "Relief Hearing" up.  But what does that mean, we have to wait
possibly until January 2007 instead of February 6th, 2007.
 
 
WE CANNOT ALL LIVE HERE FOR ANOTHER FOUR (4) MONTHS, ESPECIALLY THROUGH THE
HOLIDAY SEASON.  WE CANNOT HAVE EIGHT (8) PEOPLE STAYING IN THIS HOME FOR
THIS LENGTH OF TIME.
 
WE NEED YOUR HELP.  IS THERE ANYWAY YOU CAN HELP US?  
 
Is there any law out there that can change what is going on with Mary and
her family?  Is there a law out there that can allow her to go back to her
own home, one that she is buying and paying for and make Sean Sr. leave?
 
I have been told that Florida is NOT a "common law" state.  If this is TRUE,
then why is Mary being treated as if there is a "common law"?
 
PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, TRY TO HELP US!!!  WE ARE AT THE END OF OUR ROPES;
WE DON'T KNOW WHAT TO DO.   
 
I AM WRITING THIS TO YOU, HOPING THAT ONE OF OUR CONGRESSMEN/WOMEN WILL BE
ABLE TO HELP US FIND THE ANSWERS WE NEED AND FIND IT FAST, SO WE CAN ALL GO
BACK TO OUR NORMAL LIVES, LIVING IN OUR OWN HOMES THAT WE HAVE WORKED SO
HARD AT BUYING.
 
If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at the following:
 
Sherri Stanley-Hufford
6430 Homestead Avenue
Port St. John, FL  32927
321-638-2213 (home)
321-432-8950 (cell)
 
Thank you again for taking the time to read this, and hopefully one of you
may be able to help us with this dilemma.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Sherri Stanley-Hufford

>>> "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> 10/13/2006 2:01 PM
>>>
Dear Ms. Bishop:
 
Thank you for writing to Governor Bush about a legal problem.  The
Governor is sorry to learn of this situation, and has asked me to
respond.

 <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns =
"urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" />

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters
that should be resolved through the court system.  The person who can
best answer your legal questions is an attorney.  If you need assistance
in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service
at 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal
Services or your local legal aid office has information about the
availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone number for Florida
Legal Services is 850-385-7900.

 

I understand from your correspondence the state attorney's office has
been advised of this case.  I encourage you to continue working with the
state attorney's office to resolve any criminal issues you believe are
involved.

 

Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the
problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.  

 

                                                                       
Sincerely,

 

 

 

                                                                       
Warren Davis

                                                                       
Office of Citizens' Services

From: Brigitte Bishop [mailto:bbishop@bop.gov] 
Sent: Tuesday, October 10, 2006 10:03 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush

Subject: Elderly Exploitation and Misuse of Funds


Mr. Bush, 
 
I am contacting you out of desperation. My grandfather, Walter E.
Smith,  passed away on April 15, 2006, after an accident in a local
Sam's Club.  My uncle, Terry L. Smith, assumed primary responsibility of
my grandmother after his death.  He apparently was added to the bank
account in order to assist my grandmother, Eloise G. Smith, age 88, with
paying her bills, prior to my grandfather's death.  I am sure my
grandfather trusted his judgements at that time, not knowing that the
worst would happen.   On September 20, 2006, my sister, Shawna L. Fikar,
received a call from my grandmother, she claimed her son had taken
$38,000.00 from her checking account (which he was on) and that she was
also receiving notices of NSF's on checks written from her account.
NOTE:  He took the check book, he was signing all checks, he also had
her mail forwarded to a P.O. Box in his name in order to prevent her
from receiving mail on two occasions.  Once realized, she had it changed
back and started receiving items showing other signs of possible fraud. 
A caretaker, Jonette Armagost, Callahan, Florida is a witness to most of
what has been happening.  In responding, we found that he indeed had
removed the money, he also had cashed in Certificates of Deposits, Money
Market Accounts, Savings Accounts, etc.  He was then writing checks to
himself (for caring for her), paying his home mortgage in another state,
his rent in Florida, paying credit card bills...the list goes on.  We
hired an attorney to attempt to retrieve the money.  We have also
contacted Department of Children and Family in Nassau County, where my
grandmother lives.   Case Worker, Lynne Brown has referred the case to
the State Attorney's Office and the Nassau County Sheriff's Office.  We
have also found that he is using one, and possibly more, credits cards
that were issued to either my deceased grandfather, or in both of their
names.  My grandmother did not take care of the finances, so she didn't
even know they had credit cards.  One card is from Sears.  Sears states
that my grandfather was the only card holder on the account.  In
September, Terry Smith ordered a microphone, assuming the identity of my
grandfather and had it delivered to my grandfather's address.  Keep in
mind...this is identity theft.  
 
On October 2, 2006, Circuit Court Judge in Nassau County, Florida,
ordered Temporary Guardianship to my sister, Shawna Fikar, 14643 Corral
Berry Drive, Tampa, Florida  33626, (813) 546-0818.  We have secured
approximately $500.00 that was left in her account, set up all of her
bills to be paid electronically, and an "accounting" will be kept on all
future expenditures from her account.  Our attorney has been very
helpful in quickly addressing our issues, but we feel there are many
loop holes that will allow him to get away with what he has done.  We
need the support and help from someone that has the power to take care
of this man for exploiting and misusing his mother's money for his own
use and pleasure.
 
Another issue is that he has taken her car and will not return it.  It
is titled to my grandmother and grandfather, she pays the insurance, but
the Nassau County S.O. states the laws are funny on that subject and
there is nothing they can do.  Shawna Fikar, current Temporary Guardian,
has sent a certified mail request asking that the car be returned.  No
response from Terry Smith.  It belongs to my grandmother, she isn't
going to drive it, but it is hers and should be at her home if she
wishes.  Where are the laws to protect her?
 
More frustration comes in where we find there are not many laws that
actually hold him responsible.  We keep getting the phrase, "he is
listed on the checking accounts, not much can be done".  Well, he
blatantly used her money for his own affairs.  He refuses to respond to
our Attorney contacts, and is still refusing to return her car.      We
need help.
 
Please help us so that he does not get away with what he has done.  We
would like for her money to be returned and he pay for the criminal acts
he has committed.
 
If you, or someone that has the power to help could contact us, we
would be so grateful.  As in most cases like this, time is not on our
side.  The faster this is addressed, the better chance we have to secure
her missing funds, automobile, and ensure she is taken care of properly.

 
Thank you in advance for any assistance you can give us.
 
Brigitte Bishop, 1351 CR 482 N, Lake Panasoffkee, Florida 33538  -
(352) 689-5236 daytime -

Mr. Davis,

Is it possible you can forward the attached correspondence directly to the

political correct answer, I am looking for the truth.

Any assistance from you would be greatly appreciated!
Michele Ripley


I understand that your department looks into investigations of fraud when a 
case is presented to you.  What I don't understand is how you conduct an 
investigation when you have never spoken with me?  You obviously have the 
ability to pull my drivers license, so you obviously saw that it is signed 
MICHELE RIPLEY.  Did that not raise a red flag with your office that I was 
NOT committing fraud?



Last I checked, in the United States we are afforded the right to face our 
accuser.  Yet your department will tell me nothing of how this investigation 
was conducted, what steps you took to determine I was committing fraud, and 
how your office came to the conclusion, I.e.: documents you received showing 
that I was committing fraud.



Obviously, it does not matter that I tried repeatedly to correct this 
situation.  YOUR office in Miami would NOT accept the documents, even thou I 
repeatedly tried to explain to this that it was an official court document. 
I even went so far as to ask them to call the court house in Cutler Ridge, 
with them telling me "they can call us".  Easier said than done, I can 
assure you.



I did ask my attorney at the time, and he instructed me that when I renewed 
my license, to simply sign with my name- MICHELE RIPLEY.  Which obviously I 
did.



I did NOT receive your notice in 2004.  Not my fault and not yours.  I would 
have taken care of this situation in 2004 if I had received it, I assure 
you.  I did receive the notice this week, after speaking with your fraud 
department.  It states that I am not entitled to issuance until I show legal 
proof of name.  I assure you, this will be taken care of in the next week.



My concern is that now my license shows it has been cancelled and I don't 
want that on my record.  I was NOT committing fraud and frankly, I feel your 
office failed in their investigation.



It is silly for me to hire an attorney, when this can be solved by you 
reviewing the actual documents you received, and re-reviewing your 
investigation to find out why it was not noticed that I signed my legal name 
on my driver's license of MICHELE RIPLEY.



Please do not send me another e-mail which does not answer my question, I 
don't appreciate that and I don't appreciate the fact that you are ignoring 
the obvious.  I did NOT commit fraud.  That is a very serious crime, and I 
do not want to be labeled as one who committed fraud.  I am a law abiding 
citizen and wish to remain one in good standing.



Thank you

Michele Ripley

    -----Original Message-----

    From: Robert & Michele [mailto:fourbear@earthlink.net]

    Sent: Monday, October 09, 2006 2:03 PM

    To: Governor Jeb Bush

    Subject: Serious concerns and questions





    Dear Governor Bush,



    I am sorry for contacting your office, but I really did not know where 
to turn.  I felt your office would have the answers I need.  I have made 
over 30 phone calls trying to get an answer to my questions but frankly, 
everyone I speak with gives me a different answer.



    I have two issues that are of great concern to me.



    My first issue.  My husband and I recently testified against an 
individual who had assaulted a member of our family.  She was only 14 at the 
time of the incident, and the individual in question was sentenced to jail 
as a sexual offender. I requested after the hearing (in writing) for the 
case to be sealed, because frankly, this should not follow this young female 
around the rest of her life.  I have been told by the state attorneys office 
in Okeechobee, Florida that this can not be done due to the public having 
the right to access court records.



    It has always been my impression that if the case involves a minor, and 
is of a sexual nature, with a conviction, that the family can request the 
court records to be sealed.  If this is not the case, it should be!  Could 
your legal office provide the law on this to me, so that I can either 
present it to the state attorney in Okeechobee county, or advise me on what 
steps to take to try and pass a law such as this?



    My second issue: I just found out that my license has been cancelled. 
Apparently in 2004 your fraud division of licensing received a report that I 
was committing fraud by using a wrong name on my license.  This is far from 
the truth.  When I contacted the fraud division, they informed me that I 
could not have access to any investigation they performed. How do you do an 
investigation of fraud without speaking to the individual you are 
investigating?  How do you cancel and individual's driver's license without 
informing them?



    My drivers license has the name of: Michele Allen Corbin-Allen being my 
maiden name, and Corbin being the name of my first marriage.  The SIGNATURE 
I sign on my drivers license is Michele Ripley.  I have been re-married for 
16 years.  I have tried over 10 times to have my drivers license changed to 
my married name in Homestead, Florida when we lived there and where I was 
married.  I went to the Cutler Ridge court house, obtained a certified copy 
of my marriage license and took it over to the drivers license office in 
Homestead only to be told that they would not accept it due to the paper it 
was printed on.  (fax paper).  I again went back to the Cutler Ridge Court 
House and explained the situation- they printed out another certified copy 
of my marriage certificate, but it was still on fax paper as this is the 
paper they used in there printers.  Again, the drivers license office denied 
the document.  At this point, when I went back to the Court House, I asked 
to speak with a supervisor, who informed me that there was nothing the mater 
with the document and that there was no reason for the drivers license to 
continue to refuse it.  This was repeated two more times, with me going back 
and forth between the drivers license officer and the Cutler Ridge Court 
house.

    Nobody was budging, and nobody was willing to call there other.



    What was I to do?



    Many years later, during a custody issue it was brought up that I was 
using my previous married name on my license.  I testified in court the 
above situation and the judge stated that it would be in my best interest to 
get this resolved, having nothing to do with the custody issues at hand.  It 
was a suggestion, one that I again tried to resolve.



    I again went to the cutler ridge court house, this time I went back 
three times, with the drivers license still refusing to accept the paper my 
marriage certificate was printed on by the court house.



    What was I to do?  I simply showed ID the last time that I went to renew 
my drivers license, and signed it Michele Ripley.



    Now, I find out that apparently someone complained that I was using the 
name of Corbin and an investigation was apparently iniated, without ever 
discussing the situation with me.  When I spoke with your fraud division and 
explained the above situation, and they pulled up my drivers license, they 
did indeed see that I signed it Michele Ripley.  All they could tell me was 
that they could not believe I was allowed to sign it that way.



    What is there to believe- my name is Michele Ripley and that's how I 
sign my documents.



    I do not feel it is fair to have my drives license cancelled, nor do I 
feel it is fair to have this on my record.  I also do not understand if an 
investigation was done, why am I not entitled to the reports.  I am not a 
minor, I am an adult, this investigation was done in regards to me.  Can 
anyone just report something and you guys take it at face value?  Without 
even speaking to the individual in question?  This can not be the case.



    I would appreciate ANY assistance your office can provide on these two 
matters.



    Thank you

    Michele Ripley

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Robert & Michele" <fourbear@earthlink.net>
Sent: Tuesday, October 10, 2006 9:39 AM
Subject: RE: Serious concerns and questions


Dear Ms. Ripley:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush.  The Governor appreciates your 
questions and asked me to respond on his behalf.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in criminal 
court cases.  Each state attorney is an elected official charged with 
certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to 
prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction. 
This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt 
shown, and in the best interest of justice.  I understand you directed your 
questions regarding a criminal case to the state attorney's office and you 
are dissatisfied with their response, however, that is the office that has 
legal jurisdiction in this regard.  For further assistance, the person who 
can best answer your legal questions is an attorney.  An attorney is also 
the one you should speak with regarding the cancellation of your license. 
If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida 
Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to afford a 
lawyer, Florida Legal Services or your local legal aid office has 
information about the availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone 
number for Florida Legal Services is 850-385-7900.

To further assist you in this regard, I am forwarding a copy of your e-mail 
to the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles for their 
review.  Should you wish to contact that agency directly, please use the 
contact information provided below.

Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems 
you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.

                                                                        Sincerely,
