-----Original Message-----
From: Robert & Michele [mailto:fourbear@earthlink.net]
Sent: Monday, October 09, 2006 2:03 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Serious concerns and questions


Dear Governor Bush,

I am sorry for contacting your office, but I really did not know where to 
turn.  I felt your office would have
the answers I need.  I have made over 30 phone calls trying to get an answer 
to my questions but frankly, everyone I speak with gives me a different 
answer.

I have two issues that are of great concern to me.

My first issue.  My husband and I recently testified against an individual 
who had assaulted a member of our family.  She was only 14 at the time of 
the incident, and the individual in question was sentenced to jail as a 
sexual offender. I requested after the hearing (in writing) for the case to 
be sealed, because frankly, this should not follow this young female around 
the rest of her life.  I have been told by the state attorneys office in 
Okeechobee, Florida that this can not be done due to the public having the 
right to access court records.

It has always been my impression that if the case involves a minor, and is 
of a sexual nature, with a conviction, that the family can request the court 
records to be sealed.  If this is not the case, it should be!  Could your 
legal office provide the law on this to me, so that I can either present it 
to the state attorney in Okeechobee county, or advise me on what steps to 
take to try and pass a law such as this?

My second issue.  I just found out that my license has been cancelled. 
Apparently in 2004 your fraud division of licensing received a report that I 
was committing fraud by using a wrong name on my license.  This is far from 
the truth.  When I contacted the fraud division, they informed me that I 
could not have access to any investigation they performed.

How do you do an investigation of fraud without speaking to the individual 
you are investigating?  How do you cancel and individual's drivers license 
without informing them?

My drivers license has the name of :Michele Allen Corbin- Allen being my 
maiden name, and Corbin being the name of my first marriage.  The SIGNATURE 
I sign on my drivers license is Michele Ripley.  I have been re-married for 
16 years.  I have tried over 10 times to have my drivers license changed to 
my married name in Homestead, Florida when we lived there and where I was 
married.  I went to the Cutler Ridge court house, obtained a certified copy 
of my marriage license and took it over to the drivers license office in 
Homestead only to be told that they would not accept it due to the paper it 
was printed on.  (fax paper).  I again went back to the Cutler Ridge Court 
House and explained the situation- they printed out another certified copy 
of my marriage certificate, but it was still on fax paper as this is the 
paper they used in there printers.  Again, the drivers license office denied 
the document.  At this point, when I went back to the Court House, I asked 
to speak with a supervisor, who informed me that there was nothing the mater 
with the document and that there was no reason for the drivers license to 
continue to refuse it.  This was repeated two more times, with me going back 
and forth between the drivers license officer and the Cutler Ridge Court 
house.
Nobody was budging, and nobody was willing to call there other.

What was I to do?

Many years later, during a custody issue it was brought up that I was using 
my previous married name on my license.  I testified in court the above 
situation and the judge stated that it would be in my best interest to get 
this resolved, having nothing to do with the custody issues at hand.  It was 
a suggestion, one that I again tried to resolve.

I again went to the cutler ridge court house, this time I went back three 
times, with the drivers license still refusing to accept the paper my 
marriage certificate was printed on by the court house.

What was I to do?  I simply showed ID the last time that I went to renew my 
drivers license, and signed it Michele Ripley.

Now, I find out that apparently someone complained that I was using the name 
of Corbin and an investigation was apparently iniated, without ever 
discussing the situation with me.  When I spoke with your fraud division and 
explained the above situation, and they pulled up my drivers license, they 
did indeed see that I signed it Michele Ripley.  All they could tell me was 
that they could not believe I was allowed to sign it that way.

What is there to believe- my name is Michele Ripley and that's how I sign my 
documents.

I do not feel it is fair to have my drives license cancelled, nor do I feel 
it is fair to have this on my record.  I also do not understand if an 
investigation was done, why am I not entitled to the reports.  I am not a 
minor, I am an adult, this investigation was done in regards to me.  Can 
anyone just report something and you guys take it at face value?  Without 
even speaking to the individual in question?  This can not be the case.

I would appreciate ANY assistance your office can provide on these two 
matters.

Thank you
Michele Ripley

Warren,
 
I am impressed.  I never thought I would get any type of response.
 
The bottom line, is that in Florida, stealing a six of beer carries the same penalty as kidnapping and sexual slavery of a foreign minor; 10 years.  Compare that with the Federal Banking Laws were you can steal $1. 3 Billion and walk away with no prison time and having to pay back only a fraction of what you stole.
 
I know one thing,  I will always buy my beer in Florida.  Of course, if I need money to buy it, I may want to steal the money from the Federal Government, as you will always come out ahead.
 
Thanks for the response Mr. Davis, I think we need courts in this country that serve the people of this country equally and not discriminate based upon class, or other bias of the parties involved.
 
Killers spend less time behind bars then people who could be reformed at less cost to the tax payer.  Governors have the ability to affect change if they get involved.
 
Sincerely,
 
Mr. Johnson

Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> wrote:

Dear Mr. Johnson:

Thank you for your letter regarding a Florida criminal case. Governor Bush is sorry to learn of your concerns.

Each state attorney is an elected official charged with certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether or not to prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction. This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt shown, and in the best interest of justice. Questions about the guilt or innocence of prisoners, mental capacity to commit a crime, or the procedural fairness of their convictions must be addressed in the courts. Those who wish to contest judicial rulings should speak with an attorney about what appellate procedures may be available. 

Decisions over prisoners' movement within the system, rehabilitative or educational programs, temporary release permission, and incentive gain time are under the authority of the Department of Corrections. The Florida Parole Commission, an entity independent of the Governor's control, determines the issues of control release and early release. 

The clemency function is a power to grant full or conditional pardons, restore a felon's civil rights, or commute punishment. There are complicated rules for these lengthy procedures, and these powers are vested in the Governor only with the agreement of three Cabinet members who are also statewide elected officials. Clemency for prisoners is seldom granted, as it is necessary to await the outcome of court appeals. For more information, you can write the Office of Executive Clemency at Building C, Room 229, 2601 Blair Stone Road, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2450.

Thank you again for writing. 

Sincerely,



Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

Jeb,
I heard an story about Adam Bollenbach from a segment on the "Geraldo at Large" television segment. I believe his sentence is too harsh for his crime and I belive you should consider his clemency if he has had good behavior while in prison. Please see attached article summary from the "Geraldo at Large" :
"Adam Bollenbach has been in prison for five years, serving time for crime that could have been solved by an apology, repayment, and supervision to assure that he obtained treatment for his mental health problems. 
But why is this Florida teen, who suffers from ADHD and diagnosed as bipolar, serving a ten-year sentence for stealing beer and chips when he was 16? 

Circuit Judge Ric Howard admitted that he was using Adam as a teaching tool in front of other juvenile offenders, which resulted in the teen's ten-year prison sentence. 

Months earlier, Adam had been charged as an adult for theft of a bag of potato chips from his high school lunchroom. The charge was dropped, but according to the law, once charged as an adult, you cannot be charged as a juvenile." http://www.geraldoatlarge.com/blog.php?where_param=blog_id&blog_id=635
When you consider how a heinous crime was given the same sentence in Florida for harboring a sex slave. Please see attached article from "Naplesnews.com":

naplesnews.com
Man gets 10 years in prison for harboring sex slave
By Nicholas P. Alajakis
Wednesday, August 2, 2006
Saying she thought his actions were despicable and horrible, a judge on Tuesday sentenced a North Fort Myers man to the maximum of 10 years in prison for harboring a sex slave from Guatemala.

Fernando Pascual, 22, was given what U.S. District Judge Virginia M. Hernandez Covington called a lenient sentence. As part of a plea agreement, Pascual pleaded guilty in March to forcing a 13-year-old girl to be his sex slave and do work around the house. "These are truly horrible crimes you have committed and they will not be tolerated in the United States," Covington told Pascual after sentencing him. Pascual, his sister, Matilde Pascual Andres, and Andres' husband, Pascual Miguel Sebastian, were charged in May 2005 with harboring a young girl in a Cape Coral home. Prosecutors say the girl, referred to only as "EJJ" in court documents, was bought in Guatemala and brought to Cape Coral, where she was raped, beaten and forced to work. Matilde Pascual Andres was sentenced on Tuesday to 22 months in prison for her role in keeping the girl. Pascual Miguel Sebastian was sentenced to 16 months in May on a similar charge. Fernando Pascual was the one prosecutors were most interested in, said Chief Assistant U.S. Attorney Doug Molloy. He claimed to be married to the girl, and court records show that he would not allow her out of the home. His sentence of 10 years was in exchange for the victim not having to testify because she was traumatized by the abuse she took for two years, Covington said. "I could have, and quite frankly would have, given you a harsher sentence. (But the victim) should not have to be raped and suffer the consequences of having to come up here and testify against you," Covington told Pascual. "I do not want to minimize what happened here. Your activities are very, very wrong and illegal."

Following the sentencing, Molloy said he is happy that the whole ordeal is over, especially because it allows the victim to move on after 15 months.
"This is finally a chance to everyone to move forward," Molloy said.
 2006 Naples Daily News and NDN Productions. Published in Naples, Florida, USA by the E.W. Scripps Co.

And you consider some very divisive dealings at the highest levels of our government that have gone unpunished: See attached article from the "Austin Chronicle":

O, Brother! Where Art Thou?
Like Hugh Rodham, the Bush Bros. Have Capitalized on Family Ties
BY LOUIS DUBOSE

Unless you've been reading the Houston Chronicle society page, it's unlikely you've seen any current news about Neil Bush. The third Bush sibling has been almost as invisible as his apolitical brother Marvin, a venture capitalist living in northern Virginia, and his sister Dorothy "Doro" Koch, the youngest of the five Bush siblings, who quietly raises funds for charities in a Maryland suburb near Washington. While Jeb was governor of Florida and George W. was twice elected governor of Texas, Neil was either part of the late Maxine Mesinger's "crme de la crme crowd" at a Houston social event, or a stale S&L footnote: "the director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan when it crashed in 1988 at a cost of $1 billion to taxpayers." 
In 1990, Bush paid a $50,000 fine and was banned from banking activities for his role in taking down Silverado, which actually cost taxpayers $1.3 billion. A Resolution Trust Corporation Suit against Bush and other officers of Silverado was settled in 1991 for $26.5 million. And the fine wasn't exactly paid by Neil Bush. A Republican fundraiser set up a fund to help defer costs Neil incurred in his S&L dealings. Friends and relatives contributed -- but not then-President and Barbara Bush, which would have been unseemly. Since then, the Bush political combine has done such a remarkable job keeping Neil in the background that what seemed like a 10-year news blackout didn't end until mid-February, when the Austin Business Journal reported that Bush "quietly is heading a local start-up that's raising at least $10 million in second-round funding." According to the business newsweekly, Bush has already raised $7.1 million from 53 investors underwriting Ignite! Inc., an educational software company. After being banned from banking and all but airbrushed out of the family portrait -- or at least the family news profile -- Neil Bush is back. 
Bush wasn't just an average S&L exec drawing a big salary and recklessly pushing a federally insured institution beyond its lending limits. As a director of a failing thrift in Denver, Bush voted to approve $100 million in what were ultimately bad loans to two of his business partners. And in voting for the loans, he failed to inform fellow board members at Silverado Savings & Loan that the loan applicants were his business partners. Federal banking regulators later followed the trail of defaulted loans to Neil Bush oil ventures, in particular JNB International, an oil and gas exploration company awarded drilling concessions in Argentina -- despite its complete lack of experience in international oil and gas drilling. It probably helped that the Bush family had cultivated close ties with the fabulously corrupt Carlos Menem, former president of Argentina. 
When JNB's rights and obligations were assumed by other investors, Neil tried to persuade another American oil and gas exploration company, Plains Resources, to invest in Argentina. Plains wasn't buying. But it was hiring, and picked up Neil as a consultant for its Argentine market -- because, as Plains executive Carlos Garibaldi told The New York Times' Jeff Gerth in 1992, Neil had "traveled [in Argentina] and played tennis with President Menem." Plains President J. Patrick Collins told Gerth at the time that Neil Bush "bent over backwards not to trade on his name." 
That claim was hard to make in 1993, when Neil, Marvin, James Baker III, John Sununu, and Thomas Kelly (who had served as director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff during the Gulf War) joined President Bush on a trip to Kuwait. Three months out of office, the elder Bush was traveling on a Kuwait Airlines flight to accept an honorary degree from the country's university and its highest honor from its leader: Emir Sheikh Jabir al-Ahmad al-Sabah. The rest of the Bush entourage was following along to exploit the market in a country that considered the ex-president its savior. Former Secretary of State Baker was doing deals for Enron (the Houston-based energy-related company and contributor to Bush the Elder and later a $525,000 donor to George W. Bush's two gubernatorial races in Texas). Marvin was representing U.S. defense firms selling electronic fences to the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry. And Neil was selling anti-pollution equipment to Kuwaiti oil contractors. 
There is "no conflict of interest. ... We're just capitalizing on whatever good feelings exist," an executive from the company Neil Bush represented later told Seymour Hersh, who laid out the embarrassing story on the pages of The New Yorker in September 1993. Neil, according to Hersh, later returned to Kuwait and set up shop in the International Hotel in Kuwait City, where he tried to secure a management contract with Kuwait's Ministry of Electricity and Water. Neil's deal included foreign and Kuwaiti members of the Enron consortium, and would have had the Kuwaiti government paying a management fee to a Kuwaiti company that was owned in part by a private company set up in the Caribbean or some other tax haven. "The offshore firm would have various owners, in Europe and elsewhere, one of which would be a company in which Neil Bush had an interest," The New Yorker reported. The scheme was ingenious, a financial analyst told Hersh."If you looked at one of the contracts, how in the hell would you know that Bush was in it?" The whole deal was as unsavory and unpardonable as a round of golf with Hillary Clinton sibling Huey Rodham. 
Jeb missed that junket, but the current governor of Florida isn't above taking the family name abroad to make a buck. In 1989, Bush and his wife traveled to Nigeria with a executives of M&W Pump, a Florida-based company that had been selling agricultural pumps to Nigeria. Jeb and Columba Bush were received by Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida and celebrated by tens of thousands of Nigerians who turned out to see the son of the U.S. president. President Babangida expressed his interest in visiting the White House -- a request Jeb promised to pass along to his father -- and by 1992 the Florida pump company had secured $74 million in financing from the Export-Import Bank of the United States. It was by far the largest Ex-Im deal M&W had ever done in Nigeria -- a country Ex-Im loan officers considered a bad risk. "I didn't get paid for the Nigeria business," Bush told The Palm Beach Post in 1994. "I have not made a dime on business with Nigeria." Yet the Post found tax records that revealed Bush and earned at least $300,000 through his association with the owner of the same company for which he had done a pro-bono sales trip to Nigeria. Bush-El, a 50-50 partnership with the owner of M&W, paid Bush at least $300,000 for his participation in a separate venture, marketing agricultural hand pumps. Why would Bush suddenly find himself involved with a company selling agricultural hand pumps around the world? the Post asked. "I know how to sell things," responded Bush. "I know international sales. I know how to get people to put together tenders because I financed a lot of them when I was working at Texas Commerce Bank." 
Here in Austin, it's a safe bet that Neil will raise the additional $10 million in start-up money Ignite! needs to get its software to market. In six years at Interlink Management, a venture capital firm he ran out of his father's Houston office from 1994 to 1999, he raised $60 million for high tech and biotech start-ups. Ignite! is a new company and a new market niche, but there's nothing new in what Neil Bush is about this year: leveraging the family name and other people's money into a business that will turn a profit -- if for no one else, at the very least for him. 
Given that Adam Bollenbach's crime pales in comparison to the transgressions committed by others, in your state and within your circle, I believe you should consider giving him a break. It seems others have been treated more fairly then the way Adam has been treated.

Sincerely 

Concerned American

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Robert & Michele" <fourbear@earthlink.net>
Sent: Tuesday, October 10, 2006 9:39 AM
Subject: RE: Serious concerns and questions


Dear Ms. Ripley:

Thank you for writing to Governor Bush.  The Governor appreciates your 
questions and asked me to respond on his behalf.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in criminal 
court cases.  Each state attorney is an elected official charged with 
certain discretionary duties, including the duty to determine whether to 
prosecute any particular crime committed within his or her jurisdiction. 
This decision is based on the quality and quantity of the evidence of guilt 
shown, and in the best interest of justice.  I understand you directed your 
questions regarding a criminal case to the state attorney's office and you 
are dissatisfied with their response, however, that is the office that has 
legal jurisdiction in this regard.  For further assistance, the person who 
can best answer your legal questions is an attorney.  An attorney is also 
the one you should speak with regarding the cancellation of your license. 
If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida 
Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011.  For those unable to afford a 
lawyer, Florida Legal Services or your local legal aid office has 
information about the availability of pro bono counsel.  The main telephone 
number for Florida Legal Services is 850-385-7900.

To further assist you in this regard, I am forwarding a copy of your e-mail 
to the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles for their 
review.  Should you wish to contact that agency directly, please use the 
contact information provided below.

Thank you again for writing.  The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems 
you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance.

                                                                        Sincerely,



                                                                        Warren 
Davis
                                                                        Office 
of Citizens' Services

Florida Department of Highway Safety
  and Motor Vehicles
Suite 307
2900 Apalachee Parkway
Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0500
(850) 617-3100]






-----Original Message-----
From: Robert & Michele [mailto:fourbear@earthlink.net]
Sent: Monday, October 09, 2006 2:03 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Serious concerns and questions


Dear Governor Bush,

I am sorry for contacting your office, but I really did not know where to 
turn.  I felt your office would have
the answers I need.  I have made over 30 phone calls trying to get an answer 
to my questions but frankly, everyone I speak with gives me a different 
answer.

I have two issues that are of great concern to me.

My first issue.  My husband and I recently testified against an individual 
who had assaulted a member of our family.  She was only 14 at the time of 
the incident, and the individual in question was sentenced to jail as a 
sexual offender. I requested after the hearing (in writing) for the case to 
be sealed, because frankly, this should not follow this young female around 
the rest of her life.  I have been told by the state attorneys office in 
Okeechobee, Florida that this can not be done due to the public having the 
right to access court records.

It has always been my impression that if the case involves a minor, and is 
of a sexual nature, with a conviction, that the family can request the court 
records to be sealed.  If this is not the case, it should be!  Could your 
legal office provide the law on this to me, so that I can either present it 
to the state attorney in Okeechobee county, or advise me on what steps to 
take to try and pass a law such as this?

My second issue.  I just found out that my license has been cancelled. 
Apparently in 2004 your fraud division of licensing received a report that I 
was committing fraud by using a wrong name on my license.  This is far from 
the truth.  When I contacted the fraud division, they informed me that I 
could not have access to any investigation they performed.

How do you do an investigation of fraud without speaking to the individual 
you are investigating?  How do you cancel and individual's drivers license 
without informing them?

My drivers license has the name of :Michele Allen Corbin- Allen being my 
maiden name, and Corbin being the name of my first marriage.  The SIGNATURE 
I sign on my drivers license is Michele Ripley.  I have been re-married for 
16 years.  I have tried over 10 times to have my drivers license changed to 
my married name in Homestead, Florida when we lived there and where I was 
married.  I went to the Cutler Ridge court house, obtained a certified copy 
of my marriage license and took it over to the drivers license office in 
Homestead only to be told that they would not accept it due to the paper it 
was printed on.  (fax paper).  I again went back to the Cutler Ridge Court 
House and explained the situation- they printed out another certified copy 
of my marriage certificate, but it was still on fax paper as this is the 
paper they used in there printers.  Again, the drivers license office denied 
the document.  At this point, when I went back to the Court House, I asked 
to speak with a supervisor, who informed me that there was nothing the mater 
with the document and that there was no reason for the drivers license to 
continue to refuse it.  This was repeated two more times, with me going back 
and forth between the drivers license officer and the Cutler Ridge Court 
house.
Nobody was budging, and nobody was willing to call there other.

What was I to do?

Many years later, during a custody issue it was brought up that I was using 
my previous married name on my license.  I testified in court the above 
situation and the judge stated that it would be in my best interest to get 
this resolved, having nothing to do with the custody issues at hand.  It was 
a suggestion, one that I again tried to resolve.

I again went to the cutler ridge court house, this time I went back three 
times, with the drivers license still refusing to accept the paper my 
marriage certificate was printed on by the court house.

What was I to do?  I simply showed ID the last time that I went to renew my 
drivers license, and signed it Michele Ripley.

Now, I find out that apparently someone complained that I was using the name 
of Corbin and an investigation was apparently iniated, without ever 
discussing the situation with me.  When I spoke with your fraud division and 
explained the above situation, and they pulled up my drivers license, they 
did indeed see that I signed it Michele Ripley.  All they could tell me was 
that they could not believe I was allowed to sign it that way.

What is there to believe- my name is Michele Ripley and that's how I sign my 
documents.

I do not feel it is fair to have my drives license cancelled, nor do I feel 
it is fair to have this on my record.  I also do not understand if an 
investigation was done, why am I not entitled to the reports.  I am not a 
minor, I am an adult, this investigation was done in regards to me.  Can 
anyone just report something and you guys take it at face value?  Without 
even speaking to the individual in question?  This can not be the case.

I would appreciate ANY assistance your office can provide on these two 
matters.

Thank you
Michele Ripley

From:	Ronald L. Stephenson <rstephenson@lifesci.com>

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	WARREN DAVIS - - Re: The Florida Bar

Mr. Davis - Thank you for your email.  My concern as I tried earlier to express is there is not a way to get to The Florida Bar website from "myflorida.com."  That seems to me to be a problem that could be fixed.

Thank you.

rls (a lawyer)

Governor Jeb Bush wrote:


Dear Mr. Stephenson:

Thank you for your recent e-mail to Governor Bush.  He has asked me to respond.

Your best source of assistance with a complaint about an attorney is the Florida Bar.  As you may know, the primary purpose of the Florida Bar is to ensure the highest standards of professionalism in the practice of law for the benefit of members and the public.  Complaints may be filed by writing the Florida Bar at 650 Apalachee Parkway, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-2300 or by calling 1-800-342-8060.

Thank you again for writing.  You have my best wishes in resolving your concerns.

Sincerely,

Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

I realize that does not matter to you or anyone else in the political force.  There is nothing in it for the politician so let's ignore it and maybe they will go away.

I have been asked to speak before Supreme Court of Florida on Fairness in the Florida State Courts System.
 
According to their past 17 years of surveys the exact same problems exist that they found existed 17 years ago.  The mind boggling fact is that you keep having victims come in and speak, you confirm that yes this is wrong, yes something needs to be done.  NEXT...
 
My question is when is something actually going to be done?  It won't happen in our lifetime yet there are families being torn apart by the very justice system they put their faith in.  
 
I would love to meet with someone in your office while I am in Tallahasse giving my ten  minute speech on October 20, 2006. I realize you are very busy especially since this is an election year.
 
I gave my first speech in Miami last January and was told the committee was moved by it and invited me to speak again.  Gladly I will take off work and do just that.  However, I want to meet with someone that actually cares in your office about mothers and fathers torn from their children needlessly.  
 
I am enclosing my email that was sent back that I emailed to Mark Foley as well as my address and contact numbers.

Cathie R. Rockwood

Dear Mr. Foley,

I just wanted you to know that despite all of this news coverage, I feel you did a great job.  You are the only one in this State of Florida that ever made an effort that went further than the standard letter.  

Believe me I contacted every politician and you actually made me feel like my votes were not in vain.  This has been an ongoing 11 year experience with you and I personally am glad I voted for you.

You made calls to me and discussed my concerns.  You also made calls to the courts on my behalf or had your assistants try, even though there really was nothing you could do.  I will personally will miss having you in the political scene.  I have a very poor view of our government and you were one of the brighter lights in that scene.

As far as your sexual preference, that is no ones business but yours and the consenting adult.  I lost my brother to AIDS in 1992.  There is not a day I don't wish he was here.  He hid his gayness to the point of getting married.  My father was an alcoholic until he died.  Both of them were good caring people.  

I don't know what your future will be but I wanted you to know that you will always be in my prayers.

From:	Shari Frank <bccr3@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, October 4, 2006 3:39 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	My Brother David Tywater

Dear Governor Bush: 

I am writing this letter in desperation. On September 17, 20006 my brother was taken from the a cruise ship as we docked in Galveston, Texas. We were returning from a week long cruise celebrating my sisters wedding. It seems that there had been a law suite filed against him by someone in Florida and even though he was unaware of this, he is considered a fugitive and arrested. He was removed from the ship by officials in front of his 9 year old son who was scared to death. He was locked in the Galveston jail for either 2 or 3 days before he was allowed to call us. We could not get one answer out of the law enforcement there. It was over a week and a half before he was taken before a judge and finally told what was going on. Then another 4 days before he was allowed to sign extradition papers. He is a 39 year old man who will no doubtably loose the company he has worked very hard to build at the hands of this legal system that we call our foundation. My brothers business partner has taken all the necessary documentation and turned himself in Florida and bonded out within 30 minutes. We were also told by our attorneys that there should be no problem proving these men are innocent with the materials my brothers business partner submitted. The problem is we were also told the state you govern, Florida can take up to 90 days to come and get my brother. Can you even imagine what this type of miss-understanding would do to your family should this happen to you? No means of support while being locked up, looking your business - your lively hood? It was my understanding that a person was innocent until proven guilty, they were charged bonded out and continued living until going to court. My brother has not been allowed to do so. He sits in this jail humiliated and embarrassed at the hands of the very legal system that is supposed to serve and protect us. What sort of justice is this. How are we as parents suppose to teach our children to have faith in our legal system and that they will be treated fairly until they are proven guilty if ever accused of a crime. My brother has no rights as far as we can tell. He is a very clean cut business man sitting in a nasty jail and we seem to have no where to turn. I am begging your office to check into the practices of your legal system located in Pensacola Florida. If they have all the necessary papers and all is in order, don't you think they should collect those they have accused so that we may have some closure. I fear that my brother can not take 60 more days (mentally or financially) of waiting on a legal system that has thus far failed him greatly. Can you offer some type of explanation for this type of justice? Do you honestly think this type of treatment will have no effects on my brother. Can you explain how your state has this type of power. You had him arrested and now you are doing nothing to help and everything to ensure he loose everything. Would you want this type of treatment for one of your children? Does your state offer any type of assistance to those who have lost everything at the hands of your government (financially or mentally)? Should states have extradition rights with those that would leave someone in jail until they lost everything including their sanity? Please offer my brother some type of hope, tell us what to do or at the very least find out what the hold up is and send someone to get my brother so we can end this night mare. 

Sincerely, 

Sharp Frank 

1418 CR 47 

Angleton, Texas 77515 

BCCR3@hotmail.com. (281) 331-3433 

David Tywater inmate at 

Galveston County Jail 

Galveston, TX

more predators

1 in 4 male juveniles are molested by other juveniles
1 in 3 female juveniles are molest by other juveniles

They are not reported because your laws are not set up to help them

So they are not reported and continue to molest others and grow up to be
molesting other. 

You find some of them as adults the ones you created by ignoring the
bigger picture when they were juveniles

Again 90% can lead positive lives if they receive treatment and in the
future you will not be dealing with them as adults

Take off your blinders or is it easier to point the finger and say they
are all bad rather then start to solve the problem

Don't talk around the facts try actually answering the questions this is
a hot issue and politicians need to pay attention

Hugh

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, October 04, 2006 12:02
To: Shrager, Hugh H.
Subject: RE: The real moral dilemma

Dear Mr. Shrager:

Thank you for your letter explaining your views and opinions.  Governor
Bush is glad you took the time to share your perspective and asked me to
respond on his behalf.
 
Governor Bush believes sexual crimes against children are among the most
heinous imaginable.  The Governor encourages citizens to be ever
vigilant and to promote awareness of sexual offenders and sexual
predators living within their communities.  If you suspect a child is in
any danger, notify your local law enforcement or the Department of
Children and Families' hot line, 1-800-96-ABUSE.
 
As a concerned citizen, you have the opportunity to influence
legislation by contacting your local legislative delegation.  You may
wish to write to your senator or representative.  Governor Bush wants to
know how Floridians feel about the many critical issues we face, and
promises to keep your ideas in mind as he forms policy for addressing
these concerns.

The Governor appreciates your concerns about Mark Foley's conduct.
Needless to say, the Governor is very disappointed.   Governor Bush
asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to begin an inquiry.
Because there is also an ongoing investigation by the Federal Bureau of
Investigation, FDLE will be coordinating with the FBI, the lead agency
in the investigation. 

Thank you again for writing.  Governor Bush appreciates your concerns
about this serious issue and hopes this information is helpful.
 
Sincerely,
 
Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

children are molested and 1 in 3 female children are molested.
 
The law is setup not to help people who report it but to destroy them.
The alternative is to not report it and allow those children to commit
acts against other children or grow up and commit acts against other
teens.
 
Teen age pregnancy was a quiet secret till it became a big issue and
then we had family planning and other groups to help and support a big
problem.
 
Child molestation by other children is even bigger and all we do is put
them in JDC then wait till they commit other acts and put them in prison
 
Why not take this opportunity to step to the front of the line and do
something that would save our kids our teens and even lower the
molestation by working with them when they are young.
 
Statistically if you work them through a program they can be a positive
part of society 90% can live good lives
 
The other choice is to keep building prisons and to know that if your
kids were really honest you would find that they have dealt with this
but not told you
 
And when you gather a group of people together remember 1 in 4 and 1 in
3 and think of how many people are in the room with you who have been
molested and never got treatment because everyone was afraid to talk
 
How sad is life when we put our heads in the sand 
 
And yes I am available to speak to you any time
 
Let really make a difference
 
Thanks
Hugh

_______________/
Motion for new trial/rehearing
Since the last hearing with General Magistrate Joe Lovelace on April 27th 2006 the defendant filed another motion and also hired an attorney (Karen Glover) to accompany him to the hearing with Judge Cynthia Newton on July 11, 2006. Judge Newton referred the case back to General Magistrate Joe Lovelace but I have been unable to get a final hearing set because of the continuous delays by the defendant and his attorney. After the hearing on July 11, I was asked by Karen Glover to provide a copy of the buyers order on the purchase of my car which includes a balance due on the car in question (2003 Ford Focus). I provided that information on August 14, 2006 and tried repeatedly to contact Karen Glovers office to confirm receipt and ask for final hearing to be set. I did not get a return call until September 18, 2006, which was after call the Bar Association and Consumer Services, and at that time I was informed that there was still no hearing date, that she had sent me a copy of a referral to return to the General Magistrate and to inform me that her office will be closed from September 22 through October 9, 2006. 
I implore you to allow me to schedule the final hearing date so that I can go on with my life. I informed Governor Bush regarding this ordeal and they referred me to a Legal Hotline where I was informed(26 September) that I could file a motion for the final hearing. I cannot afford an attorney and should not need one because this is a simple divorce. I appreciate anything you and your office can do to help me finalize this divorce.
My mailing adress: POBOX 5585,Clearwater,FL,33758
Sinserely,
Vera Romelotti
Victim/Spouse 09/27/06
Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> wrote:

Dear Ms. Romelotti:

Thank you for writing again.

As previously explained, the Governor has no legal jurisdiction to intervene on your behalf. This is a judicial matter and the Governor of Florida is not a member of the Judicial branch of government nor can we provide legal advice or assistance in this regard. We are sorry to learn of your difficulty and encourage you to work with legal counsel to resolve this situation to your satisfaction.

Thank you again for writing.

Sincerely,

Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

Governor Jeb Bush wrote:
Dear Ms. Romelotti:

Thank you for writing again to Governor Bush. The Governor asked me to respond on his behalf.

As indicated in our previous correspondence, the Governor of Florida does not have legal jurisdiction to intervene on your behalf in a dissolution of marriage. 
The person who can best answer your legal questions is an attorney. If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011. For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services or your local legal aid office has information about the availability of pro bono counsel. The main telephone number for Florida Legal Services is 850-385-7900.

Thank you again for writing. The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance. Because this office does not have legal jurisdiction in this matter, I encourage you to immediately seek legal counsel to help you resolve this situation.

Sincerely,

Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

Judge Newton referred the case back to General Magistrate Joe Lovelace but I have been unable to get a final hearing set because of the continuous delays by the defendant and his attorney. After the hearing on July 11, I was asked by Karen Glover to provide a copy of the buyer's order on the purchase of my car which includes a balance due on the car in question (2003 Ford Focus). I provided that information on August 14, 2006 and tried repeatedly to contact Karen Glover's office to confirm receipt and ask for final hearing to be set. I did not get a return call until September 18, 2006, which was after call the Bar Association and Consumer Services, and at that time I was informed that there was still no hearing date, that she had sent me a copy of a referral to return to the General Magistrate and to inform me that her office will be closed from September 22 through October 9, 2006. 
I implore you to allow me to schedule the final hearing date so that I can go on with my life. I informed Governor Bush regarding this ordeal and they referred me to a Legal Hotline where I was informed(26 September) that I could file a motion for the final hearing. I cannot afford an attorney and should not need one because this is a simple divorce. I appreciate anything you and your office can do to help me finalize this divorce.
My mailing adress: POBOX 5585,Clearwater,FL,33758
Sinserely,
Vera Romelotti
Victim/Spouse 09/27/06

Governor Jeb Bush wrote:
Dear Ms. Romelotti:

Thank you for writing again to Governor Bush. The Governor asked me to respond on his behalf.

As indicated in our previous correspondence, the Governor of Florida does not have legal jurisdiction to intervene on your behalf in a dissolution of marriage. 
The person who can best answer your legal questions is an attorney. If you need assistance in locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 1-800-342-8011. For those unable to afford a lawyer, Florida Legal Services or your local legal aid office has information about the availability of pro bono counsel. The main telephone number for Florida Legal Services is 850-385-7900.

Thank you again for writing. The Governor is sorry to learn of the problems you are facing and wishes he could be of more assistance. Because this office does not have legal jurisdiction in this matter, I encourage you to immediately seek legal counsel to help you resolve this situation.

Sincerely,

Warren Davis
Office of Citizens' Services

I thank the Governor for his kind response.

As I understand the answer the Attorney General who is part of the executive 
branch has little or no role with the Local State Attorneys that are members 
of the executive branch. Local Judges are elected but part of the Judicial 
system. Election does not make a position independent of the rules or the 
law but have the same responsibilities of appointed officials. Everyone is 
required to follow the law and no one is above the law.

It may be possible to ask the Attorney Generals office to make an inquiry 
without an suggestion of pressure or improper interference.

The Chief executive is sworn to see the laws are fairly executed and support 
and defend the constitution. The laws include the application of the civil 
and criminal laws - he has the power to remove Judges or State Attorneys 
that are in gross violation of the law or ask the Judicial Review counsels 
or the Supreme Court to see if there is the chance of public corruption or 
executive prejudice or incompetence.

From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: "Peter Pflaum" <wiredbrain@hotmail.com>
Subject: RE: Please Governor Bush look into this case.
Date: Mon, 2 Oct 2006 14:23:21 -0400

Dear Mr. Pflaum:

Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush.  The Governor asked me to 
respond.

As you may know, the decision to charge a person for crimes is made by the 
state attorney, a locally elected official.  Deciding whether or not to 
charge a person is based on the best interests of justice and on the 
quantity and quality of the evidence of criminal activity.

The Florida Constitution limits the Governor's intervention in matters that 
should be resolved through the court system.  If you believe you are 
innocent, or not guilty of all charges, you may wish to obtain the services 
of an attorney experienced in criminal defense. If you need assistance in 
locating an attorney, please call the Florida Bar's Referral Service at 
1-800-342-8011.  Those who are facing criminal charges for which prison time 
is a possibility, may be appointed an attorney by the court.  Governor Bush 
does not have the ability to intervene in this regard.  For further 
assistance in this regard, please contact the office of your locally elected 
public defender.  Please be sure the attorney is provided with all of the 
evidence you believe shows innocence.

For further assistance with the probate issues you described, I encourage 
you to seek assistance from private legal counsel.

The Governor trusts justice will be served in this case.

						Sincerely,



						Warren Davis
						Office of Citizens' Services

From:	Squires,Angelique,TAMPA,Retail <angie.squires@waters.nestle.com>
Sent:	Sunday, October 1, 2006 9:13 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Florida Statute 61.13

One more thing, Mr. Bush.  Before you brush this aside, imagine if it was your daughter this was happening to. 

	 -----Original Message----- 
From:   Squires,Angelique,TAMPA,Retail  
Sent:   Sunday, October 01, 2006 8:30 AM 
To:     'jeb.bush@myflorida.com' 
Subject:        Florida Statute 61.13 
Importance:     High 

	Dear Mr. Bush,  (Grab a cup of coffee...This is about 3 pages but it's worth your time.) 

	As a FORCED resident of Florida and a conservative, I am asking you to read the following.  Earlier this year you signed an amendment to Florida Statute 61.13, although I don't believe you actually understand the consequences of such a law.  I am a VICTIM of its prior form, and I am begging you for your help.  I already wrote your office about this matter earlier this year.  I received a response that said it was not within your power or area of responsibility...something like that, but IT IS WITHIN YOUR POWER to get SOMEONE to help me.  YOU SIGNED THIS AMENDMENT, therefore YOU HAVE A HAND IN MY IMPRISONMENT.

	I wake up every day knowing that there are bars around me.  You can liken it to being accused and imprisoned for a crime you didn't commit.  Yes, the bars are 100 miles wide, but they are just as oppressive and mentally unbearable.  Worse, because my new husband fell in love with me, he had to make the choice to voluntarily imprison his own self.  Do you have any idea of how this feels?

	I've already tried the legal system.  You have to help us.  You helped Terry Schiavo and she was brain-dead.  We're not brain-dead.  We're living, feeling, contributing members of this United States society, and we deserve the same freedoms as any other law-abiding member of this country.

	THE UNACCEPTABLE DETAILS: 

	Almost 3 years ago my ex-husband left me for his mistress.  He had cheated with different women and left once before.  He had cheated when I was 5 months pregnant with our son.  He cheated a couple of months after our son was born, left me, only to return home a few months later.  He finally left for good when our son was 2-years old for his latest conquest, which he married and has a daughter with now.

	Thank God for unanswered prayers, as the Garth Brooks song goes.  Unfortunately Florida is a No-Fault state, and please dont think this message has to do with division of property.  I dont care about that at all.  What I do care about is a total lack of respect for my personal freedom, feelings and Constitutional Rights!!  Considering his total lack of moral character, I am not surprised that my ex is comfortable still violating my rights.  What is totally unacceptable and surprising is that the State of Florida and the County of Hillsborough has backed him up and unjustly imprisoned my current family and me, apparently for the next 13 years!!

	During our divorce proceedings, my ex and I had attended a mandatory mediation hearing where we signed a Pre-Judgment Agreement.  Before signing that, the Geographic Restriction section had been crossed out.  Instead of rubber-stamping our Agreement in her Final Judgment, the judge in our case injected a statement in our Judgment that said I could not relocate with our son further than 100 miles without her permission or that of my exs.  In hindsight I realize I should have appealed it at the time, but I didnt think much of it then.  Surely I thought that if a genuine opportunity for life advancement came along, the judge would rule in my favor.  Was I ever wrong!!!

	A few years ago, apparently at the urging of actively lobbying men's groups, the Florida law concerning child relocation was changed.  Formerly the State assumption was in favor of relocation, given that the move was for valid, non-vindictive reasons and not intended just to interfere with the other parent's visitation.  The Florida law governing relocation at the time of my court case was Florida Statute 61.13(2)(d):

	d) No presumption shall arise in favor of or against a request to relocate when a primary residential parent seeks to move the child and the move will materially affect the current schedule of contact and access with the secondary residential parent. In making a determination as to whether the primary residential parent may relocate with a child, the court must consider the following factors: 

	1. Whether the move would be likely to improve the general quality of life for both the residential parent and the child. 

	2. The extent to which visitation rights have been allowed and exercised. 
3. Whether the primary residential parent, once out of the jurisdiction, will be likely to comply with any substitute visitation arrangements. 

	4. Whether the substitute visitation will be adequate to foster a continuing meaningful relationship between the child and the secondary residential parent. 

	5. Whether the cost of transportation is financially affordable by one or both parties. 
6. Whether the move is in the best interests of the child. 
The UNCONSTITUTIONALITY of this statute is multi-faceted.  This law allows for a judge to override a presumption within the Florida Constitution that a parent knows and acts in the best interest of their children.  With no specific definitions of what constitutes an improvement in "quality of life" and the overriding subjectivity allowed by the 6th measure, biased Florida judges are acting upon their own beliefs, literally imprisoning custodial parents and destroying families' lives.

	If a working mother of two could become a stay-at-home mother, would that be an improvement to quality of life?  What if they could move from a small apartment where her boys shared a room to a 3,000 sq. ft. home, where the boys could have their own rooms and a big backyard?  Would that be an improvement?  ABSOLUTELY NOTNOT ACCORDING TO JUDGE MONICA SIERRA OF HILLSBOROUGH COUNTY.  Fact: Sierra never approves relocations, and the current Florida law allows her to continue as such.  Even when you pass the first 5 measures, Sierra's Orders deny relocation on the basis of the 6th factor.  "Sure, you passed the test, but I don't think so.  I know better than you what's best for your children."

	My own relocation request was based on two promotions, my own and that of my new husband.  (Most relocations are based on one family promotion, so we started the court process feeling pretty confident, especially since my son's visitation with his father was only decreasing by 10 days...75 overnights vs. his then 85.)  Unfortunately my case was assigned to Judge Sierra, and she of course decided that we didn't show any evidence of an improvement.  It didn't matter that the promotions meant $25,000 more per year.  It didn't matter that I had turned down 3 other promotions that would have placed us further away than the South Carolina move we were requesting.  It didn't matter that the house was bigger and on 10 acres, with a lifestyle that we couldn't afford within the state of Florida.  (This was a newer 3,400 sq. ft. house on 10 acres for $324,900.  That would be over $1 million in Florida, and completely out of our reach!) 

	I am not a convicted felon.  I am not a meth addict on welfare.  (If I were, the ACLU would certainly be beating down my door.)  Nonetheless, I am imprisoned by the State of Florida.  My Constitutional rights of DUE PROCESS, PRIVACY, FREEDOM TO TRAVEL and EQUAL PROTECTION have all been squashed.  No big deal?  You cannot imagine the devastating and overwhelming feeling of being trapped, caged within 100 miles, stuck at our current job levels with no hopes or aspirations, AND I AM NOT ALONE.  (I know 5 other women just in Hillsborough County that are in similar situations.)

	Do you understand?  The State of Florida is saying that our families do not deserve to aspire!!!!!!  Theyre saying we can never improve our lives.  My husband and I are both at the top level possible within the state of Florida in our respective industries.  Do you think they have a right to tell us that THIS IS IT?!!  As it stands, the only aspiration were allowed to have is, Gee, we just need to do well enough not to get fired.  Why bother to do better?  It doesnt matter if we deserve to be promoted.  Were not allowed!!  God, please help us.  This is not my America!!!

	Why is my ex husband allowed to make all the immoral choices he made, and the only ones paying the bill are my current family and me?  I didnt do anything, and now the State treats me like Im lucky to have primary residential custody of my son.  Theyre acting like Im not a good mother because I have to work.  Theyre acting like Im not a good mother because I aspire to a better life.  (Please dont misunderstand me.  My life is all about my son.  I work to live.  I dont live to work, but I do deserve to excel in life if my performance proves worthy, just like the next person.)

	This October, the Florida law governing relocation will be changed.  The new law is even more UNCONSTITUTIONAL.  Before addressing that though, consider the impractical process of applying for relocation in the first place.  In my case, I had to accept the promotion before I was able to go before the judge.  Im sure this is true in 95% of the cases.  The court process takes 6+ months, not including appeal.  So I ask you, what corporation is willing to wait more than a few weeks for an answer to an offer of promotion?  Youre forced to roll the dice, major dice.  Youre forced to risk your career, livelihood, finances, happiness and CUSTODY, all in hopes that the judge rules in your favor.  Theres no common sense, fairness or practicality to this system!!

	Lets not pretend its ever based on the actual merits of your case anyway.  Of course, I appealed Judge Sierras appalling decision.  Unfortunately the lead judge on my appellant panel was a divorced father himself.  And I quote, If your client wants to move so badly, why doesnt she just give custody to the father?  (Oh yes.  I should sit quietly and be grateful that my ex cheated on me incessantly, left me, and now I should give up our son in exchange for my freedom.  That sounds fair.  Thank God I had the self-control not to jump that railing and punch him in his fat face!!  One year and $50k later, I was left defeated and close to jobless.  Thankfully, I work for the most wonderful corporation ever and another lateral position surfaced for me in Florida, but I have ZERO chances of ever being promoted now.)

	The late 2006 amended version of Florida Statute 61.13 includes such ridiculous and blatant Constitutional violations as including the rights of 3rd parties.  Its overbearing premise states that if no geographic agreement exists, the State assumes an automatic 50-mile restriction!!  And get a load of the following factor it considers

	 The current employment and economic circumstances of each parent 
or other person and whether or not the proposed relocation is necessary to 
improve the economic circumstances of the parent or other person seeking 
relocation of the child.  

	Im sorry.  Do I understand that correctly?  Is this America?  Are they saying that the State has the right to determine if I need to make more money?!!

	Look, I dont have a bunch of money to spend on this, but I need help.  I feel like suing the State is my only option at this point.  Please, what are my options?  Who can and will help me?  Please, I cannot, should not and will not live like this for the next 13 years.

	Your time, help and consideration are greatly appreciated.  Thank you and God Bless. 

	Angie Squires 
Bradenton, FL 
(813) 477-8034 
angie.squires@waters.nestle.com <mailto:angie.squires@waters.nestle.com>
